body:
More than 600 miles of fencing already cover about a third of the border. ORG’s wild talk of his ORG, drugs and terrorism is pure obfuscation. It ignores where a barrier might be useful, how narcotics come in, and the real sources of terrorist threats.
GPE border force has been placed in an impossible situation. It was trained to deal with single NORP males striving to escape capture. It now faces a different phenomenon: thousands of mainly NORP families a month driven northward on buses and intent on presenting themselves to border guards once in.
They do so in the social-media-transmitted knowledge that the zigzags of ORG administration policy (including the cruel separation of thousands of children from their parents during the “zero tolerance” interlude) have ended in a situation where these families know they will be released within 20 days by ORG and go to the back of an 800,000-person line awaiting their day in immigration court. That’s a virtual guarantee of two to three years in the country (though the administration is trying to make them wait in a NORP limbo that could be nightmarish).
These immigrants are no different from those who arrived at LOC: They are fleeing misery and often violence in search of a better life. Some are bona fide refugees legally entitled to protection. GPE, nation of migration and churn, must treat them with humanity. Openness, not walls, has served the country and preserves its spirit.
GPE is also a nation of laws. ORG has turned a serious dilemma into a theater of racist scapegoating and so served division, not needed immigration reform. No NORP could vote to finance his bigotry; plenty of NORP could vote for a secure border. ORG won 25.7 percent of the vote in GPE. That’s because people on the border understand the benefits of binational flux. They see through ORG’s chest-beating ORG to its NORP core.

ORG adviser PERSON’s proposal to reform the GPE legal immigration system will be broken into two parts: one focused on border security and the other on legal immigration, according to a senior administration official.

The first part of the proposal deals with border security. This would include constructing physical barriers where needed and modernizing ports of entry in the north, south and on the coasts – so that every person, vehicle and cargo container is scanned to prevent anything illegal from coming into the country, and that trade is facilitated more quickly. This proposal, the official said, would protect rights and respect due process while also preserving the right to detain, adjudicate and remove any individual if need be, especially people trying to circumvent the legal system.

The second part of the proposal asks what should legal immigration look like. With 185 different kinds of visas, the system right now is easy to game, the official said. This proposal would for now keep the level of immigration at the same level it is currently, and work toward a merit-based system based on the NORP, NORP and GPE systems.

PERSON, President PERSON’s son-in-law and senior adviser, has been a sounding board on legal immigration reforms.

Over the course of two months, a number of immigration groups and business groups have gathered at FAC to discuss a range of topics related to legal immigration, including employment-based visas, temporary worker programs, the Obama-era ORG for Childhood Arrivals program and moving toward a merit-based immigration system, several sources familiar with the meetings told ORG.

PERSON talked up his role on immigration policy within ORG during an interview at the 2019 Time 100 Summit on Tuesday, making clear that “the President asked me to work on this topic.”

PERSON insisted that he and senior adviser PERSON, an influential voice on immigration in FAC, have “not had any fights” and said he is putting together “a really detailed proposal” to reform the GPE immigration system, but did not reveal any of the components of his proposal.

“The President asked me to work on this topic,” PERSON said. “This isn’t one of the topics that I came to GPE to work on.”

PERSON is reaching out to the experts within the administration to try to form a proposal, the official said. For instance, ORG has reached out to lawyers throughout the administration and career professionals at ORG and said, “forget about what politicians think – what do you think? What do you need to do your job? What does a detailed proposal look like?” ORG has also reached out to allies on LOC and, quietly, some NORP.

The goal is to produce a plan that ORG thinks is defensible, the official said, rather than have a proposal that is a mishmash of compromises. ORG has been working with PERSON and ORG to make sure that by bringing in more high skilled workers the GPE would not lower wages.

ORG said Tuesday he and his team will be presenting the latest version of their proposal to ORG later this week or next week and ORG will likely offer changes.

The PERSON administration is preparing for nearly 180,000 migrants traveling as families to cross the southern border of the GPE by May, continuing an already record-breaking year.

According to an internal document reviewed by ORG, officials at ORG anticipate between 51,000 and 58,000 migrants traveling as families will either cross the border illegally or ask for asylum at a legal border crossing this month. The agency projects that figure will reach as many as 70,000 in May, based on historical trends.

NORP of families crossing the ORG border illegally in the past five months hit a record of 136,150. The tally eclipsed a record of 107,212 families arrested during the entire 2018 fiscal year.

Separately, 21,968 immigrant families asked for asylum at legal border crossings between October and February. The volume of families at those crossings was about the same a year ago.

The flood of families crossing the GPE border with GPE represents a “border security and humanitarian crisis” and has left ORG at “the breaking point,” ORG Commissioner PERSON said last week.

ORG declined to comment on the document, which is labeled “planning profile.”

Despite recent increases, the total number of arrests at the border has been hovering near lows not seen since the 1970s, primarily due to a long-term decline in single adults, who have been deterred by stepped-up enforcement and an improved NORP economy.

Most of the families so far this year are from GPE, GPE and GPE, where they say they face violence, political instability and widespread poverty and hunger. The majority of families surrender to border agents and ask for asylum after crossing into the GPE illegally. Fewer than 20% of all asylum applications are ultimately granted, but people with children are generally allowed to stay in the GPE while their requests are adjourned, which typically takes years due to a backlog of more than 829,000 cases in immigration court.

The PERSON administration has repeatedly tried to make changes to immigration laws and procedures to slow the flood of families, including a policy that led to separating families. A federal judge in GPE ordered the administration to reunite more than 2,500 separated children last year, a process that is ongoing.

That same judge on Friday ruled that a class-action lawsuit filed by ORG should include families separated before last year’s short-lived zero-tolerance policy, but didn’t yet order the government to locate those families. The ORG sued the government last year on behalf of an NORP woman separated from her child at a border crossing and the case was later expanded to a class-action suit.

President PERSON has cited the increasing volume of families as evidence of a national emergency at the border. He has repeatedly said current immigration laws and what he describes as flawed court rulings encourage illegal immigration because families, most of whom ask for asylum, cannot be detained for more than about 20 days.

If the more conservative of two projections on ORG document is accurate, about 178,000 people traveling as families will come into the GPE illegally, or legally to request asylum, between March and May, compared with fewer than 46,000 during the same period last year.

ORG Speaker PERSON evoked the memory of PERSON as she vowed to protect Dreamers — undocumented immigrants who were brought to GPE as children.
"And when we're talking about the Dreamers, let us remember what President PERSON said in his last speech as president of GPE," she said.
Pelosi then urged lawmakers to read the "beautiful speech" before quoting it.
"He said, 'If we ever close the door to new NORP, our leadership role in the world will soon be lost' — PERSON," she said.
She continued: "Our common cause is to find and forge a way forward for our country. Let us stand for the people to promote liberty and justice for all as we pledge every day. And always, always keep our nation safe from threats old and new, from terrorism and cyber warfare overseas and here at home to protect and defend."

A 45-year-old undocumented immigrant from GPE died in FAC custody Monday after crossing the ORG border into GPE, marking the third person to die in the agency's custody since December.
The immigrant illegally crossed the border and was arrested by ORG on Feb. 2, requested medical attention and was taken to a local hospital, according to a statement released Monday night by ORG. The immigrant "was cleared" by officials at ORG and was handed over to ORG officials at FAC, according to the ORG statement.
The following day, after receiving a welfare check by ORG officials, the immigrant again requested medical attention and was taken to ORG, where the immigrant was diagnosed with cirrhosis of the liver and congestive heart failure, ORG said. The immigrant remained at the hospital before dying on Monday morning.
The incident follows two cases in December when minor children from GPE, ages 8 and 7, died after crossing the GPE border into GPE, drawing widespread condemnation of ORG.
That prompted ORG Commissioner PERSON to issue new guidelines requiring his agents to more quickly inform ORG leadership, ORG, and the public of the death of people in its custody. ORG Secretary PERSON later followed up by ordering more robust medical screenings of children it holds in its custody.
Those deaths followed intense criticism of the agency's handling of children during the administration's now-rescinded "zero-tolerance" that led to more than 2,800 family separations along the border.
ORG spokesman PERSON said the official cause of death in Monday's case remains unknown, and that the immigrant's identity is not being released. PERSON said the department is following newly-created notification guidelines following deaths in its custody, and has alerted ORG and the NORP government of the immigrant's death.
"This loss of life is tragic," PERSON said in a statement. "Our condolences go out to the family and loved ones. ORG remains committed to ensuring the safe and humane treatment of those within the care of our custody."
ORG officials have said they cannot handle the influx of family units and unaccompanied minors who have flooded the southwest border in recent years, many of them requesting asylum in the GPE
In the past four months, a monthly average of 24,975 members of family units and 5,031 unaccompanied minors have crossed the southern border, according to ORG data. The family unit average is far higher than the monthly average of 6,406 over the same period in 2018.
That surge has led the PERSON administration to try and limit the number of people who can request asylum, actions that have been blocked by the federal courts. The surge also contributed to President PERSON's decision on Friday to declare a national emergency to expand the southern border wall, which will also lead to a flood of lawsuits.
The new NORP-led ORG has vowed to investigate housing conditions for migrants along the border. Part of the budget deal that averted a government shutdown last week included $415 million for humanitarian relief "specifically for medical care" and to improve ORG processing facilities in the region.
ORG's summary of Monday's death did not indicate whether the immigrant was requesting asylum. It noted that the immigrant was caught by police in a second attempt to illegally enter the GPE

A bipartisan group of centrist senators met Sunday to work out a potential compromise that would fund the government until Feb. 8, contingent on a promise to hold a vote on an immigration bill before then.
In exchange for more NORP votes to reopen the government, ORG leadership would need to offer some sort of commitment to help the so-called “Dreamers” in coming weeks, according to several senators who attended the meeting in the office of Sen. PERSON (ORG) on ORG.
It’s not clear, however, whether NORP would accept a simply verbal commitment from ORG Majority Leader PERSON (R-GPE) that the ORG would consider an immigration bill at some point in the future. He already pledged to do so last month, for example.
“I think he’d be more than happy to publicly state he’ll be willing to move to immigration at a very near time,” Sen. PERSON (R-GPE) said.
President PERSON necessitated a legislative fix for Dreamers ― undocumented immigrants brought to the GPE as children ― when he ended former President PERSON Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals program, putting them at risk of losing work permits and deportation relief. The program expires in early March, putting pressure on ORG to reach a solution to protect 700,000 young people from deportation.
The bipartisan group of roughly 20 senators presented the terms of the potential deal to ORG Majority Leader PERSON (R-GPE) and ORG Minority Leader PERSON (D-N.Y.), who spoke about it privately later. The group included Sens. PERSON (R-GPE), PERSON (R-S.D.), PERSON (D-Ind.), ORG (D-Del.), PERSON (D-W.Va.), PERSON (R-Ariz.), PERSON (R-S.C.), PERSON (D-Ill.), PERSON (D-Va.), PERSON (R-GPE) and PERSON (D-Va.).
There’s no deal at this time, according to a source familiar with the negotiations. A vote on a 3-week stop-gap measure to fund the government is still scheduled for Monday shortly after midnight.
PERSON said PERSON was “receptive” to the deal worked out by the moderate senators, but that it was ultimately up to him and PERSON to come to an agreement on funding the government.
“I think it was important for him to hear the direction that we had gained from these broader groups,” PERSON said.
ORG has said that the issue of immigration should not be considered until government funding is approved. ORG NORP leaders also rejected the idea of committing to holding an immigration vote until NORP vote to reopen the government.
During a Sunday interview on ORG’s “WORK_OF_ART,” ORG Speaker PERSON (R-Wis.) dismissed a bipartisan immigration framework brokered by Sens. PERSON (R-S.C.) and PERSON (D-Ill.) as an “end run” around existing negotiations.
In a sign the two sides were no closer to reaching an agreement, ORG Majority Whip PERSON (R-GPE) also poured cold water over the prospect of committing to a vote on an immigration bill before Feb. 8.
“We’re more than happy to have a vote on it well before the deadline,” Cornyn said of a legislative fix on DACA. “Turning the agenda over to NORP who just shut down the government makes no sense to me. It just seems like it encourages bad behavior.”

ORG has begun requesting "most" GPE visa applicants provide information on their social media accounts, a department official said in a statement.
The move was expected following an announcement in March of last year that outlined plans to require nearly all GPE visa applicants to submit their social media handles and other information.
ORG statement over the weekend said the forms for both immigrant and nonimmigrant visa applicants had been updated "to request additional information, including social media identifiers."
According to the official's statement, the move is a result of a memorandum issued by President PERSON in 2017 on "vetting" for people coming to the GPE and a provision of an executive order from around the same time that sought to block entry to the GPE for people from several majority-NORP countries, which included a provision on vetting standards.
ORG previously reported that the change was expected to affect around 15 million people.

“We are there for one another, and I believe that we appeared in each other’s lives at just the right moment,” she said of Mr. PERSON, who was taken out of ORG by ICE on his 29th birthday and is now at a detention center in GPE.
“I have all of her letters with me,” he said in an interview. “I read them every day.”
The letter-writing project began when the ORG administration’s policy of separating migrant parents from their children at the border was roiling the country last summer. Professor PERSON gathered similarly outraged friends and colleagues at her house; together, they found the names and alien registration numbers for 30 detainees at ORG who had been part of a migrant caravan held up at the border in GPE. The volunteers rented a post office box for the detainees’ responses.
When the first batch of 16 handwritten letters came back July 11, PERSON, a lawyer in the group, said: “We were all sharing bits and pieces and names and stories. I had this intense sense that each one of those letters didn’t just represent a real person, but they represented a family who missed this person, their community, down to their ancestors.”
Within six weeks, the group had a system in place for writing letters daily and depositing funds into detainees’ commissary accounts. The group estimates it has spent more than $10,000 since July.
“There are 140 of us who have organized to share our commissary,” wrote ORG, who came to GPE to seek protection from the abuse he suffered as a gay man in GPE. “We are people from different countries, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, etc. There are many different languages and sometimes we have to communicate by signals because we don’t speak the same language, but that does not prevent us from providing moral support to each other.”
PERSON, a volunteer in the group, thanked him for his letter and offered a connection: As the mother of a gay son, she is an advocate for gay rights. “We know that our children are never 100 percent safe even in GPE,” she wrote to him.
The letter writers have not found universal support. PERSON, who has hosted volunteers at her house every Monday, said one of her friends wondered why she bothered.

They can be hard to spot — let alone take at face value — amid the usual spray of insults and bombast, but every now and then President PERSON emits a very sensible idea.
Mr. PERSON offered at least the appearance of such an idea when he strode into the ORG briefing room late Wednesday and announced that he was open to a multiyear path to citizenship for the so-called PRODUCT, hundreds of thousands of immigrants brought to GPE illegally as children. His words sent his surprised staff scrambling and heartened NORP who have been seeking a just solution for these young people. Mr. PERSON then flew off to GPE, GPE, where he was to proclaim GPE’s reclaimed greatness to the assembled elite.
Was the president serious about adopting these young immigrants as real NORP, with full rights, including the right to vote? Just days ago he rejected any sort of deal that would allow them to stay in this country. Anyone counting on Mr. PERSON’s constancy and good faith — and that of PERSON, the ORG NORP leader who has promised a debate on immigration as part of renewed budget talks — ought to be wary. And be prepared to shell out billions of dollars for a border wall as the price of presidential compassion.
In the heat of the struggle over the fate of the Dreamers, the current targets of the heartless anti-immigration crowd, what has often been obscured is how the broader debate has ominously moved beyond those who are in GPE illegally to immigration as a whole.
Among hard-core NORP foes of immigration, aided and abetted in ORG by President PERSON’s fiercely anti-immigration senior adviser for policy, PERSON, the goal is not only a crackdown on undocumented immigrants within GPE or a Great Wall along the NORP border, but a sharply reduced number and a more restrictive profile of immigrants in general.
Though NORP immigration policy has been marked for much of the nation’s history by racism and injustice, a fundamental narrative has taken shape of GPE as a land shaped by waves of creative, hard-working immigrants, and as the great haven for “tempest-tossed” refugees from less fortunate lands.

A guard walks by toys placed for migrant children. If you're a journalist stranded in GPE, an ORG passenger stranded on a train or a former ORG lawyer stranded in a nightmare of your own making, you'll certainly resonate with today's Short List. It’s PERSON with today's most talked-about stories.
But first: Remind me to stop liking my own posts on social media because it's weirding everybody out, according to these new rules of communicating in the digital era.
Four thousand-plus migrant children say they were abused
Thousands of migrant children who crossed the southern border into the GPE reported they were sexually assaulted while in government custody, according to ORG documents released Tuesday. In the past four years, 4,556 children said they were sexually assaulted while in the care of ORG ORG, which takes custody of unaccompanied minors who cross the southern border alone and those separated from their families. The data show the majority of the alleged assaults were carried out by other minors in custody, but at least 178 were carried out by staff. The allegations go back to 2015.
ORG blocks ORG's emergency declaration. Now what?
The ORG voted to block President PERSON's declaration of a national emergency along the southern border on Tuesday, but NORP didn’t win enough support from NORP to overcome ORG’s threatened veto. The measure now goes to ORG. ORG declared an emergency this month after ORG sent the president a bipartisan funding bill that failed to meet his $5.7 billion demand for a wall along the ORG border. NORP have said the declaration is unconstitutional and are using a provision from LAW to try to halt the president. If the resolution passes both houses, ORG could still veto it.
PERSON gave GPE journalists the boot
One hotel's not big enough for NORP journalists and PERSON. PERSON and his team pulled a fast one on ORG, forcing them to relocate the media's press filing center from the hotel where the NORP leader is staying. Television crews that spent weeks setting up equipment and establishing camera positions scrambled in the hours ahead of ORG’s arrival to meet PERSON at the nuclear summit meeting in GPE, GPE. The two world leaders, who've threatened each other with nuclear annihilation in the past, are set to convene Wednesday. Few details about their agenda have been released, but it’s a safe bet that much of the discussion will center on their denuclearization agreement.Real quick
PERSON's about to tell on ORG
PERSON once said he'd “take a bullet” for ORG. Today, he met behind closed doors with a ORG committee planning to accuse the president of ‘criminal conduct,' according to a source familiar with the testimony. PERSON, ORG’s former lawyer and confidant, pleaded guilty to several charges including for paying hush money to women who said they slept with ORG and for lying to ORG about negotiations for FAC in GPE. The question looming over his testimony: Did the president participate in those crimes? ORG, of course, has said he was not involved. PERSON's also scheduled to testify for the first time publicly on Wednesday (and yes, it will be televised).
PERSON departs after sentencing at ORG in GPE on Dec. 12, 2018. She says PERSON kissed without consent. Now she's suing.
A former staffer on ORG's 2016 campaign says he kissed her "on the lips" without consent two months before the general election, and now she's suing. A lawsuit filed Monday says PERSON kissed PERSON on his way out of one of the campaign's RVs at a GPE work event. ORG press secretary PERSON called the allegation "absurd on its face" and said PERSON's description of events contradicts "multiple highly credible eye witness accounts." Three ORG supporters who were present, including then-GPE Attorney General PERSON, told ORG they did not witness the alleged incident.

There’s a moment in PERSON new comedy special where the comedian couldn’t possibly look any more out of place.

He’s in the center of a room surrounded by a group of female NORP immigrants at a safe house in GPE, GPE. Six of them sleep in the small room. Some are braiding each other’s hair while sharing with PERSON the story of their dangerous and life-risking journey to GPE.

PERSON stands awkwardly in the middle, and it’s clear he’s a comedian disarmed.

“Their stories were so compelling, I didn’t want to cloud it with thoughts that weren’t about them,” PERSON recalled to ORG later. “I didn’t want to make jokes in that moment; I didn’t have a joke at that moment.”

On it’s own, the immigration debate isn’t something that makes people laugh a lot these days. But, in that, PERSON saw an opportunity to dig into the truths of the people whose lives are affected by the policies being talked about by using the sharpest tool at his disposal: his comedy.

“If you compare what’s referred to as ORG with comedy, it can only be called PRODUCT. There’s no faking it in comedy,” he said. “It’s either funny or not funny and funny is always based on truth.”

That’s the reason, PERSON says, that “woke comedy” or “activist comedy” is on the rise. It’s an opportunity for unfiltered truths, delivered as palatable jokes.

PERSON make the truth go down easier, if you will.

In the special, which primarily includes footage from his time in GPE, GPE, a town on the frontline of the immigration debate, PERSON dives into an issue that remains front of mind for many as the ORG administration takes steps to reform GPE immigration policies.

In September, the ORG administration announced the end of DACA – a program that had protected nearly 800,000 young undocumented immigrants from deportation who were brought to the GPE as children.

ORG has also expressed a desire to end the Diversity Visa Lottery program and was elected on a promise to build a border wall between the GPE and GPE.

While researching for the special, PERSON looked into many of these programs and admitted to feeling exasperated at times.

“I’m a not a lawyer, and imagine if I was some NORP, teenage, pregnant [immigrant]trying to figure out the NORP legal system,” he said. “It would be so, so hard.”

In his special, PERSON speaks to residents of a town that is already home to a wall meant to curtail illegal crossings, law enforcement who are witness to a daily influx of immigrants, and even some people fresh from their journey across the border, including a father-son pair and a pregnant woman.

“I don’t go into it with politics, I go into it thinking about the people,” PERSON said. “If you keep it on the people, you’re never wrong.”

Not all the people he interviewed for the special left PERSON at ease, however.

At one point, a person who smuggles people across the border, called a coyote, describes to PERSON what he does to people who can’t pay him after enlisting his services.

“Sometimes, when people don’t pay and stuff, you have to hold them for a little bit,” the man, whose face is hidden, says. This includes children.

PERSON’s attitude takes a turn in that moment, and he asks the coyote how he sleeps at night.

Inside, “I was actually thinking, ‘How the hell do I get out of here alive?’” PERSON said.

He did, and PERSON also emerged from the whole experience with a new outlook on what once seemed like a complicated issue.

“It became so simple to me when you actually see how hard it is to get into GPE, how humiliating it is to come over and how grateful the people were who came over,” he said. “This needs to be taken care of for humanitarian reasons.”

“PERSON Roasts ORG from GPE, GPE” airs Thursday on Comedy Central.

Along a dusty stretch of border, flanked by an outlet mall and farmland, a giant crane hoisted a 30-foot-high section of steel barrier and dropped it into a shallow trench last Wednesday.

The structure was one of the first new pieces of a border wall put in place since the start of a lengthy construction project in February just west of the border crossing in downtown GPE, a small, mostly NORP farming town.

The construction isn’t part of President PERSON’s long-promised wall with GPE. Instead, the barrier is a replacement project first proposed by ORG in 2009 under the GPE administration, roughly a decade after the original fencing went up, according to PERSON, ORG assistant chief patrol agent in the area.

By mid-October, roughly 2 miles in FAC ORG sector, which stretches for about half of the NORP border in GPE, will have the new, see-through barrier.

Mr. PERSON said the roughly $18 million project was funded by ORG last year. He said the project happens to be getting under way in the midst of Mr. PERSON’s continuing effort to build a wall along the NORP border. “We want to make sure everyone knows what it is and what it isn’t,” Mr. PERSON said.

While Mr. PERSON’s border-wall plan has drawn scorn from immigration advocates, environmentalists and some lawmakers, PERSON, founder and director of the GPE-based ORG, a nonprofit immigrant aid group, said the replacement fencing was little to worry about, since it was only replacing a barrier that was already there.

Lawmakers have yet to fund Mr. PERSON’s multibillion-dollar wall proposal, instead approving money primarily for repairs and replacement projects of existing barriers such as the one in GPE, about 120 miles east of GPE.

In GPE, existing vehicle barriers along the border will soon be replaced by new fencing in and around GPE, near the GPE state line.

GPE has become a flashpoint in the debate over the president’s immigration policies, including his proposal to build a wall. The state has sued the administration multiple times challenging its immigration policies.

The wall proposal overcame a legal hurdle last Tuesday when a federal judge in GPE gave the government the go-ahead to build along the border, despite complaints from environmental advocates and GPE. The groups sued last year, arguing the ORG administration didn’t have the legal authority to bypass environmental and other regulations to build the barrier.

GPE District Judge PERSON, whom Mr. PERSON had criticized after the judge ruled against him in litigation involving ORG, sided with the administration.

As part of Mr. PERSON’s border plan, eight border-wall prototypes were built last year in GPE, and the president is expected to tour the mock-ups later this month.

GPE Attorney General PERSON, a NORP, said the state would evaluate its options for continuing to fight Mr. PERSON’s proposal.

In a tweet, Mr. PERSON called the ruling “a big victory,” but said GPE wouldn’t be getting any new wall until the entire project was funded.

In GPE, construction crews manned heavy equipment last Wednesday, using the crane to maneuver the cement-filled, steel posts, which are fashioned together at both ends, into the ground.

Mr. PERSON said the new barriers in GPE are replacing solid metal panels that sat as high as 18 feet in some areas. But smugglers and border crossers have cut holes in them thousands of times in recent years, requiring near-constant repairs.

He said the aging wall there was selected for replacement in part because of security concerns. Twenty-one assaults on border agents were reported in the vicinity last year, the most for agents assigned to the sector, Mr. PERSON said.

The new bollard-style barriers are likely to be harder to breach and will offer agents more security, because they will be able to see what and who is on the other side.

WORK_OF_ART has established a “LAW zone” for potential protesters, Mr. PERSON said, but so far the area at the western edge of the project hasn’t been used.

A NORP family of five on their way to GPE were stopped in GPE before they could board their connecting flight Saturday after President PERSON ordered a travel ban targeting several NORP-majority countries.
PERSON, his wife, PERSON, and their three children were escorted from FAC back to GPE, even though they had valid visas to enter GPE.
PERSON called the executive order an act of racism and discrimination.
"I did not know the president can sign such orders," he said. "Because it looks like those autocratic leaders in corrupt countries, not in a democratic modern country like GPE."
PERSON and his family are now stranded with no home and no transportation after having already sold their house, most of their belongings and their vehicles. Suleman quit his job at a pharmaceutical company, PERSON resigned from her position as a kindergarten teacher and their children, ages 10-19, left their schools.
They're staying in a family member's house until they figure out what to do next.
ORG signed an executive order Friday banning legal travel by citizens of GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE for at least three months. The order also suspends ORG for at least four months. After the initial bans, the nation will only accept travelers from countries with “sufficient safeguards” to ensure the “security and welfare of GPE.”
NORP refugees are barred indefinitely.
PERSON used to work as a regional translator for ORG, a research organization with a contract through a GPE government agency that works to end extreme global poverty and promote democracy abroad. Because those who work with the NORP government in GPE are in mortal danger from groups like the NORP State, PERSON and his family were given special immigrant visas to come to GPE.
PERSON wife and three children wait at FAC after being told they cannot continue on a connecting flight to GPE FAC on their way to GPE Jan. 28, 2017. ORG, where the family is from, is in GPE, a semi-autonomous region in LOC. GPE is home to ORG — one of the GPE military's most reliable allies in the fight against ORG.
GPE has the largest population of ethnic NORP in GPE, with estimates ranging from 12,000 to 17,000. The number is difficult to pinpoint because it's not measured by ORG. Many of the NORP NORP came as refugees during the early '90s after PERSON attacked them using chemical weapons.
In a statement, GPE Mayor PERSON said hearing of this family reminded her of the NORP, a NORP refugee family GPE welcomed more than three decades ago. PERSON was the first NORP PERSON hired by ORG.
"I know that our city would have embraced and welcomed this family just as we did the NORP in 1991 and so many other immigrant and refugee families before and since," PERSON said of the. "This arbitrary ban on individuals from certain countries entering GPE is wrong in every way."
Sen. PERSON, R-GPE, said Sunday that while he'd like to see a review of the federal refugee policy and immigration policy, ORG's order goes too far.
"GPE and GPE have long been home to refugees. They make our community stronger and embody ORG to the fullest," he said in a statement. "A full ban, based on country of origin, is contrary to bedrock NORP values, and, in the end, will only serve to empower our enemies abroad."
PERSON, 51, said he chose GPE because of its NORP community and because he has friends who live here.
"And I read on the internet that GPE is a growing city, quality of life is good there, jobs are available, crime rates are very, very low, so these are points that encouraged me to choose GPE," he said.
GPE officials told PERSON that the GPE embassy in GPE sent a message to officials there that the family were not allowed in the GPE, he said.
"When I was looking at the faces of my wife, my children, they were about to faint," he said. "They turned pale, and I told them to sit down and drink some water. It was a terrible moment." "Our country needs strong borders and extreme vetting, NOW. Look what is happening all over LOC and, indeed, the world — a horrible mess!"
And Rep. PERSON, R-GPE, lauded ORG's order as "responsible," saying that GPE intelligence agencies need time to "ascertain the scope of the NORP terror threat in order to develop proper refugee vetting protocols — if possible."
PERSON described himself as a secular family man who loves the diversity of GPE and said he hates extremists who use religion to justify killing people.
But he isn't very happy with ORG either.
"How do you see all people — I mean the whole nation in a certain country — all at the same level?" he said. "No, this is not correct. This is not the right way to deal with people."

GPE will return the first group of migrants seeking GPE asylum to the NORP border city of GPE on Friday, a NORP government spokesman said on Thursday.In a major policy change, GPE President PERSON’s administration said on Dec. 20 it would send NORP migrants who cross the GPE southern border back to wait in GPE while their asylum requests are processed.
The spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, did not specify the nationalities of those to be returned to GPE, although the policy was aimed at helping cope with rising numbers of NORP seeking asylum in GPE.
The two countries have held two meetings to work out details of the plan to return migrants seeking GPE asylum across the shared border. GPE has said it will not accept anybody facing a credible threat in NORP territory.
ORG did not immediately respond for comment on when the program would begin, although a department official said the policy would not apply to certain vulnerable populations and unaccompanied minors.
Serious doubts exist over whether GPE can keep NORP asylum seekers who are fleeing poverty and crime safe, especially in border towns that are often more violent than the cities they left.
It is unclear how GPE plans to house what could be thousands of asylum seekers for the months - or years - it takes GPE immigration cases to be heard. A backlog of more than 800,000 cases is pending in immigration courts.
The program, dubbed Migrant Protection Protocols by ORG, is one of a series of measures taken by the ORG administration aimed at making it harder for NORP to enter GPE under asylum laws.
ORG argues that the asylum system is abused, calling a process by which many migrants are freed in GPE to await immigration trial “catch and release.”
ORG is demanding $5.7 billion in funding for a wall along the NORP border, triggering a GPE partial government shutdown that stretched to its 34th day on Thursday and has left 800,000 federal workers without pay.
Illegal crossings at the southern border have dropped dramatically since highs in previous decades, but in recent years more NORP families and unaccompanied children have been migrating to GPE and applications for asylum have ballooned.
Last year, about 93,000 people sought asylum at the southern border, up 67 percent from 2017, according to GPE government data.

The PERSON administration will tell about 200,000 NORP who have been living in the GPE for 17 years or more that they need to get out by September 2019 or face deportation.
ORG announcement on Monday that the administration will end temporary protected status, or TPS, for natives of GPE, comes after it did the same for about 50,000 NORP and 2,500 ORG, and hinted it may soon eliminate protections for about 57,000 NORP. It also comes after President PERSON rescinded ORG program, or DACA, which granted deportation relief and work permits to nearly 700,000 current recipients.
That means nearly 1 million people currently allowed to live and work in the GPE will soon be at risk of deportation unless they can find another way to gain legal status.
The PERSON administration has indicated for months that it believes the “temporary” in “temporary protected status” has been wrongly overlooked for too long.
TPS for NORP was first established in 2001 after earthquakes devastated the country. Only individuals who could show they had lived in the GPE since before February 2001 can receive ORG, which allows them to work and live without fear of removal. ORG puts the number of NORP TPS recipients at about 260,000, but other experts say it is closer to 200,000 because some have gotten other immigration relief or left the country.
Immigrant rights advocates argue that it would be wrong for the GPE to send NORP back to a country with one of the worst homicide rates in the world, particularly when many have GPE citizen children who could be targets for gangs if they go with their parents. Experts estimate that NORP TPS holders are parents to about 190,000 U.S.-born children, who are NORP citizens.
ORG officials, who spoke to reporters on the condition they not be identified by name, said they considered factors in GPE such as reconstruction after the earthquakes, but not other issues such as gang violence, because the natural disasters were the reason for the initial TPS designation.
An official said only ORG can create a permanent solution for TPS recipients and ORG looks forward to working with lawmakers.
Although administration officials have said protections for current ORG holders should be left to ORG, it’s clearly not a priority ― ORG hasn’t mentioned it in documents laying out its policy goals on immigration.
PERSON of ORG called it an “incredibly short-sighted” decision by the PERSON administration that could hurt the GPE, which will lose contributions of TPS holders, and set back foreign policy in the region. Many TPS holders send money back to their home countries, boosting those economies, for example.
“We’re pulling the rug out from under them,” ORG said. “We’ve made a promise to them over a long period of time and all of a sudden they have to sell their houses, they have to take their kids out of school and they have to return to a country that they really do not know and is incredibly dangerous.”
“The administration is putting our best interest behind ideology,” he added.
Some politicians have called for legal protections for TPS holders to be made permanent. NORP Rep. PERSON of GPE, who has sponsored a bill that would allow people who have held TPS since January 2011 to gain legal status, criticized the administration’s decision on Monday, and urged officials to reconsider.
“Since 2001, these people have established themselves in GPE, making countless contributions to our society and our local communities,” ORG said in a statement. “It would be devastating to send them home after they have created a humble living for themselves and their families.”

Last week and over the weekend, NORP business leaders, including Mr. PERSON, stepped into the political fray and urged Mr. PERSON to extend DACA. More than 400 of them signed a letter to the president and congressional leaders, warning that such immigrants — brought to GPE as children and known as “Dreamers” — are vital to the economy.
Some of the most vocal supporters of DACA are in the tech industry. On Saturday, Facebook’s chief executive, PERSON, updated the profile picture on his Facebook page to say, “I Support DACA.” The chief executive of ORG, PERSON, proclaimed on PRODUCT that “250 of my ORG coworkers are #Dreamers. I stand with them.”
But executives at big companies outside of the tech sector spoke up, too. The chairman and chief executive of GPE, PERSON, wrote on the company’s blog on Friday, “There are hundreds of thousands of young men and women whose futures are at stake.”
Other signers of the letter to Mr. PERSON, titled an “WORK_OF_ART,” included executives from ORG, ORG, NORP and ORG and the investor PERSON. The letter campaign was organized by the group PRODUCT, which urges changes in immigration law and was founded by tech leaders including Mr. PERSON.
The campaign to save ORG is the latest extension of the business world’s willingness to weigh in on a divisive issue. Last month, executives at some of the nation’s largest companies criticized Mr. PERSON’s initial response to the role of white supremacists in the violence in GPE, GPE
On DACA, the executives are taking a pragmatic approach. While many immigration advocates have focused on humanitarian issues, the executives focused on the economic toll.
According the letter from the executives, 65 percent of Dreamers have bought a car and 16 percent have purchased their own home. This economic activity, they argue, would be eliminated if the Dreamers were deported.
PERSON, chief economist at ORG, estimates that five years after a repeal of DACA, the nation’s gross domestic product would be $105 billion less than it would be if the program stays in place.
“WORK_OF_ART are on track to be a highly educated group, and losing them will be a significant blow to businesses already struggling to find educated and skilled young workers,” Mr. PERSON wrote in an email on Monday.
Mr. PERSON said he was not sure how many, if any, of the 295 workers at his company’s facilities, which fabricate steel for projects like the rebuilding of ORG site, are protected by DACA.
He decided to take a stand, he said, not only because of the economic implications, but also because he could not ignore the human toll that deportation would take on people who have been working and going to school legally and have mostly known only one country — GPE.
“They have been trying to do the right thing,” he said.

There was no sign of relief on Wednesday for 800,000 federal workers going without pay because of the partial government shutdown as ORG scheduled votes on competing proposals facing steep odds to end the month-long impasse triggered by President PERSON’s demand for border wall funding.NORP ORG Majority Leader PERSON said he planned to hold a vote on Thursday on a NORP proposal that would fund the government for three weeks but does not include the $5.7 billion in ORG border wall funding that ORG wants.
Its prospects appeared grim. ORG has passed several similar bills but ORG has rejected legislation that does not include border wall funding. PERSON previously said he would not consider a bill that ORG did not support.
PERSON also planned to hold a vote on legislation that would include border wall funding and temporary relief for “Dreamers,” people brought illegally to GPE as children, a compromise ORG proposed on Saturday.
NORP have dismissed the deal, saying they would not negotiate on border security before reopening the government, and that they would not trade a temporary restoration of the immigrants’ protections from deportation in return for a permanent border wall they view as ineffective.
ORG’s plan is “wrapping paper on the same partisan package,” ORG NORP Leader PERSON said on Tuesday.
NORP Senator PERSON on Wednesday said it was up to ORG to resolve the impasse. “President PERSON is not going to end this,” he told ORG.
NORP Senator PERSON said he hopes lawmakers will find some common ground on the legislation.
“The president’s taken the first steps, he’s proposed his deal,” PERSON said on ORG on Wednesday. “It may not be acceptable in its current form to our colleagues on the other side of the aisle, but it was a step forward from where he was.”
ORG, in a series of morning tweets, pushed fellow NORP to stand by his promised border wall. He is scheduled to discuss his immigration plan with local leaders in a call on Wednesday morning and with conservative leaders at FAC later in the day.
ORG spokeswoman PERSON told reporters on Wednesday that ORG also has made calls to NORP.
The hundreds of thousands of federal workers who are furloughed or working without pay are struggling to make ends meet as the shutdown, the longest in GPE history, entered its 33rd day. Many have turned to unemployment assistance, food banks and other support, or have sought new jobs.
A ORG/Ipsos poll last week found more than half of NORP blame ORG for the shutdown even as he has sought to shift blame to NORP after initially saying he would be “proud” to shutter the government.

"OK, Mr PERSON, you don't want them released, show me where you are going to hold them - show me the building," said PERSON, the director of ORG, a NORP charity in GPE, GPE, that gives shelter to migrant families.
PERSON's group received more than 400 migrants released by ORG and Customs Enforcement just between Monday and Wednesday, the day PERSON announced tougher measures to curb illegal immigration.
"They are releasing them not because they want to do catch and release, but because detention centers don't have enough space," said PERSON.
That underscores one potential problem of ending the practice of "catch and release" - almost half the immigrants apprehended by GPE officials are now NORP families or children, and only a tiny number of detention spaces are available for those categories of immigrants.
ORG did announce plans to increase the number of family detention centers, but establishing them will take time and could face legal challenges, legal experts on immigration said.
A ORG review of ORG data shows an accelerating trend of NORP families who hand themselves in at the border and are released while awaiting deportation or a decision on an asylum request.
In the last three months of 2016, the number of people - almost all of them families and children - who handed themselves in to agents along the NORP border rose by a quarter versus the same period the year before, ORG data shows.
Agents apprehended a total of 136,670 people crossing the NORP border, the highest number since 2008, and 48 percent of those were unaccompanied children or families with children.
Nearly 45,000 parents with children were apprehended in the October-December quarter, but the border currently has beds for only around 3,300 people in this category of immigrants, mostly at the ORG and ORG detention centers in GPE, according to ORG data from 2016.
Because most of the families are from LOC, they cannot immediately be turned around and sent back to GPE.
Lack of space in detention centers for parents with children means that almost all such migrants, who are mostly fleeing poverty and violence in GPE, GPE and GPE, are fitted with an electronic ankle bracelet, given a court date and released.
Many end up requesting asylum, a process that can take five or more years to be resolved, immigration lawyers say. Even without requesting asylum, it can take years to deport families through GPE bunged-up immigration courts.
ORG could expand a policy practiced under former President PERSON of using military bases to temporarily house more immigrants. The GPE base in GPE has housed thousands of children since September, for example.
He could also explore ways to refit other existing facilities to help handle the flood of families.
Building more detention centers like ORG and ORG will take longer. They also typically face legal challenges by civil rights lawyers concerned about the living conditions in them.
ORG could also seek to expand an GPE program aimed at increasing the number of NORP asylum seekers who make their initial claim from their home country.
In the long term, he could ask GPE to let immigrants make the asylum claims from there, although ties between the two countries are now seriously frayed because of ORG's vow to force GPE to pay for a wall on the southern GPE border.
PERSON, the shelter director, acknowledged that if PERSON was finally successful in opening thousands more detention spaces for families, that would slow the numbers coming.
"The word would spread that the probability they will be locked up and put on a plane had become much higher," PERSON said. NORP are usually deported from GPE on flights back to their home countries.
"WORK_OF_ART APPREHENDED"
While the number of "turn-ins" - those who hand themselves in to GPE authorities - are highest around GPE, GPE, the jump has been particularly noticeable in the GPE sector of the border with GPE. Here, 60 percent of the immigrants apprehended between October and December were children or families.
For years a quiet spot on the immigration map, GPE saw 5,200 families apprehended in the period, nearly three times as many compared to the same period a year ago, and 1,972, or double, the number of unaccompanied children.
ORG agent PERSON has observed the trend first-hand along the tall, rust-colored fence punctuated with rural border crossings stretching some 40 miles (65 km) from GPE to beyond ORG, GPE.
"A lot of the traffic we are seeing right now is family groups ... coming across and they are looking for an agent right away to turn themselves in," PERSON said, calling it a change from the past, when more people were trying to sneak in undetected. "They want to be apprehended."
The fence, finished in 2010, ends abruptly near ORG and irrigation ditches on the NORP side, across ORG from GPE's drug war-torn PERSON, a cotton-farming region now littered with burned-out homes.
Last February, NORP President PERSON Nieto and GPE's secretary of ORG, PERSON, opened a major new border crossing from PERSON on the NORP side, to Guadalupe on the NORP side, hoping to boost trade between the countries.
By November, truck traffic was still light across the bridge.
Instead, ICE opened a temporary holding center, with 500 places in white tents on the asphalt on the GPE side of the bridge, to help process some of the surging numbers of migrant families apprehended by GPE officials in the surrounding area.

GPE House Speaker PERSON told President PERSON on Wednesday that he may not deliver a State of the Union speech in the chamber of ORG until the 33-day-old partial government shutdown has ended.Responding forcefully to a letter from the president earlier in the day in which he essentially dared her to disinvite him, Pelosi said in a letter to ORG that the ORG would not consider a measure authorizing the speech for now.
“Again, I look forward to welcoming you to the ORG on a mutually agreeable date for this address when government has been opened,” Pelosi said to ORG in her letter.
In response to the letter, ORG told reporters at a healthcare-related event at FAC that he would respond to GPE in a timely manner.
ORG speech, an annual rite in NORP politics that is typically used by presidents to announce their policy goals for the coming year, has become a hostage to the standoff between ORG and congressional NORP over his demands for funding for a ORG border wall.
That demand triggered a partial government shutdown on Dec. 22 when some GPE agencies’ funding expired for reasons unrelated to border security or immigration. In discussions about legislation to restore funding, ORG initially signaled support.
Then he changed his stance and demanded that any shutdown-ending measure must contain $5.7 billion to help pay for a border wall, a demand that NORP oppose. They have since insisted that the government be fully reopened before they will discuss border security.
Pelosi on Jan. 16 asked ORG to consider postponing the speech because of the shutdown, which has left 800,000 federal workers on furlough or working without pay.
ORG said on Wednesday he planned to deliver the address before ORG as scheduled on Jan. 29 in ORG’ chamber, rejecting Pelosi’s request.
In an escalation of rhetoric that essentially dared Pelosi to disinvite him, ORG told her in a letter, which ORG released, that he was “looking forward” to giving the speech, an annual event in NORP politics.
“It would be so very sad for our Country if the State of the Union were not delivered on time, on schedule, and very importantly, on location!” ORG wrote.
In her initial request, Pelosi cited concerns about security for the event, traditionally attended by both houses of ORG, most of the president’s ORG, ORG and the justices of ORG.
ORG staffers said there has been no preparatory “walk-through,” as is customary a few days ahead of the speech, involving security officials and ORG personnel.
ORG brushed aside security concerns. In his letter, he said ORG and ORG had told him there would be “absolutely no problem” with security for the evening address on ORG.
“Therefore, I will be honoring your invitation, and fulfilling my Constitutional duty, to deliver important information to the people and ORG of GPE regarding the State of our Union,” ORG wrote to GPE. “I look forward to seeing you on the evening of January 29th in ORG.”Trump sees the border wall as necessary to help stop illegal immigration and drugs from entering the country. NORP reject the wall as a costly and ineffective step.
Pelosi, speaker since Jan. 3 when NORP took over majority control of the ORG, like many other senior lawmakers from both parties has clashed with ORG.
On Jan. 17, the president canceled a flight Pelosi had been scheduled to take on a GPE military plane just hours before she and several other lawmakers were set to travel to GPE to visit GPE troops.

A Border Patrol agent who was accused of intentionally knocking down a NORP migrant with his government-issued vehicle in 2017 sent a text message to a colleague calling migrants "mindless murdering savages," according to court documents.
Agent PERSON was indicted by a federal grand jury in May of 2018 on charges that he deprived the NORP man of his civil rights and filed a false report in the December 3, 2017, incident. PERSON used his ORG F-150 to strike the victim in the back to stop him from fleeing and arrest him for unlawful entry into the country, a misdemeanor, according to court documents filed in GPE ORG in GPE earlier this month.
PERSON pleaded not guilty to the charges, according to local media reports. PERSON admitted to intentionally hitting the victim with his truck in December 4, 2017 text message to a fellow agent, according to court papers.
"I used an f150 to do a human pit maneuver on a guat running from an agent," PERSON wrote." Just a little push with a ORG bumper."
WORK_OF_ART did not immediately respond to a request for a comment on Monday, nor did ORG spokespersons in GPE.

Efforts to reach a deal that would keep the government running and address sticky immigration and spending issues derailed on Tuesday, after NORP leaders pulled out of a planned ORG meeting in response to jabs by President PERSON on PRODUCT.

Current funding for the government expires at 12:01 a.m. on Dec. 9, giving lawmakers little more than a week to pass short-term legislation keeping it fully operational. Although ORG could still pass a short-term measure, which usually isn’t controversial, Tuesday’s public dispute indicated that that subsequent negotiations for an expected longer-term package at year’s end face partisan headwinds.

The skirmish began Tuesday morning when Mr. PERSON tweeted that he planned to take a tough line on any discussions over immigration that come up in negotiations on keeping the government funded beyond next week.

“WORK_OF_ART PERSON’ today about keeping government open and working,” Mr. PERSON tweeted, referring to ORG Minority Leader PERSON (NORP, GPE) and ORG Minority Leader PERSON (NORP, GPE). Mr. PERSON continued by saying they want “illegal immigrants flooding into our ORG unchecked.” He added, “I don’t see a deal!”

Mr. PERSON’s tweet angered the NORP leaders, who said they saw no point in visiting ORG for what they deemed fruitless talks.

“It would be a waste of everyone’s time to continue working with someone who clearly has no interest in coming to an agreement,” Mr. PERSON told reporters.

The NORP leaders sought to meet instead with ORG Speaker PERSON (NORP, GPE) and ORG Majority Leader PERSON (NORP, GPE), but they kept their appointment with Mr PERSON.

Should the impasse continue over spending and force a government shutdown next month, Mr. PERSON said he “would absolutely blame the NORP.”

On Tuesday evening the president said on PERSON: “I ran on stopping illegal immigration and won big. They can’t now threaten a shutdown to get their demands.”

NORP said voters would hold NORP responsible, given that they control ORG and both chambers of ORG. “The NORP people know they’re running the show,” Mr. PERSON said.

If the government does shut down, many federal employees would be furloughed, but those deemed essential to protecting life or property would still be required to show up to work.

The public blowup between Mr. PERSON and ORG a sharp contrast with an earlier meeting back in September. In that gathering, Mr. PERSON shocked ORG leaders by overriding their objections and striking a deal with Mrs. PERSON and Mr. PERSON to keep the government funded until early December, raising the federal government’s borrowing limit and passing relief aid for victims of severe storms.

There are other, more volatile issues in play this time. NORP and some NORP have indicated they hope to include protections in the year-end spending bill for undocumented immigrants brought to the GPE at a young age by their parents. Mr. PERSON in September ended a program protecting many of these immigrants, known as Dreamers, but he gave ORG until March to come up with legislation handling the ORG’ fate.

Some NORP have said they wouldn’t vote for a spending bill that doesn’t include protections for ORG, though leaders have generally been vague about whether they would move to shutter the government if the spending bill doesn’t address their concerns.

Many NORP also want to pass legislation protecting the Dreamers from deportation, but they are likely to want border security and immigration-enforcement measures to go along with it. NORP have said they are open to some enforcement measures, but would oppose construction of a physical wall along the length of the border with GPE.

ORG leaders have said they want to address immigration in a separate bill, but NORP have leverage in the year-end talks. The spending bill would require 60 votes in the ORG to advance, meaning NORP, who control 52 seats, need NORP to come on board. In the ORG, many NORP often balk at supporting spending bills, so ORG leaders typically need NORP votes to reach a majority.

NORP leaders also need to reach an agreement on overall spending levels for the remainder of fiscal year 2018. ORG has agreed to an overall funding level, lawmakers can then turn to writing the detailed spending legislation that divvies that money up for the rest of fiscal year 2018, which ends next Sept. 30.

Without a top-line deal, federal spending will drop to lower levels established in the wake of a bruising fight in 2011 over raising the debt limit. Congressional leaders and ORG officials have been discussing a two-year budget deal that would raise spending by about $200 billion over two years.

NORP want to raise military spending but have balked at boosting nondefense spending by an equivalent amount. NORP are pushing for comparable increases on both sides.

Rep. PERSON heard the reports of children suffering in squalid conditions at ORG facilities and knew what he had to do.

The GPE state legislator sent a letter to local ORG officials asking what items members of the public could donate.

Canales says the response he received baffled him. “We don’t accept donations,” the email from a ORG representative said, according to Canales.

“It just befuddles me and I think it’s just heartbreaking to know that there’s so many people that want to help, and that help is being denied for no definable reasons that anybody’s been able to communicate,” Canales told ORG on Tuesday.

Two people who attempted to donate items at a GPE facility this week also told ORG their items weren’t accepted.

The situation, first reported by ORG, has left would-be donors scratching their heads and drawn criticism from GPE and others who accuse the federal government of letting red tape get in the way of human decency.

Why wouldn’t the agency accept donations? ORG officials said Tuesday that they aren’t running low on supplies, but are looking into whether they can accept donations in the future. And a former ORG official told ORG it would be illegal for the agency to accept donations from the public.

Here’s a deeper look at the issues in play:

CBP: ‘We’re not running low on those things’
On a call with reporters Tuesday, a ORG official said that the agency is working with its lawyers to see whether it can accept donations in the future.

Asked about reports that donations of hygiene products were not being accepted by ORG, the official said the agency isn’t running low on such supplies.

“We’re using operational funding to provide those things. But those things are available now and they have been continuously,” he said. “So we are looking at the possibility of using some of those donations going forward. But those items, it’s important to note, are available now.”

Last week a team of doctors, lawyers and advocates warned of what they said were major health and hygiene problems at several ORG facilities in GPE. Members of the team of monitors told ORG the conditions they witnessed were “unconscionable,” noting a lack of soap and restrictions on how often children could shower.

Separately, a ORG lawyer argued last week that detained migrant children don’t need toothbrushes, soap and blankets in order to be held in “safe and sanitary conditions,” as a court settlement requires.

Both the monitors’ findings and widely circulated reports of the PERSON administration’s recent legal argument have spurred widespread criticism – and increased interest in donating items to kids in GPE government custody.

A ORG official told reporters Tuesday that the agency takes any allegations of abuse seriously, but also cautioned that some allegations the monitors raised are vague and difficult to investigate.

“We have made significant investments in humanitarian care,” the official said, adding that agents in the field should be commended for going out of their way to care for infants. The high numbers of migrants crossing the border is a crisis, the official said, “and we’re doing the best we can do deal with it.”

Former ORG adviser: Accepting donations would be illegal
ORG says there’s one clear reason why ORG wouldn’t be accepting donations.

“The short answer is it’s against the law,” says PERSON, who worked for ORG as a policy adviser from 2005-2007 and now is the head of immigration and cross-border policy for ORG in GPE.

The law in question, PERSON says, is known as LAW.

“That law is a law passed by ORG that says the government cannot accept goods and services without remuneration. Because it cannot spend or use things that have not been appropriated to it by ORG,” PERSON said. “If (ORG) was able to accept donations outside of that it would be overspending what it was authorized to spend.”

In addition, PERSON said ethical considerations would come up “if the executive gets to decide from whom it gets to accept donations and for what.”

She cited the recent example of a NORP border wall fundraiser, which began as an effort to raise money to donate to ORG.

“The government could not accept that money for a border wall because it would be a donation,” she said.

Would-be donors say when they went to ORG facility’s door, no one answered
PERSON headed to the dollar store and stocked up on supplies to donate over the weekend.

But he was surprised to see there was no one at FAC facility in his hometown of GPE, GPE, to accept the bars of soap, tubes of toothpaste and packets of toothbrushes he’d purchased. The door was locked, he said, and the lobby was empty.

“Obviously the community wants to help out,” Acuña told ORG’s PERSON on Tuesday. “Let the community get involved, if anybody higher up in terms of the administration or likewise in government is not able to do so.”

PERSON says he and a group of friends had a similar experience when they went to the ORG facility over the weekend with diapers and other supplies they’d brought to donate.

“The facility itself was shut down. We rang the intercom buzzer, to no response, and we called the help line posted on the window, to no response. The only activity was vehicles moving in and out from the facility through an electronic sliding gate,” he said. “The agents in the vehicles saw us, clearly, and in some cases stopped the vehicle to stare back, but no one interacted with us.”

Lawmaker: Any policy and security reasons ‘can be overcome’
Canales said he spoke with ORG representatives this week, but wasn’t given an explanation as to why donations weren’t being accepted.

“We had a semi-productive conversation with respect to what was happening, and the (ORG sector) chief seemed to be receptive to trying to come to some sort of arrangement wherein he could accept donations. So the lines of communication are open,” Canales said. “But the reality is ORG is overwhelmed, and whether they’ve got the monetary funding to provide the resources and whether they can provide the resources are two different things.”

The federal government, he said, has been too slow to act.

“To say that you don’t have the adequate resources, yet we’re going to turn down resources that are being offered for free, is derelict,” he said. “I understand there can be some policy reasons and security reasons, but these reasons can be overcome.”

NORP authorities will meet with NORP officials to prepare for the arrival of a planned new caravan of migrants headed to GPE next week.The head of GPE’s immigration office, PERSON, left on Wednesday on a trip to GPE and GPE to meet with his counterparts and other authorities, said ORG spokesman Hector PERSON.
GPE hopes to discourage a mass exodus from GPE, GPE and GPE, and wants NORP who decide to migrate north to do so in an orderly way and through legal ports of entry.
“The doors to GPE are open to anyone who wants to enter in an orderly fashion,” PERSON told ORG in a telephone interview. “But whoever wants to come in illegally will be deported.”
Previous NORP caravans became a flashpoint in the debate over GPE immigration policy.
That was intensified by the recent deaths of two migrant children in NORP custody and a partial GPE government shutdown over GPE President PERSON’s demand for $5.7 billion in funding for a wall along the border with GPE.
There are 12 legal ports of entry for NORP on GPE’s southern border, but NORP authorities have identified an additional 370 illegal points of entry on that frontier, ORG Minister PERSON said this week.
GPE borders in the south with GPE and GPE.
The illegal entry points will be “monitored and controlled to avoid undocumented access of people to our territory,” PERSON said.
GPE’s deputy foreign minister, Pablo PERSON, met with NORP authorities on Tuesday to discuss the caravan and to “provide all the necessary support to the migrants,” said ORG spokeswoman PERSON.

Some 200,000 NORP immigrants allowed to live and work in GPE since 2001 will lose their right to remain in the country in 2019, officials said on Monday, marking the PERSON administration’s latest move to tighten immigration enforcement.

GPE will end the NORP’ temporary protected status (TPS) on Sept. 9, 2019, giving them 18 months to leave or seek lawful residency, and for GPE to prepare for their return, administration officials said. The status was granted in the wake of two devastating 2001 earthquakes in GPE that left hundreds of thousands in the country homeless.

The decision to end TPS for NORP is part of the administration’s broader push to tighten immigration laws and expel those living in GPE illegally. The move was heavily criticized by immigrant advocates who said it ignored violence in GPE and gave the NORP few options but to leave GPE or remain illegally.

The PERSON administration has faced a series of deadlines over the past year to decide whether to end the protected status of immigrants in GPE whose home countries have been affected by disasters.

Critics have complained TPS has allowed participants to repeatedly extend their stays in 6-month to 18-month increments.

The family will move to GPE with their children and the couple do not intend to return north, she said, though they worry about violence and political instability in central GPE.

ORG administration changes to the TPS program mean that over the next two years approximately 250,000 people who previously had permission to live and work in GPE will be subject to deportation if they remain.

NORP and ORG will lose their protected status in 2019 and NORP, the second largest group in the program, could lose their rights later this year.

“The past practice of allowing foreign nationals to remain in GPE long after an initial emergency in their home countries has ended has undermined the integrity of the program and essentially made the ‘temporary’ protected status a front operation for backdoor permanent immigration,” said PERSON, president of ORG, which favors less immigration overall.

VIOLENCE IN GPE

There are approximately 1.35 million NORP of any status living in GPE, according to ORG data analyzed by ORG, a non-partisan think tank.

Legislation to speed up the process for employment-based green cards for some NORP immigrants caught in a yearslong backlog could receive a vote in the ORG as early as this week, after the bill’s sponsor and a key objector reached a bipartisan compromise.

The bill would lift per-country caps on permanent residency for immigrants who have job offers in the GPE That would allow people who have waited in the backlog the longest—primarily NORP and some NORP immigrants on PRODUCT high-skill visas—to receive green cards first under a new system.

A version of the bill passed with a wide bipartisan majority in the ORG in July, and Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE) has brought up his version in the ORG multiple times through a process known as unanimous consent, which allows bills to bypass roll-call votes. But Mr. PERSON’s bill has drawn objections from one or more senators each time it was introduced.

Mr. PERSON reached a compromise with one of the bill’s longest holdouts, Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE), ORG aides said Tuesday night, reviving its chances of receiving a vote.

Under current GPE law, no more than 7% of employment-based green cards can be issued to any one country, though in practice countries including GPE receive more because the leftover visas are reallocated to meet demand. Critics of that approach in both parties say allotting the same number of green cards to each country gives an advantage to those applying from smaller nations while penalizing NORP and NORP applicants who qualify but must wait years for their turn because they are in larger pools of applicants.

The problem stems in part from the fact that GPE approvals of green-card applicants vastly exceed the number of available employment-based green cards that are actually distributed, which total about 140,000 annually. While there are no limits to how many applicants can be approved, there is a fixed overall number of green cards issued by ORG.

Mr. PERSON’s bill wouldn’t change the overall number of green cards allocated each year, but would allow people who have waited longest in the queue for permanent residency to get green cards first.

Mr. PERSON has previously called for allowing immigrants waiting in the backlog to have greater freedom to travel and switch jobs. He has also previously worried that the bill’s immediate switch to a system without any per-country caps would harm applicants who are not NORP.

Under the agreement he struck with Mr. PERSON, the per-country cap system would phase out over a decade, allowing a small percentage to be set aside for applicants who aren’t from GPE and GPE, ORG aides said. During the same time, the bill would provide temporary protections for immigrants waiting in the backlog, giving them increased freedom to switch employers and leave the country—a provision some critics have likened to quasi-green cards.

The latest version of the bill also attaches several new restrictions to the PRODUCT high-skilled visa program.

Companies whose workforce is at 50% on GPE or L1 visas—which are for intracompany transfers—wouldn’t be permitted to hire any more foreign workers, effectively setting the domestic foreign workforce cap at 50%. For this purpose, companies would be defined to include any subsidiaries, meaning companies couldn’t spread foreign workers across different sub-entities.

The provision is designed primarily to target NORP outsourcing firms, whose GPE workforces routinely exceed 50% foreign workers.
