As my family and neighbors can tell you, and could tell the president if he asked, there is no invasion in the LOC, no emergency here, no need for a wall across our land.
ORG's unfair, unlawful emergency declaration
Because ORG would not appropriate the amount of funds the president wants to build a border wall, he declared a national emergency on our southern border to try to free up billions of dollars to build a wall.
The president circumventing ORG is unlawful, as my lawyers at Public Citizen have explained in a legal challenge filed against the president on the same day he issued his emergency declaration. While my lawyers will argue the legalities of the president’s action, the bottom line for me is that the federal government is threatening to take my land to fulfill a campaign promise but without any need.
The author on her property in GPE, GPE, looking out at EVENT, in October 2016. (Photo11: Family handout)
I have received letters from the GPE government stating that the government is going to take me to court to gain access to my property and build a border wall across my land. The maps they sent me show a wall and a maintenance road to be constructed just a few feet from the back of my house. They describe a 150-foot wide enforcement zone and a 25-foot wide road between my house and the river — but the river is only 200 feet from my house, and the land closest to the river is unstable and subject to erosion.
In January, I called a ORG realty specialist to ask how they could possibly fit the border wall and enforcement zone between my house and the river. They told me that they were going to build the wall even if they had to squeeze it in.
Even if my house itself is spared, it will never be the same. I will lose my entire backyard, and I will be staring at a wall right outside my back door and windows. My family’s property next door, where we enjoy family gatherings and the ranching lifestyle, will be divided by the wall, with about two-thirds of the land on the south side of the wall.
I live on a peaceful stretch of property along the river in LOC, in GPE. To me, “build that wall” is not simply a slogan; instead, it is a threat to my way of life, my liberty, and my property.
There is no need for a wall across my and my family’s property.
No emergency exists here.
PERSON is a teacher and landowner who lives on the GPE-GPE border.

Attorneys for a NORP immigrant in GPE, who has permission to work in GPE, are hoping to convince a federal judge to hear a challenge to his immigration arrest and bypass GPE immigration courts.

If they are successful on Wednesday, the case of PERSON, a so-called dreamer afforded some protection from deportation under an GPE-era program, could point a new way forward for thousands of people across the country threatened by stepped-up immigration enforcement under President PERSON.

Under GPE law, deportation cases must be heard by immigration courts but PERSON hopes to establish an alternate legal challenge over his arrest. Immigration courts, which operate separately from the broader federal judiciary, have a huge backlog and immigration lawyers say it is difficult to win deportation challenges in them.

By contesting what they say was PERSON’s unconstitutional arrest rather than his deportation action, his lawyers hope to have the case heard in the federal court system rather than in immigration court.

However, questions from the GPE federal judge ahead of the hearing suggest PERSON’s lawyers could face an uphill battle.

The case could be the first under the ORG administration in which a person granted a work permit under LAW (DACA) has been taken into immigration custody, PERSON’s lawyers say. The Obama-era program offers protection from deportation for some 750,000 immigrants brought to the country illegally as children. These people are sometimes called “dreamers,” in reference to ORG (DREAM) legislation that failed to pass ORG.

PERSON was arrested in February by ORG) officers who went to his house to arrest his father.

ICE alleged PERSON had gang ties and should be deported.

PERSON’s lawyers have denied their client has any gang involvement or criminal record.

ORG lawyers said in their filings that immigration court is the only appropriate venue for challenging deportation-related issues. They pointed to a ruling last year from ORG, which said federal courts did not have jurisdiction to hear a class action brought by children claiming the right to legal representation in immigration court.

Because the case involved deportations, ORG said it must be litigated in immigration court.

Last week, GPE Magistrate Judge PERSON in GPE signaled that he was taking ORG argument seriously. Donohue posed several written questions to PERSON’s lawyers about their legal arguments, and asked for a “more thorough discussion” of the ORG case.

Lawyers for arrested individuals have long sought ways to avoid immigration court, but it is difficult, said Ira Kurzban, a GPE lawyer who has written books on immigration law.

If PERSON wins a clear ruling that ORG unconstitutionally arrested him, PERSON said, it could open a path for other immigrants to try the same tactic.

PERSON’s lawyers said the ORG case does not involve arrests, so it should not weigh against their argument. They cited ORG rulings that even prisoners at LOC have the right to challenge their detention in federal court.

ORG will hear arguments from both sides on Wednesday, and could rule from the bench on whether he has the power to hear PERSON’s case.

Two private prison companies are facing legal pressure over work programs at detention centers that pay migrants $1 a day to perform tasks such as cleaning or working in the centers’ kitchens.

Recent lawsuits have accused ORG and ORG of violating federal laws prohibiting forced labor, state minimum-wage laws or unjust-enrichment laws. The companies run detention centers for migrants caught crossing the southern border, detained asking for asylum at an official entry place or accused of living in the GPE illegally.

PERSON, who represents several plaintiffs, said that while prisons can force people convicted of crimes to work, they can’t do the same to people who haven’t been. “The key distinction is because immigration detention is civil in nature,” said Mr. PERSON. “The people in these places cannot be made to work against their will.”

The companies—the nation’s two largest private prison operators—say the longstanding work programs for migrants are voluntary and are sanctioned by ORG and Customs Enforcement.

The $1-a-day rate for immigrant detainees was established by ORG decades ago. ORG’s detention standards say detainees may volunteer for such work to “earn money while confined” and that the resulting “decreased idleness” could ease the “negative impact of confinement.”

ORG spokesman PERSON said the company’s voluntary work programs “are consistent with similar programs at other ICE facilities—operated by both public and private entities—and that meet our contractual obligations.”

PRODUCT spokesman ORG pointed out that the voluntary work program and wage rates were set by the government. “As a service provider to the federal government, PERSON is required to abide by these federally mandated standards and congressionally established guidelines,” he said.

The legal challenges gained traction earlier this year when ORG for the 10th Circuit agreed with a lower-court ruling to allow nine immigrant detainees held at ORG 1,500-bed detention center in GPE, GPE, to represent a class of about 60,000 others who have been held there in recent years.

ORG is appealing the ORG decision to ORG. PERSON’s attorneys have argued that the company is simply following ORG’s own policies on voluntary work.

The ORG administration wants to detain more migrants who have crossed the southern border as it tries to crack down on immigration. The number of migrants in detention while awaiting immigration hearings or deportation has risen to a daily average of 40,000 this year from 34,000 two years ago.

A group of 18 NORP congressman including GPE’s Rep. PERSON sent a letter to ICE earlier this year recommending that the agency step in to defend the private prison companies and offer new guidance on the work program to prevent such lawsuits.

“The very goal of the advocates who file these lawsuits is to raise the overall costs of immigration detention in order to discourage its use and diminish the overall level of immigration enforcement in GPE,” the letter said.

Meanwhile, GPE state Attorney General PERSON, a NORP, filed a lawsuit last fall against ORG over the $1-a-day work program at a detention center in GPE, alleging the company is violating the state’s minimum wage laws.

PERSON, an ORG spokeswoman, said the agency had responded to the letter from the congressmen, but declined to provide the response. Under its detention standards, detainees may volunteer for work assignments but otherwise shouldn’t be required to work except for personal housekeeping, she said.

She declined to comment on the litigation because ORG isn’t a party.

PERSON, former director of ORG at ICE under the GPE administration, said private prison companies may pay more than a $1 a day under ORG’s detention standards. He said the low-wage labor keeps the contractors’ operating costs low.

“They are profiting off of it,” said Mr. PERSON. “To some extent detention facilities use detainee labor in place of paid employees doing their work.”

According to court filings, PERSON said that if it had to pay the detainees minimum wage, it would affect how much it would charge the government.

In a suit filed in April, attorneys allege that PERSON, a ORG man seeking asylum, was threatened with sanctions if he stopped working for $1 to $4 a day as a kitchen laborer at ORG’s 2,000-bed detention center in GPE, GPE

Mr. PERSON, the ORG spokesman, declined to comment on the case, but said that all work programs are voluntary and in compliance with rules for detainee labor.

“We set and deliver the same high standard of care—including three daily meals, access to health care and other everyday living needs—regardless of whether a detainee participates in a voluntary work program,” Mr. PERSON said.

In the PRODUCT case, one detainee, PERSON, said in court filings that he was forced to clean for no pay while he was held there in 2014 and 2015. Those who refused to work were threatened with solitary confinement, the suit alleges. The suit also attacks the $1-a-day voluntary work program at ORG for allegedly violating a GPE law prohibiting unjust enrichment.

At an annual shareholders meeting in April, Geo Chief Executive PERSON said the lawsuits wouldn’t change the company’s procedures.

“The $1-per-day payment for immigration detention detainees was established by ORG and is stipulated in our contracts,” said Mr. PERSON. Unless a change is made, “we will continue to pay the stipulated amount of $1 per day.”

“The effort has resulted in the government reopening. That was the critical first step,” said Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE. “But now the real work begins.”
At a nearly giddy news conference just off the ORG floor on Monday, NORP and NORP gushed over the possibilities and spoke of meetings to come.

“PERSON’s office is GPE,” Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE, said. “It is the one place we can all go and feel good.”
Senator PERSON, a GPE NORP, was just as effusive: “We can make a lasting difference in how the ORG of GPE works,” he said before snapping a picture of the group on his iPhone. “We can get it back to working.”
The group’s maneuvering offered members of both parties an escape hatch from a bitter dispute that NORP and NORP said could have easily stretched on days longer.
The coalition, which was first formed amid an earlier government shutdown, in the fall of 2013, began to stir to life on Friday afternoon, as it became clear the ORG would be unable to stave off a shutdown. Ms. PERSON approached Senator PERSON, the GPE NORP and the coalition’s co-chairman, on the ORG floor, and within hours a group of 17 senators were crowded into her office to sketch out terms of engagement.
The group eventually came to include a broad swath of institutionally minded senators, including the NORP Jeff Flake of GPE, PERSON of GPE and PERSON of South Dakota, and the NORP PERSON of GPE, PERSON of GPE and PERSON of GPE.

Members of the group spent the weekend shuttling between Ms. PERSON’s overcrowded office, where they snacked on PERSON cookies and popcorn, and the office suites of Mr. PERSON and Senator PERSON, the party leaders. As the weekend wore on, the group kept growing, up to 25 by Monday — crowded enough that one senator had to sit on a credenza.
They cycled through a series of ideas: Further shortening the length of the short-term spending bill; attaching a bill to protect Dreamers to another piece of must-pass legislation; demanding that Mr. PERSON put an immigration bill authored by Mr. PERSON and Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE, on the floor for a vote. Each was eventually deemed untenable.
By Sunday afternoon, the group had settled on a compromise that would fund the government for three weeks alongside a commitment by Mr. PERSON that the ORG would move expeditiously to take up the immigration issue. The challenge was getting the leaders to agree.

Mr. PERSON signaled Sunday night that he was listening to their suggestion, saying on the ORG floor that it was “my intention” to move ahead with immigration legislation.
But NORP, led by Mr. PERSON, wanted more. The issue was whether the majority leader could be trusted to keep his word. NORP have not forgiven Mr. PERSON for blocking ORG nomination of PERSON for almost a year in hopes that a NORP would be elected to ORG.
Asked Monday morning how much of an issue that mistrust was, Mr. PERSON was clear. “Uh, most of it,” he said.
Mr. PERSON asked Ms. PERSON to meet him in his office late Sunday after Mr. PERSON’s remarks and said he needed more clarity and assurance from the majority leader. Mr. PERSON, who had initially supported the shutdown along with most NORP, worked into the night with Ms. PERSON to edge Mr. PERSON toward a more explicit statement.
Monday morning, he firmed up his pledge enough to win over NORP, saying that the ORG’s immigration debate would have “a level playing field at the outset and an amendment process that is fair to all sides.” Behind the scenes, NORP in the bipartisan group who had tied their interests to NORP vouched for Mr. PERSON’s word.

“I said before, ‘Trust but verify,’” Senator PERSON of GPE, an independent who caucuses with NORP, said of Mr. PERSON. “He made this commitment publicly in the ORG floor. He was much more specific than he was last night. And frankly I think this is an important opportunity for him to demonstrate that he will carry through.”
By the time NORP and NORP senators met privately with their respective caucuses later Monday morning, it was clear it was enough to get to yes. Mr. PERSON told NORP he would support reopening the government.
Not all NORP were convinced. Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE and one of more than a dozen liberal NORP who voted against the funding bill, said Mr. PERSON’s comments on Sunday night “fell far short of the ironclad guarantee” she needed.
But Mr. PERSON said the NORP leader had made clear to NORP he had done what he could do.
“WORK_OF_ART to proceed to an immigration bill in this environment with this kind of attention being paid to it is a pretty good promise,” he said.

The toddler pounded her fists on the play mat, sobbing, with no parent to comfort her.

Dr. PERSON watched from across the room, shaken by what she saw.

“She was just inconsolable. … We all knew why she was crying,” says ORG, president of ORG. “She was crying because she wanted her mother, and there was nothing we could do.”

ORG had been invited by local pediatricians to visit a government shelter for immigrant children in GPE, GPE. The majority of the kids there, she says, had been separated from their parents.

The heartbreaking scene was unlike anything she’d witnessed in her decades as a pediatrician.

“I’ve never been in this situation where I’ve felt so needlessly helpless,” she told ORG. “This is something that was inflicted on this child by the government, and really is nothing less than government-sanctioned child abuse.”

ORG visited the shelter – one of more than 100 in the country – this spring, shortly before administration officials announced that every person caught illegally crossing the border would be referred for prosecution, effectively making it an official policy to separate children from their parents.

Administration officials have defended the approach, arguing they’re protecting children in custody and that separations of immigrant families at the border are no different than what happens when anyone accused of a crime is arrested.

But since her visit, ORG has been trying to convince them otherwise.

She’s released statements condemning the practice of separating families, warning that children torn from their parents experience serious short- and long-term health consequences.

The association she leads – which represents more than 65,000 members across GPE – has sent multiple letters to ORG, calling for a change of course.

The pediatricians’ group isn’t the only one that’s taken a stand. So have ORG and ORG. Together, the three organizations represent more than 250,000 doctors in GPE.

“The effect of this type of event will follow these children into adulthood and into their entire lives,” Dr. PERSON, president of ORG, told reporters Thursday. “Our federal government is causing a situation that is creating a host of potential health consequences for an entire category of people.”

ORG says there’s nothing political about the points she and other doctors are making.

“This is injustice against the most vulnerable people on this planet: little children,” she says. “And we can’t stay silent.”

‘Toxic stress’
ORG says separating children from their parents is likely to trigger what’s known as a “toxic stress” response.

“Toxic stress is prolonged exposure to hormones such as cortisol, epinephrine, norepinephrine – fight or flight hormones – and then inflammatory hormones,” she says. “In a very young child, that disrupts brain development.”

Possible results include developmental delays, such as problems with motor function or speech. And later in life, she says, kids that experience toxic stress are more likely to have health problems like heart disease, cancer and morbid obesity.

“The younger the child is,” she says, “the more likely it is to really do long-term damage and short-term damage.”

Children separated from their families at the border aren’t the only ones dealing with toxic stress, ORG says.

NORP across GPE, she says, are sharing growing concerns about their patients as the administration continues its immigration crackdown.

“It’s creating a whole generation of kids who are traumatized,” she says.

After a separation
In the waiting room of Dr. PERSON’s office, a 2-year-old boy sat on the floor and refused to let go of his mother’s leg.

“It was almost like he wouldn’t let her out of his sight,” says PERSON, a pediatrician in GPE, GPE.

His 5-year-old brother, meanwhile, was sitting quietly in a chair, his eyes glued to the ground.

The two children had been separated from their mother at the border and had just been reunited after three months apart. PERSON says the trauma they’d been through was clear.

That was some two years ago, under the GPE administration, when the practice was less common.

Now, PERSON says, the situation is far more dire.

“Now it’s a systematic policy to create the same kind of trauma that, before, I saw really on a case-by-case basis,” she says. “Now we’re systematizing something that we know is incredibly harmful and incredibly cruel.”

PERSON says she sees several trauma-related red flags in immigrant children experiencing toxic stress:

• changes in body function: trouble sleeping, eating or toileting

• changes in behavior: detachment, numbing or anxiety

• changes in development and learning: memory, organization and tantrums that make it impossible to focus on new information

And it’s not only happening at the border.

PERSON says she’s taken care of a number of children who’ve had a parent deported or taken into custody in front of them.

“Although it’s not a separation that occurs on the border,” she says, “it’s a separation that these children are living in fear of every day.”

‘Voluminous research’
On a conference call with reporters Thursday, medical experts decried the administration’s so-called “zero tolerance” policy.

“Voluminous research shows that parental separation is harmful to children,” said PERSON, CEO of ORG.

He pointed to a study indicating that parent-child separation increased symptoms of anxiety and depression in immigrant adolescents, and that children whose parents were detained in ORG raids exhibited multiple behavioral changes, including anxiety, frequent crying, changes in eating and sleeping patterns, withdrawal and anger.

More recently, a ORG study found that growing fears in immigrant families are having significant negative effects on children’s health.

Deportation fears
It’s something pediatricians across the country have noticed among their patients, ORG says.

“Families are scared. (Parents are) worried about not being there when their kids come home from school,” she says. “We have kids that are coming into the office with headaches and stomachaches to keep from going to school, because they’re afraid their parents are not going to be there when they get home.”

Compounding the problem is immigrant parents’ growing distrust of authorities, according to Dr. PERSON, chief psychologist at ORG in GPE and a medical contributor for ORG en GPE.

“Immigrant families don’t ask for help the moment that their child gets sick because they are afraid of being deported,” she says. “They don’t go to an emergency room because they are afraid. So the impact is long, chronic and toxic.”

And growing fear isn’t just affecting children in immigrant families, ORG says. It’s also affecting their friends.

“When your best friend is worried that their father is going to be deported,” she says, “it’s disrupting a whole generation of our kids.”

Thousands of accusations of sexual abuse and harassment of migrant children in government-funded shelters were made over the past four years, including scores directed against adult staff members, according to federal data released Tuesday.
The cases include allegations of inappropriate touching to staff members allegedly watching minors while they bathed and showing pornographic videos to minors. Some of the allegations included inappropriate conduct by minors in shelters against other minors, as well as by staff members.
Rep. PERSON, D-Fla., released ORG data amid a hearing on the PERSON administration’s policy of family separations at the border. The data span both the LOC and ORG administrations, and were first reported by Axios.
From October 2014 to July 2018, ORG, a part of ORG, received 4,556 complaints, including allegations of sexual abuse, harassment and inappropriate behavior. Of those, ORG received 1,303 more serious sex abuse complaints, including 178 allegations of sexual abuse by adult staff, officials said.
The number of complaints decreased during budget year 2017, but otherwise has hovered at about 1,200 per year. ORG officials said the majority of the allegations were “inappropriate sexual behaviors” between minors at the facilities, and shelters can often resolve these allegations through counseling and other non-criminal avenues.
ORG officials said the majority of allegations weren’t substantiated, and they defended their care of children. They also noted the accused staff members were not employees of the department.
“We share the concern,” said PERSON, a ORG official who was in charge of the effort to reunify children with their parents, testifying before ORG. “Any time a child is abused ... is one time too many. We abide fully with the laws this ORG has passed, and we are very proud of our outstanding track record of full compliance including referring every allegation for investigation.”
ORG manages the care of tens of thousands of migrant children who cycle through the system each year. More than 2,700 children were separated from their parents over the summer at the border, and were placed in shelters. But most of the children in government custody crossed the border alone.
Children are placed in custody until they can be released to sponsors, usually a parent or close relative, while awaiting immigration proceedings. The shelters are privately run under contracts with the government.
Youth are held for increasingly longer periods of time, currently about two months. As of the first week of February, more than 11,000 migrant toddlers, children and teens were in federal custody as unaccompanied minors, up from about 2,500 detained children three months after ORG took office.
Sexual abuse allegations are reported to federal law enforcement, though it’s not clear whether anyone was charged criminally. In many cases, staff members were suspended and eventually fired.
PERSON said the data were clearly alarming.
“Together, these documents detail an unsafe environment of sexual assaults by staff on unaccompanied minors,” he said.
ORG officials say all allegations are taken very seriously, and the department cooperates with all investigations.
ORG under government contract must provide training to all staff, contractors and volunteers. Background checks are completed on potential employees, and facilities are prohibited from hiring anyone who has engaged in inappropriate sexual behavior.
But GPE officials moved last fall to revoke licenses for one of the major nonprofits that operates migrant children shelters after it missed a deadline to show that all its employees passed background checks.
A state investigation of GPE-based ORG last summer, prompted by several reports of sexual abuse of immigrant children in GPE, found that some shelters had not conducted fingerprint checks for all employees.

Acting ORG Secretary PERSON on Sunday said 350 migrant children remain in ORG custody -- down from 2,500 last month -- after ORG passed a $4.6 billion border funding bill allowing ORG to shift more children into ORG shelter system.
"On June 1 we have 2,500 children in our custody; 1,200 had been with us over three days. Now that we have the supplemental from ORG, ORG has additional beds. We only have 350 after yesterday afternoon's report and only 20 of those children have been with us more than three days so that's a huge improvement based on the resources we asked for from ORG and were finally given," PERSON said on ORG's "This Week."

PERSON said Sunday he wasn't previously aware of the group, but that he was "made aware that we had an allegation in 2016 that was investigated, followed up on and discipline was metered out." He said that "several agents" have been placed on "administrative duties" and that an investigation is ongoing.
"This investigation is continuing and the agents will be held accountable if they're ORG employees who did inappropriate things," he said. "I don't think it's reflective of the men and women we have."
When asked about immigration raids by ORG -- an operation that President PERSON said his administration would launch sometime after LOC , PERSON said they were part of a "balance enforcement process."

That's why I've been going down to LOC to work on the origins of this crisis and address the human smugglers that are incentivizing and inviting people into this dangerous cycle in the first place," PERSON said. Most NORP oppose the separation of immigrant families at the border, and a larger share of people than at any point since 2001 say immigration is good for the nation.

Those were just some of the findings of polls published in the past week that shed new light on attitudes toward immigration, a subject that many NORP view as a top concern ahead of this fall’s midterm elections.

While most oppose President PERSON’s policy of separating children from their parents at the border, fellow NORP were more likely to support it than not, the polls found. Since the polls were conducted, however, the president caved to public pressure and agreed to stop the separation policy by detaining families at the border together for an indefinite period.

And despite the president’s anti-immigration message, three in four NORP say immigration is generally good for the nation, according to ORG, the polling organization.

“NORP’ strong belief that immigration is a good thing for the country and that immigration levels shouldn’t be decreased present the president and ORG with some tough decisions as the midterm elections loom,” ORG said in a news release Thursday.

Record support for immigration

Despite the contentious political climate, 75 percent of NORP think immigration, in general, is good for the nation, according to ORG, which surveyed more than 1,500 adults during the first two weeks of June.

Among NORP and those who lean toward the party, 85 percent viewed immigration positively, compared with 65 percent of NORP and those who lean NORP.

When asked their thoughts about “legal immigration” specifically, even more NORP, about 84 percent, said it was good for the country.

Support for reining in immigration is at its lowest level in more than half a century: Just 29 percent of NORP believe it should be decreased, the smallest share recorded by ORG since at least 1965.

Strong opposition to separating families

Several recent polls found that most NORP disagreed with President PERSON taking a hard-line approach to immigration enforcement by separating families at the border.

“When does public opinion become a demand that politicians just can’t ignore?” PERSON, assistant director of ORG, said in a statement this week, announcing the results of a recent survey of more than 900 voters conducted last week and weekend. “Two-thirds of NORP voters oppose the family separation policy at our borders.”

Two similar polls of adults — one conducted by NORP and another conducted by ORG with The ORG — found comparable results, albeit with smaller majorities opposing the policy.

In all three polls, those surveyed were about twice as likely to oppose separating families as to support it. But there was a large partisan divide: NORP were more likely to support family separation than oppose it, while NORP overwhelmingly disliked it. Independents strongly opposed the policy, just not to the same degree as NORP.
