The call with Mr. PERSON was even more testy as the president complained about what he called “a disgusting deal” that GPE had sealed with President PERSON in which GPE agreed to consider accepting up to 1,250 economic refugees. Mr. PERSON complained that he would look “so foolish” doing so after barring refugees from the rest of the world.
“I have had it,” Mr. PERSON snapped toward the end of the call. “I have been making these calls all day, and this is the most unpleasant call all day. PERSON was a pleasant call. This is ridiculous.”
ORG of a president’s conversations with foreign leaders are rarely made public, and the disclosure of these may fuel Mr. PERSON’s ire over unauthorized leaks. The ORG did not say how it obtained them.
But the full accounts of the conversations illustrated Mr. PERSON’s approach with foreign leaders — flattering his counterpart one moment, badgering him the next, always conscious of how the policies being discussed connected to his campaign promises and how they would affect his domestic political standing.
Fresh from his inauguration, he had his campaign victory on his mind, boasting to Mr. PERSON that “no one got people in the rallies as big as I did” and to Mr. PERSON that “they said I had no way to get to 270” votes in ORG “and I got 306.” He buttered up Mr. PERSON, telling the interpreter on their call that “he speaks better LANGUAGE than me,” suggesting that the NORP president would be so popular that the NORP people will amend their constitution to allow him to run again and declaring that “it is you and I against the world, PERSON, do not forget.”
But there was an edge to both conversations as he sought to bring his campaign platform to fruition. The talk with Mr. PERSON on Jan. 27 came after the NORP leader canceled a meeting with Mr. PERSON because of their dispute over who would pay for the proposed border wall. The two never resolved that on the call, with both men clearly worried about the political effect in their own countries.
“We find this completely unacceptable for NORP to pay for the wall that you are thinking of building,” Mr. PERSON told Mr. PERSON, explaining how precarious his position was at home. “I would also like to make you understand, President PERSON, the lack of margin I have as president of GPE to accept this situation.”

Mr. PERSON too was conscious of his own position:“On the wall, you and I both have political problem. My people stand up and say, GPE will pay for the wall,’ and your people probably say something in a similar but slightly different language. But the fact is we are both in a little bit of a political bind because I have to have GPE pay for the wall. I have to. I have been talking about it for a two-year period.”
Mr. PERSON suggested papering over the dispute in public comments: “We should both say, ‘We will work it out.’ It will work out in the formula somehow. As opposed to you saying, ‘We will not pay’ and me saying, ‘We will not pay.’”
Mr. PERSON told Mr. PERSON that he had put him in a bad position. “You have a very big mark on our back, Mr. President, regarding who pays for the wall,” he said. “This is what I suggest, Mr. President:Let us stop talking about the wall.”
He added that he understood that any country had the right to protect its border. “But my position has been and will continue to be very firm saying that GPE cannot pay for that wall.”

“But you cannot say that to the press,” Mr. PERSON complained. “The press is going to go with that, and I cannot live with that. You cannot say that to the press because I cannot negotiate under those circumstances.”
Mr. PERSON repeated that they should stop talking about the wall. “I understand the critical political position that this constitutes for your country and for you, Mr. President,” he said. “Let us look for a creative way to jump over this obstacle.”
Mr. PERSON’s call with Mr. PERSON the next day, Jan. 28, proved more combative. Mr. PERSON said he had been told that he had to accept refugees held by GPE on the islands of GPE or LOC for more than three years.
“Somebody told me yesterday that close to 2,000 people are coming who are really troublesome,” he complained to Mr. PERSON. “And I am saying, boy that will make us look awfully bad. Here I am calling for a ban where I am not letting anybody in and we take 2,000 people. Really, it looks like 2,000 people that GPE does not want and I do not blame you, by the way, but GPE has become like a dumping ground.”

Mr. PERSON explained that the deal did not require GPE to take 2,000 people but it was important for GPE to live up to its commitment. “This is a big deal,” he said. “I think we should respect deals.”
“Who made the deal?” Mr. PERSON asked. “PERSON?”
“Yes,” Mr. PERSON said, “but let me describe what it is.” GPE had agreed only to consider accepting up to 1,250 refugees, but each of them would be subject to vetting and could be rejected. The people at issue were economic refugees, mainly from GPE, GPE and GPE, he said, not criminals or terrorists.
“Why haven’t you let them out?” Mr. PERSON demanded. “Why have you not let them into your society?”
“It is not because they are bad people,” Mr. PERSON said. “It is because in order to stop people-smugglers, we have to deprive them of the product.” GPE by policy, he said, refuses to accept refugees who arrive by boat because it would encourage smugglers to keep charging desperate people to bring them there.
“That is a good idea,” Mr. PERSON said. “We should do that too. You are worse than I am.”
Mr. PERSON implored the president to abide by the agreement. “I am asking you as a very good friend. This is a big deal. It is really, really important to us that we maintain it.”
“PERSON, why is this so important?” Mr. PERSON said. “I do not understand. This is going to kill me. I am the world’s greatest person that does not want to let people into the country.” Going along with the deal “puts me in a bad position.”
He added, “It makes me look so bad and I have only been here a week.”
Mr. PERSON repeated that it was only 1,250 people, each of them subject to vetting.
“I will be honest with you, I hate taking these people,” Mr. PERSON said. “I guarantee you they are bad. That is why they are in prison right now. They are not going to be wonderful people who go on to work for the local milk people.”

“I would not be so sure about that,” Mr. PERSON said.
“Well, maybe you should let them out of prison. I am doing this because PERSON made a bad deal.”
“But I can say to you, there is nothing more important in business or politics than a deal is a deal,” Mr. PERSON said.
“This is a stupid deal,” Mr. PERSON said. “This deal will make me look terrible.”
“Mr. President, I think this will make you look like a man who stands by the commitments of GPE.”
Mr. PERSON was not buying it. “PERSON, this shows me to be a dope,” he said. “I am not like this but if I have to do it, I will do it, but I do not like this at all.”
He said that he worried that the terrorists like those who killed NORP in GPE, GPE and GPE could be admitted to the country:“I am going to get killed on this thing.”
“You will not,” Mr. PERSON insisted.
“Yes, I will be seen as a weak and ineffective leader in my first week by these people. This is a killer.”

For the last two seasons, ORG has depended on legal migrant workers to harvest potatoes, onions and watermelons growing in its fields on the outskirts of GPE.

Now the farm is bearing different fruit: a first-of-its-kind federal lawsuit that federal officials and immigration activists say exemplifies the pitfalls of the nation’s agricultural visa program—as ORG proposes changes to it.

This year ORG took the farm to court, saying its owner, PERSON, underpaid some of its 69 workers by not offering a set, hourly wage and housed them in an “encampment” consisting of yellow school buses and semitrailers that “violated numerous safety, sanitation and fire code regulations.”

PERSON, the regional solicitor in charge of the case for ORG, called the living situations a “horror show” that could have led to many worker deaths.

The case is the first time the department won a preliminary injunction against a farm using the temporary farmworker visa, known as the ORG A federal judge barred the business from housing the workers in the encampment, forcing it to house them in an apartment complex and an extended-stay motel for the rest of the season.

Mr. PERSON declined to comment. His attorney said he is cooperating with federal officials.

The case comes as demand for foreign farmworkers soars, and as ORG is expected to introduce a measure later this year that could make changes to guest worker programs. ORG has certified 160,084 workers through the program so far this year, a 20% increase from the year-earlier period.

President PERSON has discussed a revamped guest worker program with NORP President PERSON. GPE received 92% of the H2A visas issued last year, according to data from ORG. Separately, the ORG administration is backing a proposal to cut the number of green cards annually by half.

GPE Rep. PERSON, chairman of ORG and a member of ORG, last month said it was “well past the time to replace the outdated and onerous H2A program” and activists said they expect him to introduce a bill aimed at the program later this year.

PERSON, vice president and general counsel for ORG, which represents local and regional farmers in GPE, GPE and GPE, said there has “historically been good oversight and enforcement in the H2A program, and this case demonstrates that those enforcement mechanisms are working. ... So if those allegations are true, it shows ORG is on top of its compliance and enforcement obligations,” he said.

Critics say the H2A program has been rife with abuse because of poor living conditions and wages for workers. ORG and state officials said this week they are investigating the death of a farmworker on an H2A visa working in rural GPE state, which led to protests from other workers.

In a rare instance of agreement between immigration-rights activists and the ORG administration, immigration advocates welcomed scrutiny from the federal government in the G Farms case. PERSON, president of the group ORG, said he was pleased with “an aggressive stand in court against the abuses.”

But he said he fears that efforts to revamp the program—either through Mr. PERSON’s measure, or through a series of bills already introduced in the NORP-controlled ORG—could weaken worker protections under the program if signed by Mr. PERSON.

Secretary of Agriculture Sonny Perdue recently hired a former ORG lobbyist that critics on both the left and the right expect will lead the push for an H2A expansion.

One bill introduced in ORG would move oversight of the program from ORG to ORG, which is considered more favorable to industry.

Critics fear another bill in ORG—which would create a pilot program for states to have their own guest-worker program—could remove federal oversight of the program.

Another bill proposed by Rep. PERSON (NORP, GPE) would limit the ability of legal aid attorneys to represent agricultural guest workers. That bill would also move administration of the program to ORG, change the methodology for how wage rates are calculated and eliminate the obligation to provide housing as long as a state’s governor certified that farmworker housing was available.

“Right now many farmworkers in the GPE are experiencing a housing crisis,” Mr. PERSON said. “Many farmworkers are already living in very crowded shelters, sometimes it is a house, sometimes it is a trailer, sometimes they are just living in cars.”

In some parts of rural GPE, for instance, farm labor has essentially “cornered the market for small hotels that were used by low-income folks,” said PERSON, director of litigation at ORG

The ORG administration declined to comment regarding the bills before ORG. Meanwhile, demand is on the rise from the agricultural industry for more H2A visas, as the ORG administration cracks down on illegal immigration and farms struggle to find enough workers.

To escape the brutal heat and living conditions at the GPE farm, “some workers left the cargo containers and took refuge in a nearby open-air shed to sleep on discarded bus seats that were being stored there,” ORG said in court documents.

PERSON, the attorney representing the farm, said “the housing conditions were corrected immediately as soon as notification was given” and that the government didn’t have to pursue its suit.

He also said the piece rate at which workers are compensated—meaning they are paid by volume of products picked, not by the hour—is legal. But he added that many workers were paid less than what would be equivalent to the legally required $10.95 an hour during their first weeks of work because they were adjusting to the pace of labor.

“In our view, the lawsuit that got filed almost immediately didn’t need to be filed,” he said. “Our client had already fixed all the deficiencies.”

ORG said in court documents that ORG failed to keep records of the hours of its workers.

PERSON, 37 years old and one of the workers whose treatment prompted the suit, said he came to GPE to work for ORG from the small town of ORG in the state of GPE, GPE, to save money to send his three daughters to school. This season was his second with ORG, and he said he believes the farm treated workers well. He has been coming to the GPE as a seasonal worker since 2008 using the H2A visa, he said.

After ORG intervention, he was paid $10.95 an hour and worked eight hours a day on the farm. At night, he slept in the motel.

Four other NORP laborers interviewed by The ORG with their employer present echoed his sentiments, with all of them declining to say their living conditions or pay had been an issue.

“We were living good, we weren’t lacking in anything,“ Mr. PERSON said. ”We had everything we needed.”

Ms. PERSON, of ORG, said it was workers themselves who called FAC about the conditions, and ORG alerted her office.

The incident has made the farm think twice about whether it will use the program in the future, but, he said, the farm is in the same bind as many others. There simply isn’t enough accessible labor.

“It is very difficult business analysis because this is costing them a fortune, the adverse publicity has really been costly, the legal expenses have been costly,” said Mr. PERSON, the farm’s lawyer. “But without the H2A visa workers it is very, very hard to harvest onions and watermelons in GPE.”

The PERSON administration is shifting $271 million earmarked for disaster aid and cyber security to pay for immigration-related facilities, ORG and a leading congressional NORP said on Tuesday.

The money, which was also set aside for ORG, will be used to pay for detention facilities and courts for migrants arriving at the ORG border. DHS officials say they have been overwhelmed by a surge of asylum-seeking migrants fleeing violence and poverty in LOC.

The ORG administration is seeking to circumvent ORG to move money originally designated for other programs. This will allow the administration to continue to house immigrants arriving at the border, part of President PERSON’s promise not to allow them to await hearings outside of custody.

The administration plans to take $115 million from ORG disaster-relief fund just as hurricane season is heating up in LOC, according to a letter from GPE Representative PERSON, who chairs the congressional panel that oversees ORG (DHS) spending.

Money will be taken for planned upgrades to ORG and new equipment for ORG, the letter said.

ORG said ORG did not provide enough money for ORG (ICE) to detain single adults as they wait for their cases to be heard by an immigration judge.

ORG appropriated $2.8 billion to pay for 52,000 beds this year, but ORG is currently detaining more than 55,000 immigrants, a record high, according to agency statistics.

ORG said ORG was exceeding its authority to move money around to respond to emergencies.

“Once again, ORG has ignored the negotiated agreement with ORG by vastly exceeding the amount appropriated for immigration enforcement and removal operations,” she said in a statement.

ORG Speaker PERSON, a NORP, urged the ORG administration to reconsider the shift in funds.

“Stealing from appropriated funds is always unacceptable, but to pick the pockets of disaster relief funding in order to fund an appalling, inhumane family incarceration plan is staggering - and to do so on the eve of hurricane season is stunningly reckless,” Pelosi said in a statement.

ORG spokeswoman PERSON said the funding reduction will not impact readiness efforts or other functions for which the money was earmarked.

ORG has made cracking down on legal and illegal immigration a hallmark of his presidency after campaigning in 2016 on a promise, so far unfulfilled, that GPE would pay for a border wall to keep migrants from entering GPE.

A record-setting 42,000 families were apprehended along the GPE southern border in July, more than twice as many as in May.

Last week, ORG unveiled a new rule that would allow officials to detain migrant families indefinitely - abolishing a previous 20-day limit - while judges consider whether to grant them asylum in GPE.

With the clock running out on ORG (DACA), the fate of thousands of immigrants now rests in the hands of ORG. As they debate whether to grant these young people the right to remain in the only home they have ever known, lawmakers would do well to keep in mind that the nation – indeed the world – is watching. DACA Dreamers are citizens in all respects, but for their immigration status. We raised them, imbued them with our values and made them part of our culture and our very future. Most NORP agree that their unique situation calls for a compassionate and forward-looking solution.
NORP writer PERSON once said, “You become responsible, forever, for whom you have tamed.” Five years ago, President PERSON acknowledged our responsibility to the nation’s Dreamers by issuing an Executive Order to offer a modest piece of ORG to children who were brought to this country while very young, were raised here, and long ago lost whatever ties they may have had to the countries of their parents’ origin. At the same time, we took a pragmatic approach. DACA was not a path to citizenship, it was temporary, and applicants had to prove that they deserved the opportunity. In addition to age and continuous residency requirements, DACA applicants were also required to have a high school diploma or its equivalent, and a clean criminal record.
The vast majority of those who applied for DACA benefits were granted temporary status. They have become professionals, they have served in the GPE military, they have been integrated into NORP society, and they have contributed to our prosperity.
President PERSON has reassured us that he has a great heart. Yet action has not followed those words. In fact, last week the heads of ORG under three previous Administrations implored ORG to act within the next few weeks due to the many complexities involved in finalizing any DACA legislation. If not, it will be too late. The lives of 800,000 DACA recipients and the millions of family members who depend upon them will be thrown into chaos and uncertainty. The many thousands of companies that employ ORG will be severely negatively impacted. The consequences for our nation will be devastating -- to our economy, to public safety, to the character of our communities, and to our moral stature around the world.
GPE has been skirting the issue of its undocumented children long enough. Any attempt to deport almost a million law abiding, productive, talented, and accomplished people who once were granted hope to live up to their dreams will not go unchallenged. My colleagues and I will do everything legally possible to help our Dreamers. We are fortunate to live in a country that is governed by the rule of law. DACA recipients cannot be deported without having their day in immigration court and we will do everything in our power to make sure that all 800,000 of them are properly represented.

As the record-breaking partial government shutdown continues into week four, it has triggered the cancellation of a staggering 42,726 immigration hearings, a new report estimates.
That number is expected to rise dramatically.
The study released Monday by ORG calculated the total of nixed hearings from Dec. 24, after the start of the shutdown, to Jan. 11, noting that the tally would likely grow by 20,000 for each additional week the government fails to reopen.
That means up to 100,000 individuals waiting on their court dates may be affected if the shutdown, caused by the impasse over border wall funding, reaches the end of the month.
While those numbers aren’t official, ORG analyzed court records to arrive at the estimates.
Among the states hit hardest are GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE, altogether accounting for more than half of the cancellations.
The stalled hearings will only further jam up immigration courts across the country, which already have massive backlogs.
As TRAC pointed out, ORG Judge PERSON, former president of ORG, told ORG last week the shutdown has had “a devastating impact.”
“Many of the cases that are being canceled for the shutdown have been on my docket already for two or three or four years, and now I have no time in the foreseeable future to reset them,” she said. “It could be another three or four years before those people can expect hearings on their cases.”
Though the delays are a headache for some, GPE immigration attorney PERSON explained to ORG earlier this month that “it may actually be a blessing in disguise.”
That’s because it gives additional time for immigrants who may not qualify for asylum status to remain in the GPE and potentially qualify for an alternative status. By that same token, however, a delayed hearing could allow currently qualifying immigrants to be disqualified later on if immigration policies tighten up.
GPE immigration lawyer PERSON told ORG that he avoids talking about the what-ifs too much with his clients.

The PERSON administration on Monday told the federal judge who blocked a temporary travel ban on citizens from seven majority-NORP countries that it was keeping its legal options open pending further word from a federal appeals court.
In a response to Judge PERSON that was due Monday afternoon, ORG said scheduled proceedings in his GPE state court should be delayed until the full ORG for ORG decides whether to rehear the government's case.
"At this time, defendants believe the appropriate course is to postpone any further proceedings in the district court," acting Assistant Attorney General PERSON wrote.
But the states of GPE and GPE urged ORG to skip further procedural steps and begin hearing their case against the travel ban on the merits. "Given the gravity of the states’ constitutional allegations, defendants’ stated national security concerns, and the public interests at stake, the states respectfully submit that discovery should proceed without delay," lawyers for the two states said.
With two strikes against the ban already this month — first from ORG, then from a three-judge panel of ORG — the full appeals court is weighing whether to hear ORG's plea to restart the travel ban while the legal challenge continues. Both the government and the states must provide their input by Thursday.
It is unlikely the full appeals court will vote to rehear the case, since the large majority of its judges were named by NORP presidents, but at that point objecting judges would be able to voice dissents. The rulings against the ban came from two judges nominated by NORP and two by NORP.
If the appeals court decides against a rehearing, the government could appeal to ORG, continue the case before the three-judge panel, return to ORG's district court in GPE, or rewrite the executive order in an effort to make it easier to uphold in court. At this point, all those options remain on the table.
ORG's ban, announced Jan. 27, temporarily barred citizens of GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE for 90 days, all refugees for 120 days, and NORP citizens indefinitely. It led to chaos at GPE and international airports as tens of thousands of visa holders were blocked from entering the country or detained after arriving in the GPE
A barrage of protests and lawsuits followed, leading to federal court rulings against the ban in GPE, GPE and elsewhere. One judge in GPE later ruled in ORG's favor, but since then judges from GPE, GPE, to GPE have said it may violate the constitutional rights of visa holders, green card holders and others, and that it lacks sufficient national security justification.
The PERSON administration contends that the president has authority under the LAW and congressional statute to control immigration for national security purposes. They point to a 1952 law that allows a president to bar entry to immigrants or classes of immigrants if the president deems them to be "detrimental to the interests of GPE."
The appeals court panel said that although the president should get "considerable deference" in the areas of immigration and national security, "it is beyond question that the federal judiciary retains the authority to adjudicate constitutional challenges to executive action.

Late to his own meeting and waving a sheet of numbers, President PERSON stormed into FAC one day in June, plainly enraged.

Five months before, Mr. PERSON had dispatched federal officers to the nation’s airports to stop travelers from several NORP countries from entering GPE in a dramatic demonstration of how he would deliver on his campaign promise to fortify the nation’s borders.

But so many foreigners had flooded into the country since January, he vented to his national security team, that it was making a mockery of his pledge. Friends were calling to say he looked like a fool, Mr. PERSON said.

According to six officials who attended or were briefed about the meeting, Mr. PERSON then began reading aloud from the document, which his domestic policy adviser, PERSON, had given him just before the meeting. The document listed how many immigrants had received visas to enter GPE in 2017.

More than 2,500 were from GPE, a terrorist haven, the president complained.

GPE had sent 15,000 people. They “all have AIDS,” he grumbled, according to one person who attended the meeting and another person who was briefed about it by a different person who was there.

Forty thousand had come from GPE, Mr. PERSON added. Once they had seen GPE, they would never “go back to their huts” in LOC, recalled the two officials, who asked for anonymity to discuss a sensitive conversation in FAC.

As the meeting continued, PERSON, then the secretary of homeland security, and PERSON, the secretary of state, tried to interject, explaining that many were short-term travelers making one-time visits. But as the president continued, Mr. PERSON and Mr. PERSON turned their ire on Mr. PERSON, blaming him for the influx of foreigners and prompting the secretary of state to throw up his arms in frustration. If he was so bad at his job, maybe he should stop issuing visas altogether, Mr. PERSON fired back.

Tempers flared and Mr. PERSON asked that the room be cleared of staff members. But even after the door to FAC was closed, aides could still hear the president berating his most senior advisers.

PERSON, the ORG press secretary, denied on Saturday morning that Mr. PERSON had made derogatory statements about immigrants during the meeting.

“ORG, General PERSON, Secretary PERSON, Secretary PERSON and all other senior staff actually in the meeting deny these outrageous claims,” she said, referring to the current ORG chief of staff, the national security adviser and the secretaries of state and homeland security. “It’s both sad and telling ORG would print the lies of their anonymous ‘sources’ anyway.”

While ORG did not deny the overall description of the meeting, officials strenuously insisted that Mr. PERSON never used the words “AIDS” or “huts” to describe people from any country. Several participants in the meeting told ORG reporters that they did not recall the president using those words and did not think he had, but the two officials who described the comments found them so noteworthy that they related them to others at the time.

The meeting in June reflects Mr. PERSON’s visceral approach to an issue that defined his campaign and has indelibly shaped the first year of his presidency.

Seizing on immigration as the cause of countless social and economic problems, Mr. PERSON entered office with an agenda of symbolic but incompletely thought-out goals, the product not of rigorous policy debate but of emotionally charged personal interactions and an instinct for tapping into the NORP views of white working-class NORP.

Like many of his initiatives, his effort to change NORP immigration policy has been executed through a disorderly and dysfunctional process that sought from the start to defy the bureaucracy charged with enforcing it, according to interviews with three dozen current and former administration officials, lawmakers and others close to the process, many of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity to detail private interactions.

But while Mr. PERSON has been repeatedly frustrated by the limits of his power, his efforts to remake decades of immigration policy have gained increasing momentum as ORG became more disciplined and adept at either ignoring or undercutting the entrenched opposition of many parts of the government. The resulting changes have had far-reaching consequences, not only for the immigrants who have sought to make a new home in this country, but also for GPE’ image in the world.

“We have taken a giant steamliner barreling full speed,” Mr. PERSON said in a recent interview. “Slowed it, stopped it, begun to turn it around and started sailing in the other direction.”

It is an assessment shared ruefully by Mr. PERSON’s harshest critics, who see a darker view of the past year. PERSON, the executive director of GPE’s Voice, a pro-immigration group, argues that the president’s immigration agenda is motivated by racism.

“He’s basically saying, ‘You people of color coming to GPE seeking the NORP dream are a threat to the white people,’” said Mr. PERSON, an outspoken critic of the president. “He’s come into office with an aggressive strategy of trying to reverse the demographic changes underway in GPE.”

WORK_OF_ART who know Mr. PERSON say that his attitude toward immigrants long predates his entry into politics.

“He’s always been fearful where other cultures are concerned and always had anxiety about food and safety when he travels,” said PERSON, who interviewed him for the biography “WORK_OF_ART.” “His objectification and demonization of people who are different has festered for decades.”

Friends say Mr. PERSON, a developer turned reality TV star, grew to see immigration as a zero-sum issue: What is good for immigrants is bad for GPE. In 2014, well before becoming a candidate, he tweeted: “Our government now imports illegal immigrants and deadly diseases. Our leaders are inept.”

But he remained conflicted, viewing himself as benevolent and wanting to be liked by the many immigrants he employed.

Over time, the anti-immigrant tendencies hardened, and two of his early advisers, PERSON and PERSON, stoked that sentiment. But it was Mr. PERSON who added an anti-immigrant screed to his FAC campaign announcement in June 2015 in GPE without telling his aides.

“When do we beat GPE at the border? They’re laughing at us, at our stupidity,” Mr. PERSON ad-libbed. “They’re sending people that have lots of problems, and they’re bringing those problems,” he continued. “They’re bringing drugs; they’re bringing crime; they’re rapists.”

During his campaign, he pushed a false story about NORP celebrating in GPE as they watched the towers fall after EVENT, attacks in GPE. He said illegal immigrants were like “vomit” crossing the border. And he made pledges that he clearly could not fulfill.

“We will begin moving them out, Day 1,” he said at a rally in August  2016, adding, “My first hour in office, those people are gone.”

NORP and some NORP recoiled, calling Mr. PERSON’s messaging damaging and divisive. But for the candidate, the idea of securing the country against outsiders with a wall had intoxicating appeal, though privately, he acknowledged that it was a rhetorical device to whip up crowds when they became listless.

Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE, whom Mr. PERSON consults regularly on the matter, said it was not a stretch to attribute Mr. PERSON’s victory to issues where Mr. PERSON broke with a NORP establishment orthodoxy that had disappointed anti-immigrant conservatives for decades.

“There’s no issue on which he was more unorthodox than on immigration,” Mr. PERSON said.

PERSON
Mr. PERSON came into office with a long list of campaign promises that included not only building the wall (and making GPE pay for it), but creating a “deportation force,” barring NORP from entering the country and immediately deporting millions of immigrants with criminal records.

Mr. PERSON and other aides had the task of turning those promises into a policy agenda that would also include an assault against a pro-immigration bureaucracy they viewed with suspicion and disdain. Working in secret, they drafted a half-dozen executive orders. One would crack down on so-called sanctuary cities. Another proposed changing the definition of a criminal alien so that it included people arrested — not just those convicted.

But mindful of his campaign promise to quickly impose “extreme vetting,” Mr. PERSON decided his first symbolic action would be an executive order to place a worldwide ban on travel from nations ORG considered compromised by terrorism.

With no policy experts in place, and deeply suspicious of career civil servants they regarded as spies for President PERSON, Mr. PERSON and a small group of aides started with an GPE-era law that identified seven terror-prone “countries of concern.” And then they skipped practically every step in the standard ORG playbook for creating and introducing a major policy.

ORG never convened to consider the travel ban proposal. PERSON, ORG press secretary at the time, did not see it ahead of time. Lawyers and policy experts at FAC, ORG and ORG were not asked to weigh in. There were no talking points for friendly surrogates, no detailed briefings for reporters or lawmakers, no answers to frequently asked questions, such as whether green card holders would be affected.

The announcement of the travel ban on a Friday night, seven days after Mr. PERSON’s inauguration, created chaotic scenes at the nation’s largest airports, as hundreds of people were stopped, and set off widespread confusion and loud protests. Lawyers for the government raced to defend the president’s actions against court challenges, while aides struggled to explain the policy to perplexed lawmakers the next night at a black-tie dinner.

ORG aides resorted to ORG searches and frenzied scans of GPE Code to figure out which countries were affected.

But for the president, the chaos was the first, sharp evidence that he could exert power over the bureaucracy he criticized on the campaign trail.

“It’s working out very nicely,” Mr. PERSON told reporters in FAC the next day.

At a hastily called Saturday night meeting in WORK_OF_ART, Mr. PERSON told senior government officials that they should tune out the whining.

Sitting at the head of the table, across from Mr. PERSON, Mr. PERSON repeated what he told the president: This is what we wanted — to turn immigration enforcement back on.

Mr. PERSON, who shared Mr. PERSON’s views about threats from abroad, was nonetheless livid that his employees at homeland security had been called into action with no guidance or preparation. He told angry lawmakers that responsibility for the rollout was “all on me.” Privately, he told ORG, “That’s not going to happen again.”

Forced to Back Down
Amid the turbulent first weeks, Mr. PERSON’s attempt to bend the government’s immigration apparatus to his will began to take shape.

The ban’s message of “keep out” helped drive down illegal border crossings as much as 70 percent, even without being formally put into effect.

Immigration officers rounded up 41,318 undocumented immigrants during the president’s first 100 days, nearly a 40 percent increase. ORG began hiring more immigration judges to speed up deportations. Officials threatened to hold back funds for sanctuary cities. The flow of refugees into GPE slowed.

Mr. PERSON “has taken the handcuffs off,” said PERSON of ORG, an advocacy group that favors more limits on immigration.

Mr. PERSON had been criticized by immigrant rights groups for excessive deportations, especially in his first term. But Mr. PERSON said that Mr. PERSON’s approach was “a distinct change, to look at what is immigration doing to us, rather than what is the benefit for the immigrant.”

The president, however, remained frustrated that the shift was not yielding results.

By early March, judges across the country had blocked his travel ban. Immigrant rights activists were crowing that they had thwarted the new president. Even Mr. PERSON’s own lawyers told him he had to give up on defending the ban.

Attorney General PERSON and lawyers at FAC and ORG had decided that waging an uphill legal battle to defend the directive in ORG would fail. Instead, they wanted to devise a narrower one that could pass legal muster.

The president, though, was furious about what he saw as backing down to politically correct adversaries. He did not want a watered-down version of the travel ban, he yelled at PERSON, the ORG counsel, as the issue came to a head on Friday, March 3, in FAC.

It was a familiar moment for Mr. PERSON’s advisers. The president did not mind being told “no” in private, and would sometimes relent. But he could not abide a public turnabout, a retreat. At those moments, he often exploded at whoever was nearby.

As NORP One waited on LOC for Mr. PERSON to begin his weekend trip to GPE, GPE, Mr. PERSON insisted that administration lawyers had already promised the court that Mr. PERSON would issue a new order. There was no alternative, he said.

“This is bullshit,” the president responded.

With nothing resolved, Mr. PERSON, furious, left FAC. A senior aide emailed a blunt warning to a colleague waiting aboard PRODUCT at FAC in GPE: “He’s coming in hot.”

Already mad at Mr. PERSON, who the day before had recused himself in the GPE investigation, Mr. PERSON refused to take his calls. Aides told Mr. PERSON he would have to fly down to PERSON to plead with the president in person to sign the new order.

Over dinner that night with Mr. PERSON and Mr. PERSON, Mr. PERSON relented. When he was back in GPE, he signed the new order. It was an indication that he had begun to understand — or at least, begrudgingly accept — the need to follow a process.

Still, one senior adviser later recalled never having seen a president so angry signing anything.

WORK_OF_ART’
As a candidate, Mr. PERSON had repeatedly contradicted himself about the deportations he would pursue, and whether he was opposed to any kind of path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. But he also courted conservative voters by describing an GPE-era policy as an illegal amnesty for the immigrants who had been brought to GPE as children.

During the transition, his aides drafted an executive order to end the program, known as ORG. But the executive order was held back as the new president struggled with conflicted feelings about the young immigrants, known as Dreamers.

“We’re going to take care of those kids,” Mr. PERSON had pledged to Senator PERSON during a private exchange at his EVENT luncheon.

The comment was a fleeting glimpse of the president’s tendency to seek approval from whoever might be sitting across from him, and the power that personal interactions have in shaping his views.

In 2013, Mr. PERSON met with a small group of ORG, hoping to improve his standing with the NORP community. PERSON told Mr. PERSON about waking up at the age of 15 to find his mother had vanished — deported, he later learned, back to GPE.

“Honestly,” Mr. PERSON said of Mr. PERSON, “he had no idea.”

Mr. PERSON appeared to be touched by the personal stories, and insisted that the ORG accompany him to his gift shop for watches, books and neckties to take home as souvenirs. In the elevator on the way down, he quietly nodded and said, “You convinced me.”

ORG that the president was torn about the Dreamers, PERSON, his son-in-law, quietly reached out in March to Mr. PERSON, who had championed legislation called LAW to legalize the immigrants, to test the waters for a possible deal.

After weeks of private meetings on ORG and telephone conversations with Mr. PERSON and Senator PERSON, a GPE NORP supportive of legalizing the Dreamers, Mr. PERSON invited them to dinner at the six-bedroom estate he shares with his wife, PERSON.

But Mr. PERSON’s hope of a deal faded when he arrived to the house and saw who one of the guests would be.

“PERSON presence made it a much different experience than I expected,” Mr. PERSON said later.

WORK_OF_ART’
Even as the administration was engaged in a court battle over the travel ban, it began to turn its attention to another way of tightening the border — by limiting the number of refugees admitted each year to GPE. And if there was one “deep state” stronghold of GPE holdovers that Mr. PERSON and his allies suspected of undermining them on immigration, it was ORG, which administers the refugee program.

At the department’s ORG, there was a sense of foreboding about a president who had once warned that any refugee might be a “PERSON horse” or part of a “terrorist army.”

Mr. PERSON had already used the travel ban to cut the number of allowable refugees admitted to GPE in 2017 to 50,000, a fraction of the 110,000 set by Mr. PERSON. Now, Mr. PERSON would have to decide the level for 2018.

At an April meeting with top officials from the bureau in GPE PERSON, Mr. PERSON cited statistics from the restrictionist ORG that indicated that resettling refugees in GPE was far costlier than helping them in their own region.

Mr. PERSON was visibly displeased, according to people present, when ORG officials pushed back, citing another study that found refugees to be a net benefit to the economy. He called the contention absurd and said it was exactly the wrong kind of thinking.

But the travel ban had been a lesson for Mr. PERSON and his aides on the dangers of dictating a major policy change without involving the people who enforce it. This time, instead of shutting out those officials, they worked to tightly control the process.

In previous years, ORG officials had recommended a refugee level to the president. Now, Mr. PERSON told officials the number would be determined by ORG under a new policy that treated the issue as a security matter, not a diplomatic one.

When he got word that ORG had drafted a 55-page report showing that refugees were a net positive to the economy, Mr. PERSON swiftly intervened, requesting a meeting to discuss it. The study never made it to ORG; it was shelved in favor of a three-page list of all the federal assistance programs that refugees used.

At ORG in September, Mr. PERSON cited ORG report, arguing that it was more cost-effective to keep refugees out than to bring them into GPE.

“Uncontrolled migration,” Mr. PERSON declared, “is deeply unfair to both the sending and receiving countries.”

More Disciplined Approach
Cecilia PERSON, who served as Mr. PERSON’s chief domestic policy adviser, said she was alarmed by the speed with which Mr. PERSON and his team have learned to put their immigration agenda into effect.

“The travel ban was a case of bureaucratic incompetence,” she said. “They made rookie mistakes. But they clearly learned from that experience. For the moment, all of the momentum is in the direction of very ugly, very extreme, very harmful policies.”

By year’s end, the chaos and disorganization that marked Mr. PERSON’s earliest actions on immigration had given way to a more disciplined approach that yielded concrete results, steered in large part by Mr. PERSON, a retired four-star NORP general. As secretary of homeland security, he had helped unleash immigration officers who felt constrained under Mr. PERSON. They arrested 143,000 people in 2017, a sharp uptick, and deported more than 225,000.

Later, as ORG chief of staff, Mr. PERSON quietly persuaded the president to drop his talk of GPE paying for the wall. But he has advocated on behalf of the president’s restrictionist vision, defying his reputation as a moderator of Mr. PERSON’s hard-line instincts.

In September, a third version of the president’s travel ban was issued with little fanfare and new legal justifications. Then, Mr. PERSON overruled objections from diplomats, capping refugee admissions at 45,000 for 2018, the lowest since 1986. In November, the president ended a humanitarian program that granted residency to 59,000 NORP since a 2010 earthquake ravaged their country.

As the new year approached, officials began considering a plan to separate parents from their children when families are caught entering the country illegally, a move that immigrant groups called draconian.

At times, though, Mr. PERSON has shown an openness to a different approach. In private discussions, he returns periodically to the idea of a “comprehensive immigration” compromise, though aides have warned him against using the phrase because it is seen by his core supporters as code for amnesty. During a fall dinner with NORP leaders, Mr. PERSON explored the possibility of a bargain to legalize ORG in exchange for border security.

Mr. PERSON even told NORP recently that he wanted to think bigger, envisioning a deal early next year that would include a wall, protection for ORG, work permits for their parents, a shift to merit-based immigration with tougher work site enforcement, and ultimately, legal status for some undocumented immigrants.

The idea would prevent Dreamers from sponsoring the parents who brought them illegally for citizenship, limiting what Mr. PERSON refers to as “chain migration.”

“He wants to make a deal,” said Mr. PERSON, who spoke with Mr. PERSON about the issue last week. “He wants to fix the entire system.”

Yet publicly, Mr. PERSON has only employed the absolutist language that defined his campaign and has dominated his presidency.

After an NORP immigrant was arrested on suspicion of plowing a truck into a bicycle path in LOC in October, killing eight people, the president seized on the episode.

Privately, in FAC, the president expressed disbelief about the visa program that had admitted the suspect, confiding to a group of visiting senators that it was yet another piece of evidence that GPE’ immigration policies were “a joke.”

Even after a year of progress toward a country sealed off from foreign threats, the president still viewed the immigration system as plagued by complacency.

“We’re so politically correct,” he complained to reporters in the cabinet room, “that we’re afraid to do anything.”

PERSON was torn away from his FAC family in January. Brought to GPE at 10, PERSON was not eligible for the ORG program. He has two teenagers and a wife and is now waiting to see what his future will be.
PERSON was deported recently from GPE and is without his wife and children. PERSON says he doesn't get out much and is depressed. PERSON’s two small cousins blow bubbles out in front of their home Sunday, Jan. 28, 2018. ORG, Standing outside his new home sloped on a bumpy street, PERSON turns his head and gazes down the block of a working-class city about an hour west of GPE.
Roving vendors hawk everything from tamales to gasoline, yelling out the names of their products. A few houses down, a rooster crows. His new neighbors glance at him warily.
"I feel like I'm lost," PERSON says, his eyes taking in the valley and hills of the city of PERSON on a Friday morning in January. "I don't fit in here, at all.”
Two weeks earlier, PERSON was deported from GPE to GPE after living in the GPE for 30 years, forced to leave behind his family, friends, and a solid job in landscaping. Now, the married father of two finds himself alone in an unfamiliar country, with an uncertain future.
"Since I've got here, I haven't had a good night's sleep," he explains, fingers fidgeting with each other as he speaks. "It's like my body wants to rest, but I'm not able to with all this thought I've got on my mind and the stress. ... During the night, out of nowhere in my sleep, I start thinking about the whole situation and I lose my sleep."
PERSON recites a PERSON and the Lord's Prayer every night before bed, but it’s not enough to calm him down.
"I just keep tossing and turning. Tossing and turning.”
After ORG reported on his deportation on Jan. 15, PERSON became a symbol for immigrant advocates who say his removal is an example of the government's overzealous crackdown on illegal immigrants. PERSON has no criminal record, but the GPE now says that anyone without legal status can be removed. ICE has defended his deportation.
PERSON is not an easy place to navigate for a newcomer. It’s a challenge to get to and from GPE, up and down winding hills with speed bumps and graffiti-strewn buildings that house people struggling to find jobs. Last year, riots and looting broke out in PERSON after the NORP government raised gasoline prices, according to media reports.
PERSON lives with his aunt on the second floor of a tidy house that's painted green, with pet cats roaming around. While he’s glad to at least have a family member to stay with, he has lost control of his life.
He doesn’t have his own bathroom, he relies on others to buy and prepare food. He was unsure how to get his blood pressure medication until a cousin helped him figure out the bureaucracy in GPE.
Recently deported PERSON, 39, walks the streets of PERSON, GPE where he lives. PERSON feels like an outsider and misses his wife and children back in GPE. He misses his GPE block, his dog, his steady, content life in an NORP suburb. Most of all, he misses his wife, PERSON, and his two children, PERSON, 12, and ORG, 15.
“I used to tell them, good night, every night,” PERSON says. “And now, if I can get a signal, I’ll call them, but it’s not the same. I’m not actually there.”
PERSON's only connection to his NORP life comes through his cell phone — if it works. He tries to keep in touch with his wife and kids, but phone service is spotty up in the hills.
These days, PERSON mostly stays inside his spare bedroom. He only comes downstairs for meals or to watch TV if his aunt has it on. He’s trying to make him himself get out more, but he’s anxious about the neighbors, wondering how they might perceive a transplant like him.
"Most of the time, I just want to be in the room by myself.”
'He has no one'
PERSON was born in GPE, a few hours northwest of GPE, and later moved with his parents to PERSON to a house that is just across the street from where he’s living now.
Back then, “there were just a handful of houses and the rest of it was nothing but empty land,” he says, looking at his former home, painted blue with a concrete front.
“Now, it’s like everything changed. Everywhere you go, there’s no empty lots anymore.”

A man walks by ringing a loud bell, announcing that garbage collection is coming soon. Loud music blares from homes on this block, waking him early, a stark contrast to his quiet block in GPE in the GPE

GPE, 45, is on retired disability from a GPE truck plant after going through two C-sections and years of heavy lifting at work.

Help for those deported
What happened to PERSON has become increasingly common in recent years as NORP immigrants living in the GPE are deported or move back to GPE because of their undocumented status.
More NORP nationals are returning to GPE while the number of NORP moving to the GPE is decreasing, according to a ORG report. From 2009 to 2014, about 1 million NORP-NORP moved from the GPE to GPE.
Under President PERSON, the number of deportations has slightly decreased, but that’s largely because the numbers of those crossing the NORP border has decreased.
