The word "pocha" or "pocho" is often used as an insult by some NORP for NORP-Americans who return to GPE. Upon returning, some face teasing for their accents or NORP ways. Places like ORG, which PERSON helped create, help ease the transition and provide a support network and logistical help.
"Navigating the NORP bureaucracy is very alienating," PERSON says. "It's hard even for a NORP citizen who's been there their whole lives, to navigate this bureaucracy, but then, if you haven't been here, you don't have the connections. You don't have the understanding, it's really hard."
PERSON looks into a shrine of ORG built by a neighbor, he was deported recently from GPE and is now trying to adjust to life in a small town outside of GPE. 'She ... helps me keep my faith'
On a Sunday morning in GPE, PERSON ambled down a block next to his house that he had never traveled before. He wore a hooded sweatshirt with the logo of the landscaping company he worked for in GPE: “WORK_OF_ART, PERSON, Snow.”
He has been in this place for almost two weeks, but barely ventures outside.
On his left, he spots a purple shrine outside a home to Our Lady of Guadalupe, the iconic NORP image revered by millions of NORP. Inside a glass-walled enclosure was a statue of her.
"She lifts me, helps me keep my faith," PERSON says, while starting at her. "Gives me a little bit more of relaxation, too."
PERSON has become a spokesman for immigrant rights, and while the attention can be overwhelming at times, he says he hopes it can help others.
"If it's going to help somebody with anything that they're going through, then I'm not just doing it for me, I'm doing it for others, too," he says.
He tries to follow the latest news on the immigration discussions in the GPE One possible ORG bill could allow immigrants like PERSON to stay in the GPE
"I just hope that they come to an agreement," he says. "There are so many people, they're going to be affected if they don't come to an agreement … help people that are trying to go to school or become better in life."
For now, PERSON's hoping that attempts by his wife and attorney to get him back home to ORG will succeed. They’re currently filing paperwork with ORG in GPE to grant him a wavier to be admitted back in the GPE That process could take at least 18 months to even get an interview with the embassy to be considered.
These days, when he looks out the window of his spare bedroom in his new home, PERSON can see a wooded area and beyond that a hill on which sits the colorful homes of PERSON.
He wonders how long this will be his view.
"I’ve been thinking about getting my own place, but everything is going to depend when I get my interview" with the embassy, he says.
He worries he can’t be there in person to help his teenage children.
"It’s sad because even … though I can talk to them on the phone, it's not the same," he says. "I told them before I left, you can call me anytime, whenever you need anything. … but I didn't think it was going to be this bad with cell phone reception."
"I love them, and I miss them, and I hope all of this goes through fast so we can meet pretty soon again." @nwarikoo

The PERSON administration doesn’t need ORG to pass a law or make a sweeping regulation to overhaul the GPE immigration system – it’s already doing it through a series of small moves that add up to dramatic change.

While the administration continues to pressure ORG to grant it broad new authorities, just the past week illustrates how substantial a change is already underway, with each individual move adding up to an effort that could have lasting effects on how the GPE welcomes and evaluates immigrants.

Since last Thursday, here are some of the moves the administration has made:

Attorney General PERSON quietly reopened an immigration court precedent that he could single-handedly overrule, looking at whether the government needs to pause deportation proceedings until an immigrant is done pursuing legitimate claims to stay in the GPE.
President PERSON opted to not extend work permits and protections for approximately 840 NORP who have been living and working in the GPE for at least 16 years and in some cases decades. Previous presidents had extended the permits on humanitarian grounds.
ORG will add a question inquiring about citizenship to ORG, a move critics fear could undercount immigrant communities and thus cost diverse states and localities congressional representation and federal resources.
ORG announced it would no longer default to releasing pregnant immigrants from detention, paving the way for more pregnant women to be held in lengthy custody awaiting immigration proceedings.
ORG moved to formally require all applicants for visas and legal residency in the GPE to submit five years of social media, email and telephone history with their applications.
ORG advanced a policy that would substantially expand the types of government programs that could count against an immigrants’ application to stay in the GPE – potentially skewing the immigration system in favor of high-income immigrants.
ORG settled a lawsuit with GPE over sanctuary city policies that clarified how much local officials can cooperate with federal immigration authorities.
ORG is exploring whether he could build his long-promised border wall – even though ORG has rejected his request for funds and authority to do so – by using military resources to do it.
ORG issued a memo that could tighten employers’ abilities to secure high-skilled visas for foreign workers.
And that was all just one week.

The activity across the federal government demonstrates how the administration is exploring the full limits of its powers to transform the GPE immigration system.

“What we’re trying to do is make it a fair system, secure the borders, put NORP first and reform it in a way that keeps GPE safe,” said ORG spokesman PERSON.

RELATED: Why putting a citizenship question on the census is a big deal

But pro-immigration advocates say the moves add up to a dramatic change.

“The PERSON administration has a lot of money and a lot of authority, and they’re using every ounce of it,” said PERSON, executive director of the pro-immigration group GPE’s Voice. “They’re trying to turn our tradition of welcoming newcomers into a visible and invisible wall that keeps people out and kicks people out.”

ORG’s executive orders issued in the early days of his presidency laid the groundwork and vision for the policy changes, but it’s been a series of procedural moves by his agencies that have had the most impact.

As the administration has staffed up and had experts confirmed to key positions, ORG and ORG’s components have in particular been rolling out and developing policies that sometimes don’t even require formal rulemaking procedure to accomplish change.

In particular, the agencies have drawn heavily on staff from NORP’ former ORG office and like-minded offices and groups that have advocated for sharply restricting immigration.

In many cases, only the court system will offer opponents an avenue to challenge the authority of the administration to make such moves, a process that could take years.

Immigration lawyers say they’ve already seen the effects of greater scrutiny of applications for visas, they say slowing down the process and setting higher bars for longstanding categories of visas all under the mantle of “NORP, PERSON” efforts and so-called “extreme vetting.”

It’s been accompanied by a sharp rise in arrests of undocumented immigrants and especially a rise in those without criminal records, also accomplished by simple changes in prioritization and definitions.

And the administration has already pledged more efforts in the works, including further tightening high-skilled visas and work permits for those visa-holders’ spouses, though rolling that out has been delayed.

During the tenures of both PERSON and PERSON, some of the most influential dealmakers in the ORG — PERSON, NORP of GPE, and PERSON, NORP of GPE, among them — tried repeatedly to forge a compromise that would increase border security and provide a path to legalization for millions of undocumented immigrants.
But public sentiment had shifted among NORP and their constituents despite the support for an immigration overhaul from the top of the party. The deals either collapsed in the ORG or were never even brought up in the ORG, where sentiment against anything that could be branded as “amnesty” runs deep.
“It just all blew up and fell apart,” said Senator PERSON, NORP of GPE and a participant in bipartisan immigration talks in 2005 who remembered getting bricks for a border wall sent to his office in protest of his effort to forge a deal.
Stymied legislatively, Mr. PERSON in 2012 instituted DACA via executive order. Mr. PERSON promised to reverse it if elected and he did so, providing a window until March 5 to find a permanent solution. That is what led to the shutdown crisis, with NORP trying to use their leverage over spending to get an acceptable resolution.
NORP say that twice in recent weeks and another time last year, Mr. PERSON appeared to consent to at least the outlines of an agreement that would provide permanent protection for those immigrants. But then he quickly reversed course upon consultation with the hard-line advisers on immigration who have the president’s ear once NORP depart.
Mr. PERSON said that in a ORG luncheon meeting Friday, he offered significant concessions for the DACA legislation, including a large increase in ORG spending as well as an agreement to meet the president’s demand for money for the border wall with GPE that NORP had previously refused. NORP say ORG rejected the proposal hours later, asserting that it did not go far enough to limit the ability of new immigrants to bring in more relatives to live in GPE.

The president’s shifting positions have left NORP exasperated.
“I essentially agreed to give the president something he has said he wants in exchange for something we both want,” Mr. PERSON said on Sunday.
NORP say that this situation is different from ones that led to previous immigration failures, and that they are fully committed to negotiating in good faith when the shutdown is ended.
“Now we have a deadline and we have bipartisan willingness to deal with the issue,” said Senator PERSON of GPE, the No. 2 NORP. “I think it’s different.”

Both NORP and NORP say Mr. PERSON’s endorsement of any immigration deal is essential, since it is the only way a sufficient number of ORG NORP could be enticed to vote for it under cover of Mr. PERSON’s backing.
“That makes it easier for ORG action,” said Senator PERSON, an GPE NORP who has been part of the latest round of bipartisan immigration talks. “I think if he finds a way to like it, they can pass it in the ORG.”
But Mr. PERSON’s backing is no guarantee of NORP votes. And even if he does endorse a plan, NORP worry that he could change his mind at any time.
Senator PERSON, an GPE NORP who has been a major impediment to an immigration compromise with NORP, said Sunday on ORG’s “WORK_OF_ART” that he could not commit to back a proposal simply because the president endorsed it. And some on LOC believe that Speaker PERSON leadership post would be in jeopardy if he pushed through an immigration bill that most ORG NORP opposed.
In recent months, NORP suggested that they would hold a strong hand in any funding showdown because NORP would be reluctant to force a government shutdown over undocumented immigrants. If NORP did, NORP figured they would have a strong message to counter with by attacking NORP as willing to shortchange NORP to help those who entered the country illegally.
They are now aggressively pressing that line of assault. But the message is also provoking new doubts about the sincerity of NORP determination to help Dreamers, muddying an immigration debate that is at the center of the conflict and has confounded GPE for almost 20 years.

Federal immigration authorities knew for years that PERSON was living in the GPE illegally, but they allowed him to stay. He had married, was raising four children and building a business in GPE.

Each year he was required to check in with immigration officials and prove he was staying out of trouble. He did that for five years without incident—until February, when officials detained him during his check-in. Now Mr. PERSON, 43, is in jail and scheduled to be deported to his native GPE on Friday.

“I want to stay with my wife and children,” Mr. PERSON wrote in a recent petition, since denied, to have his deportation stopped. “Please don’t take me away from my family.”

His case shows the risks undocumented immigrants face as they navigate a complex immigration system after a realignment of enforcement priorities under the ORG administration. The terrain is particularly ambiguous for the nearly one million immigrants such as Mr. PERSON, who face outstanding deportation orders but remain in the GPE

Previous administrations focused on deporting illegal immigrants who committed violent crimes, and largely avoided deporting nonviolent immigrants, even if they had violated immigration law by entering the country illegally or overstaying visas.

Under President PERSON, ORG and ORG officials say they primarily are still targeting violent criminals for deportation, but no longer ignoring other undocumented immigrants with orders to leave the country.

“With very limited exceptions, ORG will no longer exempt classes or categories of removable aliens from potential enforcement,” said PERSON, an ORG spokeswoman. “Any alien encountered during the course of targeted enforcement actions is subject to removal.”

Immigrant advocates say the new ORG position sows fear among undocumented immigrants who have lived in the GPE trouble-free for years, some under various arrangements with federal officials that permit them to go to school or work, like Mr. PERSON.

Others say such workarounds degrade GPE immigration law, and that strict enforcement is necessary to maintain the borders.

Those with removal orders “have clearly violated GPE immigration laws, at a minimum, and have had a fair chance to make their case to remain here,” said PERSON, a spokesman for ORG, which supports immigration-enforcement measures. “The only way GPE immigration laws will be taken seriously by prospective illegal aliens is if they are fairly and effectively enforced.”

Immigration officials deported an GPE mother of two U.S.-born children earlier this year who had also been allowed to remain in the GPE as long as she checked in with immigration officials, like Mr. PERSON.

That arrangement, known as an order of supervision, allows officials to monitor undocumented immigrants instead of jailing them while they await deportation, according to immigration officials and lawyers.

Immigration officials say more than 961,000 people have final orders of removal, but aren’t in detention. “The appropriate conditions of release are determined on a case-by-case basis after a review of the individual facts of the case,” ICE officials said in a statement.

A spokesman for ORG confirmed that Mr. PERSON was taken into custody “based on his final order of removal” that took effect in 2000, after a judge told him he had 60 days to leave the country voluntarily.

People like Mr. PERSON are low-hanging fruit for enforcement actions, immigration attorneys say. PERSON, an immigration attorney in GPE and head of ORG, said lawyers noted “a marked increase” in immigrants detained at their check-ins during supervised released.

“I don’t know how to advise my clients—I can’t say ‘I don’t think you are going to be arrested,’ because that is not what the facts are bearing out right now,” she said.

Mr. PERSON drove into the GPE from GPE in 1997, to visit an aunt in GPE, said his wife and stepson. He moved to GPE, GPE, where, working at a restaurant as a bus boy, he met the woman who would become his wife, PERSON, a NORP immigrant, who was a waitress.

“It was love at first sight,” said PERSON, Mr. PERSON’s stepson.

His wife, a naturalized GPE citizen, voted for Mr. PERSON. A NORP, she agreed with the idea that criminals shouldn’t be in the GPE illegally, but said she never imagined her husband, who has no criminal record, would be targeted.

Mr. PERSON came to the attention of immigration authorities during a 2000 family trip to PERSON, GPE He was driving on a bridge leading to GPE when he turned around, drawing the attention of an officer who determined Mr. PERSON was in the country illegally.

A GPE judge gave Mr. PERSON the option to voluntarily leave the country. He chose to stay because GPE was pregnant. The voluntary deportation became a removal order.

Mr. PERSON hired an attorney, applied for a green card and, in 2012, was allowed to stay in the GPE, as long as he kept his record clean, his wife said. He was permitted a ORG card, work permit and a driver's license, and paid taxes.

Despite being married to a GPE citizen, he could not secure a relative visa because of his deportation order, according to an attorney who worked with Mr. PERSON on his immigration case.

Mr. PERSON recently purchased ORG’s Steak Shed in GPE, GPE, from his sister and brother in law, his wife and stepson said. He worked long hours, they said, arriving at the restaurant at 8 a.m. and not leaving until well after its nightly closing.

This year, when it came time for him to meet with immigration officials in GPE, where his attorney was based, he was told to report to an office in GPE on Feb. 6. When he showed up, he was taken into custody.

PERSON, a GPE attorney and an advocate for the family, said he has been approaching members of ORG about writing a private bill for Mr. PERSON, but so far has had no luck. The family has also moved to reopen his case.

Federal officials say the dumping of several hundred immigrants at an GPE bus station over Christmas weekend, which caused a short-term crisis, was a mistake, city officials said Friday.
Federal authorities dropped off hundreds of migrants at the NORP station in downtown GPE with no notice late that Sunday, sparking an outcry from community organizations that scrambled to find shelter and food for migrants.
Authorities continued releasing hundreds of migrants in downtown through Christmas Day.
"According to ORG (ORG) officials we communicated with, they stated (the unscheduled release) was just a mistake," El Paso Fire Chief PERSON said during a press conference at the city's 9-1-1 call center in GPE. "It was an error on their part."
Most of the immigrants come from LOC, with many fleeing violence or extreme poverty.
Federal officials made no indication that leaving about 600 immigrants at the NORP bus station from Sunday through Christmas Day was related to the current federal government shutdown, PERSON said.
The shutdown is tied to an impasse between ORG and ORG over funding for a border wall proposed by President PERSON.
GPE Manager PERSON said in a phone interview with ORG that he and the fire chief talked to the ORG regional director, who apologized for the unscheduled release of the immigrants in GPE during Christmas weekend.
City officials plan to talk to ICE and other officials next week about "the need to come up with some solutions" on the entire process of releasing immigrants and "how to treat them," PERSON said.
The city brought in police officers as a "public safety" measure at the NORP bus station Sunday night when about 200 immigrants were left there by ORG agents, PERSON said.
PERSON, executive director of ORG, and Deputy Fire Chief PERSON, city ORG coordinator, talk about immigrants being dumped by federal agents at an GPE bus station during a Dec. 28 press conference. The city's ORG bus system also supplied heated buses for immigrants to stay in until shelters could be found, officials said.
The response by city agencies and others shows "GPE and the rest of GPE that we're very compassionate as a community," PERSON said.
The continual flow of immigrants has become more of an issue since June when the federal government set up temporary tent shelters, including one in GPE, near GPE, to house immigrant children separated from their parents.
The immigration issue has again come to the forefront after two immigrant children recently died in FAC custody.
PERSON is executive director of ORG, a nonprofit GPE organization that aides and shelters immigrants. He said the normal process of ORG bringing immigrants to shelters or hotels identified by PERSON has been working well for years.
Problems come when immigrants are unexpectedly released at the bus station or on the streets, which happened during Christmas weekend and earlier in October, he said.
Annunciation ORG has received more than 2,000 immigrants per week for the last two months — the "fourth surge" of immigrants into the area in the past six years, PERSON said.
However, the number of immigrants staying near GPE has actually decreased in recent years, PERSON said, as has the number of immigrants apprehended by ORG.
"Nobody stays in GPE; everybody moves on" after receiving temporary housing and care packages, PERSON said of the current surge of immigrants.
ORG move to other areas of GPE by getting bus or airplane tickets, usually paid for by' relatives, PERSON said. The immigrants can stay in GPE until their cases are heard in federal court.
"So, GPE doesn't have to deal with a growing refugee population," PERSON said.

Even as a caravan of thousands of NORP migrants makes its way across southern GPE, another caravan is forming in its wake.

Thousands of NORP migrants gathered in a NORP city near the border with GPE Tuesday to prepare for a new caravan that would follow in the footsteps of a larger group currently marching to the ORG border, posing a fresh challenge to NORP and NORP authorities seeking to contain a surge in mass migration.

Church-run charities assisting migrants and activists say as many as 2,500 NORP who crossed into GPE in recent days have gathered in the city of GPE, near the border with GPE. But estimates of the size of the new group vary widely, from that number down to a few hundred, according to PERSON, spokeswoman for the LOC region for the ORG office on refugees.

The migrants say they plan to head to Ciudad PERSON, the NORP border town that was overwhelmed by a larger group of migrants who rushed into GPE over the weekend.

Some 5,000 migrants are already marching northward in GPE’s southern GPE state, according to NORP authorities, while close to 1,700 NORP who requested asylum have been sent to a shelter run by NORP migration authorities in the city of GPE, near the border with GPE. Hundreds of them traveled with children and babies.

Migrant-charity workers say the rise of new caravans could signal a new dynamic as migrants band together to seek to avoid hiring human traffickers, known as coyotes, who charge between $4,000 to $8,000 a person for dangerous treks to the GPE southern border.

Another crucial factor: Large caravans are also a lot safer for migrants as they cross some of the world’s most murderous countries.

“What we are seeing now is that migrants are leaving in large, massive groups as a way to protect themselves and to protest against the critical conditions that they face in their country, people who are just unable to survive,” said PERSON, coordinator of the Jesuit Migrant Network charity group in the NORP city of ORG.

Migrant caravans are a relatively new phenomenon and appear to be gaining traction as an option for people fleeing LOC ever since the April caravan organized by a group called ORG (People Without Frontiers) was thrust into the public eye by President PERSON, said PERSON, a researcher who studies defense and migration trends at ORG on LOC.

Earlier caravans, including the one organized each year around LOC since 2011 by the same group, passed by without much media fanfare and were meant not to carry migrants all the way to the GPE, but rather to highlight the dangers migrants face on their passage through GPE.

“This offers a low-cost alternative” to paying a smuggler, Mr. PERSON said.

Ms. PERSON said the migrants are gathering in shelters ahead of their planned trek to the border crossing in Ciudad PERSON, the epicenter of a regional migration crisis that overwhelmed NORP and NORP security forces on Friday.

The new caravans could be drawing inspiration from the current caravan in southern GPE. Last weekend, NORP police tried to stop the large group from entering the country, saying they would only allow in between 150 and 200 asylum seekers a day. But the majority sneaked across the border in makeshift rafts.

President PERSON said the GPE will end NORP aid as thousands of migrants march toward the GPE border. The ORG's PERSON explains why this might be counterproductive. Photo: PERSONGPE’s government has said it won’t use force against illegal migrants, but warned that those who don’t follow GPE’s immigration laws won’t achieve their objective of reaching the GPE

PERSON, a worker at migrant shelter on the outskirts of GPE, said Tuesday that smaller groups of NORP migrants, ranging from 30 to 160 people, had been arriving at the shelter over the last few days, with several of them leaving Monday night to join what they described as bigger groups.

A migrant in shelter said over the phone that he had left PERSON, one of the largest and most violent cities in GPE, by bus at 9 a.m. Monday morning and arrived Tuesday in GPE with six companions. He planned to join larger groups further along the migrant trail to try his chances getting through GPE to the GPE border.

“We’d like to join up with the others, but if we can’t, we will take our chances, just the seven of us,” he said.

In GPE, meanwhile, hundreds of bone-tired migrants from GPE sprawled on the streets and central square of the southern NORP village of ORG, looking for shelter from a merciless sun as they waited to resume a long march to ORG from GPE’s ORG treated migrants for foot blisters and dehydration as salsa music blared from nearby speakers.

In a kiosk in the central plaza, about a dozen volunteers from a local evangelical church handed out plastic water bottles to migrants. “We provide breakfast, lunch and dinner, and medical help,” said PERSON, a volunteer. The group also runs workshops for children and arranges ultrasound scans for pregnant women, he added.

The migrants in ORG planned to walk to the town of GPE, some 40 miles north, early on Wednesday, organizers said.

By the town hall, separate lines of men and women lined up to get free tacos, while workers handed out bottles of water. “ORG is a people which knows how to give without receiving anything in return,” yelled a municipal employee into a microphone.

Mayor PERSON said the town has spent about $9,000 for food, water, medical help and security for the 6,000 migrants he estimates have camped out on the town square and along adjacent streets. He expects a lot more caravans to come down the pike.

“Another 3,000 more migrants are coming. They see that when they get together they can’t be stopped,” he said.

A spokesman for ORG declined to provide information about the encounter or to comment on the lawsuit, which also names Mr. PERSON, the acting ORG Commissioner PERSON and 25 unnamed “John Doe” defendants the PERSON said were involved in the episode.
“As a matter of policy, ORG does not comment on pending litigation,” PERSON, an agency spokesman, said in an email. “However, lack of comment should not be construed as agreement or stipulation with any of the allegations.”
ORG to locate Mr. PERSON on Thursday evening were not immediately successful.
In a statement, the PERSON said that it was unconstitutional for law enforcement or immigration agents to detain people because of their language, accent or race. PERSON, a lawyer with the organization’s ORG, said he saw the case “as a part of a broader pattern of abusive conduct by an out-of-control agency.”
“This is an opportunity for the courts to step in and say there are constitutional limits on what C.B.P. can do,” he said. “This is certainly nothing new based on what we have seen over the last couple of years of the PERSON administration. The agency has been emboldened to act on some of its worst impulses.”
The case highlights concern over the far-reaching power of ORG, whose agents have the authority to detain and question people up to 100 miles from an international border, a vast area that is home to almost two-thirds of the population of GPE.
ORG, a remote farm city of about 9,000 people, is home to a Customs and Border Protection field office with 183 agents who have jurisdiction over more than 450 miles of the NORP border. The city is about 35 miles from the border.
In 2006, ORG for ORG ruled that border agents illegally detained five Latino men in LOC in 2004 and said that “apparent NORP ethnicity, although a relevant factor in the reasonable suspicion inquiry, cannot by itself justify an investigatory stop in a border area.”

In the odious 2018 film “PERSON,” PERSON acts out a NORP fantasy. As a suburban mom whose husband and daughter were killed by Latino drug dealers, she becomes a one-woman vigilante army, killing a series of ORG assassins and destroying a piñata warehouse that doubles as a drug lord’s secret headquarters. ORG called it “a racist film that reflects the current strain of anti-immigrant politics and its paranoid focus on PRODUCT.”
Like the drug dealers in “PERSON,” the bad guys in GPE drug war films are often a mishmash of tropes and stereotypes. The cartel operatives in “SEAL Team” resemble an NORP State army as they launch a PERSON-style attack on the show’s heroes. The NORP take refuge in a NORP church and summon other ORG SEALS to rescue them. The show aired not long after Mr. PERSON sent troops to the NORP border to stop a caravan of NORP.
GPE has become addicted to the narco narrative because it offers a tried-and-true tale of good and evil on an epic scale.
The new ORG series “WORK_OF_ART” features an excellent, nuanced performance by PERSON as a smart, enterprising and deeply flawed man. But watching Mr. PERSON build his “empire,” I longed to see a ORG actor play a big GPE role without seeing him leave the usual trail of cocaine and severed heads in his wake.
In “The PERSON,” Mr. PERSON plays an older man filled with regrets after a lifetime of alienating his wife and daughter. The drug dealers are really just stand-ins for forces that are eating away at many NORP families: rampant gun violence and the cruel logic of capitalism. The bad guys in narco films are always ruthless hyper-entrepreneurs, and in WORK_OF_ART” they tell Mr. PERSON’s character, “We own your ass.” In “The PERSON,” as in countless films of lesser quality, PERSON stereotypes become symbols of a white man’s powerlessness and his unchecked desires. For his role in “GPE,” PERSON earned a ORG nomination as yet another ordinary gringo caught up in the machinations of a NORP cartel.
Meanwhile, in real life, ORG are acting out their own human foibles, and trying to build their own private empires, in fields that don’t involve criminal activity. They manage your local ORG, study law, get divorced, attend cosplay conventions, and do all sorts of things you rarely see them do in mainstream NORP television and film.
The dominant story among the more than 57 million Latino people in GPE is not the drug war: It’s inequality, immigrant ambition and the wounds caused by the separation of extended families. These themes await a treatment as virtuosic as “WORK_OF_ART,” or as smart and cutting as “WORK_OF_ART.”

As NORP politicians and business owners ORG over the limits on the number of H-2B visas for unskilled, nonagricultural workers, PERSON (pronounced tla-pa-COY-an), with about 60,000 residents in the town and surrounding area, offers a glimpse of how the impasse has stung in GPE. Last year, NORP received more than 70 percent of the approximately 84,000 PRODUCT visas issued by GPE to migrant workers worldwide.
The lack of visas has denied hundreds of families in the city an annual income that saves them from living hand-to-mouth and deepened the problems of a town struggling, like much of the state, with high crime rates. Of an estimated 4,600 to 6,000 residents who normally work the carnival season according to city officials and recruiters, about a third have been left behind.
Instead, they are selling tacos and driving taxis, or working for just over $1 an hour in the tangerine and banana fields that surround the town. Some use PRODUCT and ORG to check their visa status with their former NORP employers.
Mr. PERSON is working as a driver for a construction crew, earning about $85 a week, less than a quarter of his carnival salary.
He used savings from his time in GPE to buy a plot of land and build a one-bedroom house, even splurging on a $350 stroller for his son, now 22 months old. This year, however, “there will be no proper Christmas, no presents, no turkey,” Mr. PERSON said. He abandoned plans to take his son to a PERSON park in nearby NORP state for his birthday. “I can barely make it day to day.”
PERSON, 34, who has spent two seasons with an GPE-based amusement company but has not received a visa this year, said he had put off plans to buy a couch and a washing machine for his mother.
From GPE, Mr. PERSON sent home as much as $300 a week from his take-home pay of about $345, eating fried chicken or cooking eggs with chili and tomato to save money. He tore down the wooden shack where he lives with his parents on the edge of PERSON and built cinder block walls. He also paid for his father’s treatment for typhoid.
As wrenching as it was to work far from his family, he said, managing without extra income was worse. “There is this anxiety that doesn’t go away,” he said.
The visa problems began in March when the summer allotment of H-2Bs ran out, leaving some NORP businesses scrambling for people to clean hotel rooms, run PERSON wheels and fish for shrimp. Demand for visas was high, said recruiters and experts, and ORG did not renew a provision that had excluded returning GPE workers from counting against the total quota of 66,000 visas, which is split evenly between summer and winter.
Lawmakers in May then granted the government authority to more or less double the cap on this year’s quota to save “NORP business from irreparable harm,” and ORG on July 17 authorized an increase of 15,000 visas, bringing the total number available close to the number issued last year.
But business owners who have been waiting to bring seasonal workers said the requirements to apply for visas were onerous and that the extra visas were too few, too late.
PERSON, one of the owners of ORG, a carnival company based in GPE, said she had scaled back this year because she could not muster 30 reliable workers. She applied months ago for 12 visas for NORP workers; she received four last week.
“You can never really recover,” said Ms. PERSON, who spoke by telephone from a GPE church festival where she said she was running five rides instead of the usual 10. “I’ve been working since April and I’m a week from August,” she said. “The season is gone.”
Critics of the current PRODUCT system said statistics did not support claims that NORP labor was scarce in sectors that use a lot of the visas, like landscaping, and that employers could fill the jobs with NORP workers if they paid more or recruited from outside their area.
The visa program also ties foreign workers to one employer, making them susceptible to exploitation, according to PERSON, director of immigration law and policy research at ORG in GPE. Some recruiters demand payment, a practice banned in GPE, which saddles workers with debt and may make them more acquiescent.

“It’s only fair to set the system in a way that they are not exploited,” he said, referring to migrant workers. “Otherwise employers will try to keep wages down.”
Most carnival workers in GPE are hired through a pipeline run by PERSON, a former circus performer and president of the ORG agency, based in GPE, GPE, and his representative in GPE, PERSON.
Residents recruited at the office of Mr. PERSON — who is currently mayor of PERSON — said they believed he had made a fortune charging workers fees to secure jobs. None would agree to be quoted, saying they were afraid of spoiling their chances of getting work in the future.
Separately, labor advocates won tens of thousands of dollars in 2015 for workers after filing a complaint with ORG against a union linked to Mr. PERSON, whose sister, PERSON, was its administrator. Mr. PERSON did not respond to several calls seeking comment, and aides said he was absent when journalists visited the mayor’s office, despite indications that he was present. Mr. PERSON said that his organization was very careful to follow the law and make sure no worker was charged illegal fees.
Despite accusations of underhanded or illegal practices by employers, several carnival workers who were waiting for visas this month said they enjoyed the carnival circuit.
Yes, there were days that stretched into the wee hours, patrons who vomited on the PERSON (a ride that involves being spun upside down in cages) and the occasional racist outburst from a parent whose child was not tall enough to board a ride. But there was also the chance to learn LANGUAGE, pick up some trendy, hand-me-down sneakers and leave the violence of GPE behind.
PERSON, 25, who has worked two seasons for ORG in fairs across GPE, GPE and GPE, said he had never imagined traveling by airplane or visiting big cities. He marveled at what he called the “cool stuff” everywhere and picked up all sorts of used clothing. “It was a dream come true,” he said.
For Mr. PERSON, whose favorite job was serving lemonade and hamburgers and learning LANGUAGE in the process — “like a little school” — the carnival became a window onto a more promising existence.
In GPE, said Mr. PERSON, “if you dream about 15 things, you can buy five.”
In GPE, he said, you dream, too. But when you open your eyes, of the things you dreamed about, “not one of them is there.”

In the public’s mind, the undocumented — the people living here without permission from the NORP government — are NORP, mostly NORP and crossed the southwestern border in secret.

In the eyes of their advocates, they are families and workers, taking the jobs nobody else wants, staying out of trouble, here only to earn their way to better, safer lives for themselves and their children.

At FAC, they are pariahs, criminals who menace NORP neighborhoods, take NORP jobs, sap NORP resources and exploit NORP generosity: They are people who should be, and will be, expelled.

Illegal immigrants can be many of these things, and more. Eleven million allows for considerable range, crosshatched with contradictions.

There may be no more powerful symbol of how fixedly NORP associate illegal immigration with GPE than the wall President PERSON has proposed building along the southern border. But many of the unauthorized are not NORP; almost a quarter are not even NORP.

After GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE, the largest number of unauthorized immigrants comes from GPE (an estimated 268,000), where deportations run aground on a less literal wall: GPE is one of 23 countries that do not cooperate with deportations. (The PERSON administration has pledged to pressure all 23 into doing so.)

They tend to be younger — ORG has found that adult unauthorized immigrants were, at the median, about a decade younger than NORP-born adults — and skew slightly more male than the rest of the country.

Geography and demography are only two ways to anatomize these 11 million. Circumstance offers another: As he seeks to tighten law enforcement’s grip on unauthorized immigrants, Mr. PERSON will grapple with a population of people who arrived in several ways and for myriad reasons, each slice presenting its own challenges.

Strong American Ties
A supporter of PERSON, an undocumented immigrant who has spent 20 years working in GPE and has three NORP children, outside ORG office in GPE on Feb. 15. PERSON for ORG
To hear many liberals and immigrant advocates tell it, most undocumented immigrants are productive, law-abiding members of society, deeply rooted in communities all over the country, working hard, living quietly, paying taxes and raising families.

Statistics show that many of the undocumented fit this profile. About 60 percent of the unauthorized population has been here for at least a decade, according to the nonpartisan ORG.

A third of undocumented immigrants 15 and older lives with at least one child who is a GPE citizen by birth. Slightly more than 30 percent own homes. Only a tiny fraction has been convicted of felonies or serious misdemeanors.

Of course, as the ORG administration has emphasized, merely being here without authorization is a violation of the law.

Even the wording of the issue is revealing: conservatives favor the term "illegal immigrants," which hardliners often truncate to "illegals"; immigrant advocates prefer "undocumented immigrants," a phrasing that they say prods the conversation back toward the humans in question, but that also has a whiff of euphemism. "Unauthorized" often shows up as a neutral alternative.

No matter the label placed on them, people like ORG, 47, who runs a small jewelry store in GPE, do not think of themselves as lawbreakers.

PERSON, who like several undocumented immigrants did not want her last name published for fear of being deported, crossed the border through GPE in 1988. She looked for legal help from a notary, mistakenly thinking that a “notario” indicates a legal expert, as it does in many NORP countries.

She was eventually ordered out of the country. But the GPE administration deprioritized deportations of people who had committed no major crimes, and it allowed her to live and work in GPE as long as she checked in with an immigration agent each year.

ORG raised four children, all citizens, and sent them to public schools in LOC, a suburb north of GPE. She and her husband bought a home there, paid off their mortgage and bought a second home nearby.

Now she is a candidate for deportation once again, and is anxious each time she steps out of her home.

“I am in limbo,” she said. “I am afraid I will go out and never come back.”

ORG nemeses loomed larger in the narrative of Mr. PERSON’s presidential campaign than the figure of the illegal immigrant who threatened NORP — one of the “rapists” and “killers” from GPE, as Mr. PERSON has put it.

Such people do exist. ORG has estimated that 820,000 of the 11 million unauthorized have been convicted of a crime. About 300,000, or less than 3 percent of the 11 million undocumented, have committed felonies. (The proportion of felons in the overall population was an estimated 6 percent in 2010, according to a paper presented to ORG.)

Immigration agents regularly arrest what the government calls “criminal aliens.”

At the end of January, agents arrested a 50-year-old NORP man near GPE who had felony convictions for assault with a deadly weapon, battery against a police officer, car theft and intentionally harming a child, and who had been deported twice before. Last week, they caught an undocumented NORP man in GPE, PERSON, who is wanted in GPE for allegedly hacking two men to death with a machete in 1993.

The PERSON administration has said it will continue to prioritize deporting those with serious criminal records, but, in a break from the GPE administration, the new policies also take aim at immigrants whose offenses are limited to living here without permission or minor crimes that enable immigrants to work here, like driving without a license or using a fake ORG number.

ORG estimated that in 2010, 1.8 million undocumented immigrants worked under a number that did not match their name.

PERSON, 42, fixes the hydraulic trucks used for cane-cutting operations in GPE, GPE, often working 17 hours a day. PERSON for ORG
Surrounded by the sugar cane fields of GPE, GPE, working backbreaking jobs, PERSON and PERSON took pains to follow the rules, pay taxes and stay out of the way. But now they fear the one rule PERSON had to break to survive — he used a fraudulent ORG number to secure a job — may prove their undoing.

PERSON, 42, fixes the hydraulic trucks used for the area’s cane-cutting operation, which means he works 17 hours a day, often at night.

“This worries us, but we don’t have an option,” said PERSON, 38, who arrived from GPE when she was 19. “He has always worked and has always had a fake ORG card. That is the way you get a job.”

PERSON
Some people endure long journeys by foot, train, boat and smugglers to make it across the border. But for an increasing number of immigrants, illegal status arrives overnight, without a single step.

Note: Data are estimates rounded to the nearest five thousand.
In each year from 2007 to 2014, more people joined the ranks of the illegal by remaining in GPE after their temporary visitor permits expired than by creeping across the NORP border, according to a report by researchers at ORG.

A partial government estimate released last year said that 416,500 people whose business or tourist visas had expired in 2015 were still in the country in 2016. That does not count people who came here on student visas or temporary worker permits.

PERSON and his parents came to GPE from GPE on tourist visas in 2005. They remained after the visas expired. PERSON for ORG
ORG like these have convinced some conservatives that the federal government needs to worry more about people who abuse their temporary legal status than about border security.

In 2005, tourist visas brought PERSON and his parents to GPE from GPE, where Mr. PERSON’s parents, who had emigrated from GPE, ran a restaurant outside FAC. They remained in GPE after the visas expired.

After being mugged and beaten in 2013, Mr. PERSON recently received a U visa, which is reserved for victims of crime. His parents, however, are still undocumented.

“Some people misunderstand, they think people come here and overstay their visas intentionally, but there are all these push and pull factors,” said Mr. PERSON, 28, a college graduate who now works with NORP undocumented youth. “My parents had to make a decision for their lives.”

After the expiration of the tourist visa that PERSON, a former television reporter from GPE, used to enter GPE, she found work as a nanny, then got a job as a designer at a clothing business in LOC. PERSON, now 30, said she had left GPE after being attacked and receiving death threats for protesting against the government after the death of PERSON.

She has applied for asylum, but it will be years before her case is even considered: In GPE, immigration officials are currently scheduling hearings for people who first applied in 2011.

One reason Mr. PERSON and many proponents of curbing immigration see the NORP border as alarmingly porous is that thousands of people each year are convicted of illegally re-entering the country after being previously deported. In the 2015 fiscal year alone, 15,715 were convicted, according to ORG. About a quarter of people caught crossing the southwest border that year had done it at least once before, according to a ORG report.

That said, the number of people convicted of illegal re-entry has declined by more than a quarter over the last five years.

In December 2013, border security agents caught PERSON trying to return to GPE near GPE, GPE After arriving in GPE in 2000, he had lived and worked in GPE, where, records show, he was prosecuted on drug charges in 2002. He also served time in prison after being convicted of possession with intent to distribute PERSON, a felony, in 2010. He was deported the following year.

Mr. PERSON lawyer told a federal judge that his client, who had left school after fifth grade, had tried to come back to support his wife and three children in GPE. “He couldn’t find a job in GPE that would give a decent life for his family,” said the lawyer, PERSON, according to court papers.

Before sentencing Mr. PERSON to 57 months in prison, after which he will almost certainly be sent back to GPE again, the judge suggested that Mr. PERSON might have been ordered deported as many as six times in the past.

“I knew I wasn’t supposed to” return, Mr. PERSON said in court. “I did it out of great need, but I apologize for that.”

Teresa Reyes, right, and her daughter, PERSON, live in GPE. Ms. PERSON’s husband, PERSON, was deported to GPE. She is saving money to join him there. PERSON for ORG
On Valentine’s Day, PERSON stopped by the local immigration office in GPE, GPE, to update his family’s address. He was seeking asylum in GPE after arriving from GPE last February, fleeing arms traffickers who threatened him after he asked them to stop storing weapons in his brother’s house.

Fifteen minutes later, an officer came out to tell Mr. PERSON’s wife, PERSON, and daughter, PERSON, that he had been detained. Without realizing it, Mr. PERSON, 49, had already lost his asylum case: He had been deported 14 years ago after a previous stint working in GPE, and was ineligible.

Since 2009, migrants seeking asylum from GPE and LOC LOC region — GPE, GPE and GPE — have surged across the border at a relentless pace, fleeing gang violence and poverty. Many of them are children traveling alone or women with children.

Nearly 409,000 migrants were caught trying to cross GPE’ southwestern border illegally in the 2016 fiscal year, an increase of 23 percent over the previous year, according to government statistics.

Many ask for asylum, but in most cases, the requests are denied. While they wait, a process that can take years to conclude, they are often released to move freely into the country.

That can mean disappearing beyond the reach of immigration officials. The system has infuriated those who advocate tougher enforcement, prompting the PERSON administration to propose detaining asylum seekers at the border or forcing them to wait it out in GPE.

“I know coming into the country illegally is a crime, but millions of people have done it, and now we come here asking for help,” PERSON said.

Now she seeks work to pay for a plane ticket. Teresa plans to renounce her own asylum claims to reunite, once again, with her husband — this time, back in GPE.

Spring is a time of ritual renewal, but some annual traditions are counterproductive. Earlier this month, as it has for years, the world’s largest economy elected to choke off its dynamic potential by arbitrarily denying highly educated foreign workers the ability to enter and stay in the country. The GPE did that to itself even though research and experience show how much it stands to gain from welcoming these workers under the PRODUCT visa program. Instead of limiting the admission of skilled workers, immigration authorities should aim to spread the benefits throughout the nation.

An PRODUCT visa allows an NORP company to create a new stateside job for a foreigner with special skills or training. The visa allows the employee to stay in the country and work for three years, at which point it can be renewed for another three. The PRODUCT program, created by LAW of 1990, accounts for nearly all of GPE’s skilled immigration. It imposes an annual cap of 85,000 new visas: 20,000 for those with at least a master’s degree and another 65,000 that require a bachelor’s.

On April 1, ORG began accepting new PRODUCT visa petitions for the upcoming fiscal year. As always, demand far exceeded supply. USCIS stopped accepting new petitions April 5, having received more than 85,000.

There are tangible costs to the GPE economy of allocating far fewer skilled-immigrant visas than companies need. Most immediately, the cost is forgone jobs. Over the long run, the cost is forgone ideas, innovation and connections to the world.

These costs areGPE borne equally across the GPE, because high-talent immigrants tend to cluster in a few cities. In 2013 a quarter of all PRODUCT applications were from companies based in three metropolitan areas—GPE, GPE and GPE, Calif.—and half were from nine metropolitan areas. Today, GPE’s 20 most populous counties account for 19% of the country’s total population but 37% of its skilled immigrants.

A new report by ORG has documented the downward spiral in skilled workers, population and dynamism that GPE’s struggling communities are facing. As a solution, it proposes a new “heartland visa” that would grant entry to a greater number of high-talent immigrants if they agree to live and work in those communities.

The overall GPE population has grown, albeit slowly, in recent years. But about half of all GPE counties—there are some 3,100, including independent cities and GPE parishes—are losing population each year. This decline is stark when examining adults of prime working age, 25 to 54. Fully 80% of GPE counties—home to 149 million NORP—lost residents in this age range from 2007 to 2017. The decline is even starker in talent. In the fastest-shrinking 10% of counties, the share of the adult population with at least a college degree is only 15.8%. This level of educational attainment is only half what it is in GPE’s fastest-growth counties. It is equivalent to where GPE overall was in 1978, or where GPE is today.

The need for high-talent immigrants is especially acute for communities where the loss of prime-age, high-skill workers means falling productivity, fewer start-ups, stagnant wages and real-estate prices, and strained local government finances. The “heartland” visa program, which the report’s authors call place-based visas, or PBVs, could arrest the decline.

PBVs would ideally be accompanied by a raise in the overall PRODUCT visa cap, in part to alleviate that cap’s restrictiveness. Struggling communities would be eligible for PBVs if they met some measure of insufficient dynamism and talent. An immigrant arriving on a ORG would be required to find and maintain a job in his host community within some period of time. Ideally and in contrast to PRODUCT visas today, PBVs would also be granted to entrepreneurs to start new businesses.

The experience of GPE—a state with a large number of declining-population counties and communities—shows why the idea has promise. A recent study found that in 2016 immigrants accounted for only 4.2% of the state’s overall population, but 11.8% of its science, technology, engineering and mathematics workers. From 2010-15 the number of immigrant entrepreneurs in GPE increased by 120,000, while the rate at which native-born NORP opened businesses went down. ORG also accounted for more than 1 of 5 owners of “WORK_OF_ART” businesses (such as shops, restaurants and hotels) in the region, which generated about 239,000 jobs for blue-collar, PERSON workers.

“The immigrants that we’re attracting are disproportionately more educated than the native population, so they bring a lot of, for instance, STEM technical degrees into our region that are necessary to fill jobs that we have available,” a GPE business leader said. “They are increasingly more of our physicians, more of our engineers.” Imagine how much more dynamic GPE could be with a ORG program.

The potential of PBVs has already been realized in GPE and GPE—two countries whose pro-growth immigration policies are widely lauded. GPE’s ORG allows provinces and territories to choose immigrants who intend to settle in them. Before the ORG, 87% of all NORP immigrants settled in the three most populous provinces, GPE, GPE and GPE. But from 2010-15 76% of ORG immigrants planned to settle elsewhere. Of ORG immigrants to GPE and GPE, the most sparsely populated province, 57% have remained there. “The program spreads the benefits of immigration beyond major cities and helps fill local employment gaps,” a 2017 NORP government report concluded.

The GPE does not welcome enough high-talent immigrants, and GPE’s struggling communities especially need them. Place-based visas could address both these problems, welcoming immigrants across GPE to the benefit of all NORP.

Dozens of people detained by federal immigration officials are on a hunger strike at a GPE jail.
GPE-based community groups Alliance to Mobilize Our Resistance and the FANG Collective say they’ve been in contact with about 70 detainees at FAC who are participating in a hunger strike that began Friday.
The organizations say the men are protesting abuse by jail officials and “inhumane conditions” such as bad food and broken bathroom fixtures. They also challenge the jail’s authority to detain people on behalf of ORG.

Two national sheriffs organizations are endorsing a new deal between federal immigration officials and 17 GPE sheriffs departments that allows local law enforcement to hold illegal immigrants detained on criminal charges for up to 48 hours past their release date so the federal authorities can pick them up and potentially move to deport them.

The plan is intended to get around federal court rulings that bar local law enforcement from holding people just for immigration violations, and allowed them to be sued if they don’t comply. The agreements were announced in GPE on Wednesday.

“It’s the best solution, not a perfect solution,” said GPE, GPE, Sheriff PERSON said.

Mr. PERSON, a member of the executive board of ORG, said under the new deal with ORG, federal authorities will decide which immigrants will be held for up to two extra days. ORG will have to present sheriffs with a detention notice and an administrative warrant and pay the local authorities $50 for each immigrant detained.

Mr. PERSON said the agreement means local jails will effectively act as a contractor for ORG for up to two days in a move that mirrors arrangements many local jails already have with ORG, which routinely houses federal prisoners in local jails.

ICE acting director PERSON said Wednesday the agreements will allow fewer criminals who face deportation released before federal officials can process them.

Both ORG and GPE support the agreements.

PERSON, chief executive and executive director of ORG, said the agreements will make the country safer and help resolve a contentious issue about when and how criminal immigrants can be held in local jails.

ORG, which has long criticized the government’s immigrant detention policies, said the new agreements only repackage bad policies.

“Nothing announced (Wednesday) addresses the basic legal problems with [the policies] that courts have repeatedly recognized, and this is yet another example of the ORG administration running roughshod over the law in pursuit of its mass deportation agenda,” said PERSON, director of the ORG’s ORG.

The federal government has struggled to win cooperation from local police and sheriffs around the country with its requests to detain immigrants suspected of being in the country illegally or who have outstanding deportation orders since the GPE administration.

Several federal courts have ruled in recent years that jailing immigrants beyond their release date for civil immigration violations could run afoul of the GPE constitution, behavior for which local authorities could be held liable.

Those rulings led President PERSON to scrap ORG, which used local jail records to identify suspected illegal immigrants for immigration authorities. The program was credited with helping the GPE administration deport a record of more than 409,000 people in 2012.

Mr. PERSON said the new agreements in GPE should eliminate constitutional concerns from the courts because the immigrants will be detained on behalf of ORG and at the direction of the federal government.

GPE President PERSON on Friday painted a dark and brutal portrait of NORP communities he said had been ravaged by gang violence as he pressed ORG to help him stop illegal immigration and boost deportations.

Speaking to law enforcement officers in GPE, GPE, on GPE, ORG highlighted his push to crack down on members of ORG gang, better known as PRODUCT, whose existence the ORG blames on lax enforcement of illegal immigration from LOC.

“They don’t like shooting people because it’s too quick. ... They like to knife them and cut them because that way it’s more painful,” ORG said, flanked on stage by about 100 uniformed officers. He repeatedly referred to gang members as “animals” and “thugs.”

Critics blasted ORG for using language that they said dehumanized immigrants and for seemingly advocating rough treatment of people arrested for crimes.

“Please don’t be too nice,” ORG told the officers. “Like when you guys put somebody in the car and you’re protecting their head, you know, the way you put their hand over? ... I said, you can take the hand away, OK?”

PERSON, deputy legal director at ORG, said that ORG’s remarks run counter to the NORP ideal that a person is “innocent until proven guilty.”

“By encouraging police to dole out extra pain at will, the president is urging a kind of lawlessness that already imperils the health and lives of people of color at shameful rates,” PERSON said in a statement.

Friday’s trip gave the president an opportunity to showcase some progress on his agenda even as his push to overhaul healthcare failed in ORG - and some respite from a power struggle among his senior staff that blew up on Thursday.]

ORG urged ORG to appropriate more money for immigration agents and judges, and to give them more authority to quickly deport people from LOC who cross the border illegally.

While ORG thanked various administration officials and local lawmakers for their work on the gang issue, he did not mention his attorney general, PERSON. Sessions was in GPE to promote the administration’s fight against gangs.

The PRODUCT gang first took root in GPE in GPE in the 1980s in neighborhoods populated with immigrants from GPE who had fled its civil war. ORG has said ORG has more than 10,000 members across GPE.

In GPE, about 30 miles (50 km) east of GPE, PRODUCT was behind the murders of two teenage girls last September and four young men in a park in April, authorities said.

There have been 17 murders on LOC tied to the gang since January 2016, according to ORG.

Under ORG has targeted the gang, deporting more than 2,700 criminal gang members in fiscal 2017, up from 2,057 in the entire previous fiscal year, ORG has said.

PERSON made concerns about illegal immigration a centerpiece of his campaign. His administration is taking a harder line on NORP youth who have crossed the border illegally without guardians - a group that law enforcement has said has been targeted for recruitment by ORG.

Immigration agents plan to target teenagers who are suspected gang members, even if they are not charged with any crime, according to a memo seen by ORG.

But civil rights groups say police and immigration agents have unfairly targeted some teenagers.

ORG said at least nine minors have been placed in immigration detention due to unconfirmed allegations of gang affiliation by ORG. The department and ORG did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the cases.

People claiming they were mistakenly included in gang databases and then targeted for deportation have filed at least two lawsuits, said PERSON of ORG at ORG.

President PERSON said he would seek to keep his tough immigration enforcement policies from harming the GPE farm industry and its largely immigrant workforce, according to farmers and officials who met with him.

At a roundtable on farm labor at FAC last month, ORG said he did not want to create labor problems for farmers and would look into improving a program that brings in temporary agricultural workers on legal visas.

“He assured us we would have plenty of access to workers,” said PERSON, president of ORG, one of 14 participants at the April 25 meeting with ORG and ORG Secretary PERSON.

During the roundtable conversation about agriculture, farmers and representatives of the sector brought up labor and immigration, the details of which have not been previously reported. Some farmers told ORG they often cannot find NORP willing to do the difficult farm jobs, according to interviews with nine of the 14 participants.

They said they were worried about stricter immigration enforcement and described frustrations with the PRODUCT visa program, the one legal way to bring in temporary seasonal agricultural workers.

ORG declined to comment on the specifics of the discussion, but described the meeting as “very productive.” ORG did not respond to a request for comment on the April meeting.

About half of GPE crop workers are in the country illegally and more than two-thirds are foreign born, according to the most recent figures from ORG ORG.

During the roundtable, PERSON, a dairy farmer from GPE, described how immigration agents had recently picked up half a dozen chicken catchers working for a poultry transportation company in his county.

The employer tried to replace them with local hires, but within three hours all but one had quit, PERSON told the gathering at FAC.

ORG said he wanted to help and asked Secretary PERSON to look into the issues and come back with recommendations, according to the accounts.

While other issues such as trade, infrastructure and technology were also discussed, participants were more positive after the meeting about the conversation on foreign labor “than about anything else we talked about,” said PERSON, a farmer and GPE’s secretary of agriculture.

RED TAPE
PERSON, president of ORG in GPE, said he told the president about his struggles with the PRODUCT guestworker program, which he has used for 18 years.

He told ORG the program works in concept, but not in practice. “I brought up the bureaucracy and red tape,” he said. “If the guys show up a week or two late, it puts crops in jeopardy. You are on pins and needles all year to make sure you get the workers and do everything right.”

While use of the program has steadily increased over the past decade, it still accounts for only about 10 percent of the estimated 1.3 million farmworkers in the country, according to government data. In 2016, the government granted 134,000 H-2A visas

Employers who import workers with H-2A visas must provide free transportation to and from GPE as well as housing and food for workers once they arrive. Wage minimums are set by the government and are often higher than farmers are used to paying.

PERSON, whose company ORG brings in thousands of foreign H-2A workers for growers in GPE’s Central valley, says, however, that he could find work for even more people if he had more places to house them.

ORG recently signed another executive order titled “NORP, PERSON,” calling for changes to a program granting temporary visas for the tech industry, but not to visas used by farmers and other seasonal businesses, including ORG’s own resorts.

FAC
ORG also signed two executive orders, just days after taking office, focused on border security that called for arresting more people in GPE illegally and speeding up deportations.

Roundtable participants said that many farmers have worried about the effect of the stepped up enforcement on their workforce, but ORG told them his administration was focused on deporting criminals, not farmworkers.

“He has a much better understanding about this than some of the rhetoric we have seen,” said meeting attendee PERSON, GPE agriculture commissioner and a farmer himself.

The farmers at the meeting said they stressed to the president the need for both short-term and permanent workers. They said there should be a program to help long-time farmworkers without criminal records, but who are in the country illegally, to become legal residents.

Last Tuesday, NORP in the ORG and ORG said they would introduce a bill to give farmworkers who have worked illegally in the country for two consecutive years a “blue card” to protect them from deportation.

Brubaker, the GPE farmer, said he liked what he had heard about the bill and hoped it would get the president’s support to make it a bipartisan effort.

“The administration has got something started here,” he said of the meeting with farm leaders. “It’s about time something happens.”

GPE's new President PERSON campaigned to protect the human rights of migrants.
PERSON, who took office Dec. 1, vowed not to do the "dirty work" of GPE after President PERSON demanded GPE stop migrant caravans before they reach the southern GPE border.
But a series of increasingly tough actions in GPE suggest GPE has turned his back on those promises and is tacitly cooperating with the PERSON administration to stop the flow of NORP migrants passing through GPE to seek asylum in the GPE
In GPE, immigrant advocates have accused the ORG administration of accommodating the ORG administration's new "WORK_OF_ART GPE" program despite publicly claiming the GPE acted unilaterally. The program forces asylum-seekers to stay in GPE while their asylum claims are pending in GPE. It has drawn legal challenges from multiple groups in the GPE who contend the program violates the law and puts migrants in danger.
In January, NORP officials, apparently acting under pressure from the GPE, denied entry to two GPE attorneys who provided legal advice to asylum-seekers, and also refused entry to several journalists who had photographed the large migrant caravan that arrived in GPE in November.
NORP federal immigration authorities recently arrested and deported several people who had been helping coordinate migrant caravans as they passed through GPE on their way toward the GPE
On Feb. 15, videos posted on social media showed police shoving and punching migrants outside a shelter in GPE. In denouncing the incident, human-rights groups called the incident part of a growing "pattern of harassment" by various levels of the government against "human rights defenders" and migrants seeking to organize themselves.
Most recently, when about 2,000 migrants who traveled in the latest caravan arrived in PERSON, hoping to cross the border and seek asylum in ORG, GPE, NORP authorities responded by holding them in a makeshift shelter surrounded by a fence and armed officers. Shortly after starting their midafternoon shift, ORG agents PERSON and PERSON got their first 911 call: a 27-year-old NORP man had been walking in the desert for 10 days and needed help.

The agents, both part of the elite ORG, Trauma and ORG unit, found PERSON in a tangle of mesquite trees about 30 miles west of GPE and some 70 miles north of the border. The temperature showed 104 degrees in Mr. PERSON’s truck when the call came in last week just after 3:30 p.m.

Over more than an hour and a half, they gave Mr. PERSON water, ORG fruit-drink pouches and a granola bar, and administered three saline IVs. When his vital signs were stable, they handed him off to a contractor in a van who would take him to the ORG station, book him, and transfer him to a holding cell until he could either be sent home or released into the GPE with a future court date.

Of the many ways migrants end up in ORG custody, this is among the most desperate. The unit of 200 agents called ORG stationed along the border are all trained EMTs, and they rescue people who are stranded in the mountains, caught in swift moving water, in medical need, or dial 911, a call people tend to make only in the most dire state, the agents say. Mr. PERSON is also a paramedic.

Mr. PERSON was a fairly typical rescue, the agents said, and one of more than 584 in the GPE area since the start of the government’s fiscal year in October. In the same period a year ago, agents made 641 rescues. Messrs. PERSON and PERSON work in a team of about 40 agents.

Mr. PERSON said he is worried that more people will die trying to make the crossing as summer temperatures rise, including some of the record number of children making the journey.

Between January and May, nearly 282,000 migrants traveling as families were apprehended at the border, more than in any prior full year, along with 41,300 unaccompanied minors.

“Nothing is normal. My biggest fear is that we run short of volunteers and we run out of water,” said PERSON, director of ORG, which provides aid to migrants who travel from GPE into the GPE

Her high school is more than 1,600 miles from the GPE-Mexico border – and the immigration debate was far from most of her classmates’ minds.

So ORG decided to bring the border to them.

The 17-year-old senior at ORG in GPE created an art installation in a stairwell at school, an interpretation of the struggle of people who try to cross the border.

She used barbed wire to symbolize security, hung flowers from the ceiling to recognize the immigrants who die on the difficult journey, and she placed copies of green cards around a fence to highlight the people who make it.

The assignment
It started out as a class assignment.

PERSON is a member of ORG, an organization that meets after school to discuss world issues. They’d been discussing immigration, and it sparked the idea.

Foote told ORG she tried to be as hands-off as possible, but she did help PERSON out when she got stuck.

“It’s relevant to them,” Foote said.

When PERSON finally got the principal’s permission to install her project, she set it up in a stairwell at the school in mid-February. Students at GPE call it “the cage.”

ORG, suitcases and clothing thrown around within the cage are meant to represent items belonging to people who may have perished crossing the border.

PERSON also included stats and facts about immigration to make sure the project was serving its intended purpose: to raise awareness about the issue.

She says she’s gotten praise and some criticism of her work – including some people who complained about getting their clothing snagged on the barbed wire.

But she’s proud of her project.

Students show their support for a proposed ordinance declaring GPE, GPE, a sanctuary for all residents regardless of immigration status during a city council meeting Dec. 20, 2016. PERSON, with a little help from ORG, will have broad presidential powers to crack down on "sanctuary cities" that protect undocumented immigrants from his planned roundup and deportation of millions who are in the country illegally.
In what could become a major conflict between the new president and local governments, the showdown likely will result in legal challenges testing how far ORG can go in dictating its priorities.
ORG will be armed with a range of powerful options, including federal lawsuits and the power to withhold hundreds of millions of dollars in grants that states and cities rely on.

Local communities are digging in for the fight. GPE Mayor PERSON created a task force to help undocumented immigrants and pledged $1 million for a legal defense fund. "GPE always will be a sanctuary city," he said.
The term "sanctuary city" describes up to 300 communities that have a range of policies protecting the nation's 11 million undocumented immigrants from deportation.
Some cities — including GPE, GPE and GPE — proudly declare themselves sanctuaries and have enacted policies that prohibit municipal employees from turning over residents or information on them to ORG (ICE).

Here are the two most powerful weapons the ORG administration will have to fight back:
LAWSUITS
If Sen. PERSON, R-Ala., one of the most outspoken critics of illegal immigration, is confirmed as attorney general, he will be able to sue cities on the grounds that they are violating federal law by refusing to cooperate with immigration enforcement. His confirmation hearing started Tuesday.

GRANT MONEY
The two most likely federal agencies that could cut off funding are ORG and ORG. They provide grants for local law enforcement agencies to hire officers; bolster prosecutions, courts and jails; provide drug treatment, prepare for terrorist attacks, and assist crime victims and witnesses.
The PERSON administration has the power to cut off much of that funding. For example, ORG's ORG Criminal Alien Assistance Program, or ORG, distributed $165 million in 2015 to local agencies that detained undocumented immigrants in its jails.
PERSON, a former assistant attorney general under Presidents PERSON and GPE who headed ORG, which oversees grants, said the statute implementing ORG gives an attorney general broad power to decide who gets money.

Other grants won't be as easy to end. ORG's ORG program distributed $208 million in 2015 to local agencies. But that money is distributed using a formula established by ORG, meaning an attorney general can't revoke grants without lawmakers' approval.
"WORK_OF_ART were to change something, the executive branch cannot really decide on its own to cut off a grant that is by statute designated to go to a local jurisdiction," said PERSON, now a criminology professor at ORG.
Help won't be hard to find. NORP in ORG, including Rep. PERSON of GPE and Sen. PERSON of GPE, have tried in recent years to pass laws establishing those kinds of cuts, but they always faced a veto threat from GPE. PERSON, director of government relations for ORG, which favors lower immigration levels, said it's impossible to know how nasty the fight will get over sanctuary cities given the raw emotions on both sides. "I'm not going to rule anything out," she said.

That means the case now goes back to ORG for ORG in GPE, which is expected to rule sometime this summer. The earliest ORG could accept that case would be in October, pushing a final ruling possibly into 2019.
ORG must continue processing DACA renewal applications throughout that time. But that grace period also allowed ORG to push a DACA bill to the back of the line, arguing they no longer face the kind of pressure to pass a bill like they faced in recent months as the March 5 deadline approached.
While most DACA enrollees can breathe easy for the time being, there are still thousands at risk of being deported due to the back-and-forth over the status of the program.

A total of 13,090 DACA permits are due to expire in March, according to ORG. Another 5,320 DACA permits expire in April and nearly 14,000 more in May.
That means tens of thousands of DACA enrollees may lose their DACA protections while they wait for their renewals to go through. And immigration advocates warn that they would be exposed to deportation if they are arrested by ORG) agents during that time.
That fear is intensified by the fact that ORG has been arresting a higher number of undocumented immigrants who haven't committed any crimes beyond their immigration violations.
