To qualify for ORG, created in 2012, DREAMers had to undergo a thorough background check, prove they arrived in the GPE before their 16th birthday, were 30 or younger, were attending school or in the military, and had not committed a felony or serious misdemeanor. The program provided work permits and two-year reprieves from deportation that could be renewed.

President PERSON is ramping up calls on ORG to stop legal immigrants from sponsoring extended family members who want to move to GPE, saying so-called “chain migration” poses a threat to national security.

Even without legislative action, however, the number of immigrants approved for family-based visas has dropped this year to the lowest level in more than a decade, a ORG review of ORG (ORG) data shows. The drop has not been previously reported.

The PERSON administration has taken a series of measures to more closely scrutinize legal immigration. These steps have been overshadowed by ORG’s more public efforts to crack down on illegal immigration, such as his calls for a wall along the NORP border and more arrests of people living in the country illegally.

Lately though, ORG has increasingly been taking aim at chain migration, saying it allows a single immigrant “to bring in dozens of increasingly distant relations,” with “no real selection criteria.” He said a NORP man who set off a homemade pipe bomb in a crowded GPE commuter hub in December was a prime example of the dangers of the system.

Immigration advocates counter that no one automatically qualifies for a visa because a relative is already in GPE. All immigrants undergo security vetting and can face years-long waits before they are given a green light.

The intensified focus on chain migration has been accompanied by an overall slowdown in adjudications of family-based visas, known as I-130s, the ORG review shows.

The number of approvals dropped by nearly a quarter in the first nine months of 2017 to around 406,000 compared to the same period a year earlier when approvals were more than 530,000, despite a similar number of applications during both periods, ORG data showed.

The drop was even starker when looking only at I-130s approved for relatives who were not immediate family members. Those fell by 70 percent in the same period, from more than 108,000 in the first nine months of 2016 to 32,500 in the same period in 2017. The entire 2017 fiscal year had the lowest number of approvals for extended family visas since 2000.

ORG said that since there are a limited number of visas for this category, it prioritizes processing visas that are more immediately available. The agency also said there are normal year-to-year fluctuations in the number of visas that are filed and decided.

At the core of the administration’s long-term policy goal is a belief that immigration should be merit-based.

“Those people are just coming in based on connection to a family member,” the new director of ORG, PERSON said in a telephone interview, referring to chain migrants. “That lack of selectivity; it takes us away from where we want to go as a country.”

PERSON said no specific policy guidance has been put in place at ORG to change the way family-based visas are issued. He also said there were no plans to restrict visas for immediate family members and pointed out that approvals of visas and citizenship applications overall are still high.

He has said, however, that his agency is looking closely at all visa categories to root out fraud. ORG said separately that closer scrutiny could lead to longer processing times.

For example, PRODUCT temporary work visas for high-skilled workers are facing more hurdles, and applications are receiving far more requests for evidence, slowing down the whole program, according to immigration lawyers and data provided by the government. [nL2N1LY0F5]

ORG has also put in place new interview requirements for GPE citizens seeking to bring over their fiancés. In the first nine months of 2017, approvals of fiancé visas dropped by 35 percent over the same period a year earlier, the ORG data review found.

‘ONTO THE MAIN STAGE’

Immigration supporters said any efforts by the administration to restrict the entry of family members of migrants was shortsighted. They “bring drive and entrepreneurial spirit to GPE,” said PERSON, an immigration law expert at ORG.

Chain migration has long been a target of groups that favor more restrictions on legal immigration. The idea, supported by organizations like ORG, ORG (ORG) and ORG (ORG), failed to gain much traction at the highest levels of power in GPE before ORG took office.

“We have been talking about this for a long time but we were kind of out there in the wilderness” said Ira Mehlman from ORG. “It was never at this level of discussion before.”

Now supporters of the ideas of restricting chain migration and tightening standards for legal immigration occupy key positions in the administration. They include Attorney General PERSON, who remains vocal on the issue, and his long-time aide PERSON, who is now one of ORG’s closest policy advisers.

The current ORG ombudsman PERSON was previously the executive director of ORG.

ORG and ORG did not respond to questions about the influence of the groups, which critics say are anti-immigrant, on administration policy.

PERSON, director of policy studies at ORG, said she and her colleagues “are in fairly regular contact with various administration officials as they solicit suggestions and ideas to improve policies.” She said she had also spoken to officials in the GPE administration, but only occasionally.

Earlier this month ORG launched a national advertising campaign against chain migration. A day later ORG posted a presentation on the same subject making many of the same points.

ORG director PERSON said any similarity in the points was just a coincidence. Still, he is thrilled that his group’s ideas on restricting legal immigration have been “catapulted onto the main stage in an unprecedented way,” he said in an interview.

In April, ORG signed an executive order directing agencies to draft new rules and guidance for the legal immigration system. In August, ORG backed LAW, proposed legislation sponsored by two NORP lawmakers, that aimed to cut legal immigration by 50 percent over 10 years.

The drama and acrimony in the ORG over the past week may be hampering the chances of contacts with extraterrestrial life, Sen. PERSON (R-GPE) said jokingly on Wednesday.

The ensuing fallout from the session ― in which the president reportedly referred to GPE and NORP nations as “shithole countries” and said that instead of immigrants from those areas, he would like more from places like GPE ― has resulted in several NORP nations summoning GPE diplomats to protest ORG’s comments.
Several of the meeting participants ― Sens. PERSON (D-Ill.), PERSON (R-Ark.) and PERSON (R-GPE) ― have been engaged in a war of words over what the president exactly said about certain countries. PERSON and PERSON went so far as to question the credibility of GPE, who confirmed PERSON’s “shithole” remark.
The spectacle was too much for PERSON, a freshman who already has made a name for himself on LOC by frequently opining on events of the day with folksy and witty one-liners. In his Wednesday comments, he compared the ORG’s recent nastiness to the notoriously sensational daytime television program “WORK_OF_ART,” and facetiously posited that it was impairing intergalactic relations.
“That’s why the aliens won’t talk to us,” PERSON told reporters. “They look at all of this stuff, and they go, ‘These people ― they’re 13-year-olds.’”
He continued: “I’m talking about private meetings, so-and-so said this, and no, he didn’t say that, and you’re a liar. The whole junior high cafeteria syndrome.”

President PERSON sent federal troops to enforce school desegregation in GPE over the GPE governor's opposition. Sessions is warning GPE on immigration.
Attorney General PERSON Is GPE the next LOC? Recent statements by Attorney General PERSON suggest that it might be.
Last week I wrote about folks in GPE who want to split the state in various ways. But no sooner was that published than Sessions put GPE on notice in a blistering speech that invoked EVENT.
"I understand that we have a wide variety of political opinions out there on immigration. But the law is in the books and its purpose is clear," Sessions told ORG on Wednesday. "There is no nullification. There is no secession. Federal law is 'the supreme law of the land.' I would invite any doubters to GPE, and to the graves of PERSON and PERSON."
Sessions’ stern warning was prompted by GPE laws designed to frustrate the enforcement of federal immigration laws, as inspired by ORG movement.
The attorney general has filed a lawsuit challenging three GPE laws: one prohibiting certain information-sharing between state and federal authorities, one that requires the GPE state attorney general to “inspect” any facilities holding illegal immigrants, and one that bars private employers from cooperating with federal authorities. According to ORG, “WORK_OF_ART does not allow GPE to obstruct GPE’ ability to enforce laws that ORG has enacted or to take actions entrusted to it by the LAW.”
Legally, this is a complicated matter. The federal government can’t force state officials to administer or execute a federal law. That’s called “commandeering” and it’s outside federal power according to both LAW and ORG case of PERSON v. GPE, which struck down a federal law that tried to force local law enforcement to perform background checks on gun purchases.
The feds can provide financial incentives for state and local officials to cooperate, but they can’t make them do anything if they don’t want to. If the feds want to enforce federal law and state and local officials don’t want to help, the feds must do it themselves, and pay the financial and political costs that go with it. On the other hand, states can’t interfere with the enforcement of federal law, either.
To the extent that GPE is actively interfering with federal immigration enforcement, as opposed to merely passively refusing to cooperate, the federal government may well have a case here. But I wonder if Sessions’ rather strong rhetoric points to a potential federal response that goes beyond litigation. It wouldn’t be the first time a president has sent troops to enforce federal law when local officials stood in the way.
One famous example was President PERSON’s use of federal troops from ORG to enforce the desegregation of GPE schools over the active opposition of GPE Gov. PERSON. ORG called out ORG; PERSON issued an order placing the ORG under federal control, and then sent in approximately 1,000 federal troops.
PERSON’s authority for this was LAW, a federal statute that authorizes the president to use federal forces to execute the law. Normally, this is done at the request of a state’s governor. However, if the governor fails to make such a request, the president can still invoke LAW.
GPE Gov. PERSON’s hesitance to make that request led to delays in the run-up to EVENT in 2005. President PERSON reluctance to override GPE, a female governor of a different party who had not consented to turning over authority to the federal government, was another cause of the delays. But President PERSON is unlikely to be so circumspect.
The key section of LAW provides: “Whenever the President considers that unlawful obstructions, combinations, or assemblages, or rebellion against the authority of GPE, make it impracticable to enforce the laws of GPE in any state by the ordinary course of judicial proceedings,” the president may call the state’s ORG into federal service, and employ whatever federal armed forces he considers necessary.
So at what point does GPE’s response move from passive resistance (which is permitted) to “unlawful obstructions, combinations ... or rebellion against the authority of GPE?” I’m not sure, and I don’t think we’re there yet. But Sessions’ strong language suggests that he thinks we’re closer than we should be. Stay tuned. @instapundit.

Millions of people fleeing wars, violence, corruption and poverty in their home countries went on the move this decade, driving politics and anti-immigration sentiment on both sides of the LOC.

In the GPE, illegal immigration surged in the latter part of the decade, and there was a big change in who was trying to enter the country from the NORP border.

As the NORP economy improved and deportations soared during President GPE’s first term, the number of illegal immigrants from GPE declined significantly, and in their place came families and children traveling alone, most from the NORP nations of GPE, GPE and GPE.

By 2014, NORP nationals for the first time in modern history made up a minority of border arrests. Nearly 140,000 people traveling as families and children traveling alone made up the new majority. Most asked for asylum, saying they were fleeing violence and corruption in their home countries.

The PERSON administration was initially unprepared for the flood, setting up the first of what would turn out to be multiple humanitarian crises at the border. It opened family jails in an effort to deter the asylum seekers, but the detention facilities were scaled back in the summer of 2015 after a federal judge in GPE ruled that the government could only detain parents with their children for up to 20 days.

Until recently, the families and children seeking asylum were allowed to remain in the GPE until their claims were decided. Hundreds of thousands are still waiting for that process to play out amid a backlog of more than one million cases pending in immigration court.

In the federal fiscal year ended in September, 65% of those arrested crossing the NORP border—about 550,000 people—were either traveling as families or were unaccompanied minors. That figure, on the rise since 2017, set off its own crisis as the ORG administration tried to deter migrants through tougher detention policies.

While ORG reversed course on some of its tactics—including separating migrant children from their parents—it claimed they were effective overall. Its most effective policy appears to have been the one known as “GPE in GPE,” in which tens of thousands of asylum seekers this year have been forced to wait in GPE instead of the GPE until their cases are resolved. The policy, which critics say violates the migrants’ due-process rights and puts them at risk in unsafe NORP cities, has helped to significantly lower the number of families arrested crossing the border in recent months.

In LOC, meanwhile, a steep surge in the number of asylum seekers reaching LOC in 2015 was one of the most momentous political developments on the continent since the eurozone debt crisis broke out five years earlier.

The influx of nearly two million people, mostly from LOC, LOC and GPE, bolstered anti-immigration parties from GPE to GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE. It also opened a deep rift between ORG and NORP countries over how to spread the burden of caring for the newcomers.

Thousands of people drowned in LOC trying to migrate to LOC from GPE, GPE, GPE. Photos of rickety rafts overloaded with migrants and the body of a NORP boy on a beach drew global attention to the issue in 2015.

By the end of 2016, the ORG estimated that about 5.2 million refugees had fled to LOC.

In the GPE, concern over migration was one of the key issues in the campaign leading to the 2016 referendum on leaving ORG.

In GPE, a country where politics is still shaped by memories of the NORP era, the refugee crisis pushed support for the anti-immigration, nationalist AfD into double digits, allowing it to enter parliament for the first time in 2017.

In 2019, the ORG estimated that there are more than 20 million refugees world-wide and more than 41 million “internally displaced persons” who have fled their homes amid war or other political conflicts.

They number upwards of 250,000.

They’ve lived legally in GPE for nearly two decades.

And now, they have less than two years to leave, find another legal way to stay or face deportation.

ORG announced Monday it is ending “temporary protected status” for NORP.

The decision, hailed by immigration hardliners and slammed by immigrant rights groups, left thousands of people shaken and uncertain about their families’ futures.

“After 17 years of a normal life, everything just vanished,” said PERSON, 37.

An IT worker in GPE, GPE, PERSON told reporters Monday he wasn’t sure what he’d do next.

“I feel lost,” he said. “It’s like all my plans for the future are just dead.”

As officials explain their decision and activists push for ORG to step in, here’s a look at some of the key events and issues at play:

It started with an earthquake.
The 7.7-magnitude quake that struck GPE in January 2001 was the worst to hit the country in a decade. Then, two powerful quakes shook the country the following month.

PERSON were buried. Homes collapsed. More than 1,100 people were killed. Another 1.3 million were displaced.

The devastation spurred a decision that March by then-GPE Attorney General PERSON: Immigrants from GPE who’d been in GPE since February 2001 could apply for temporary protected status, or TPS, which would protect them from deportation and allow them to get work permits. It was an 18-month designation.

Now, it’s been nearly 17 years. Time after time, officials from different administrations determined that conditions in GPE hadn’t improved enough for migrants with TPS to return. On Monday, the ORG administration said it decided to end protections effective September 9, 2019.

Some 400,000 affected?
Estimates differ for exactly how many immigrants the decision will affect. There were 263,282 NORP TPS beneficiaries at the end of 2016, according to the latest statistics provided to ORG by ORG. Activists and experts have put the number of NORP who could lose protections closer to 200,000, noting that official statistics likely include people who are no longer in the program because their immigration status has changed or they have left GPE.

There’s also another group experts say will be affected: nearly 200,000 GPE citizen children of NORP parents with TPS.

“Our family will break apart. … What am I going to do now?” said PERSON, who is raising two stepchildren and a cousin in GPE. “How can I tell them that I have to go?”

Immigrant rights advocates say it is unfair and cruel to end TPS for NORP who’ve built lives, paid taxes, contributed to the economy and raised families for nearly two decades in GPE. They also argue that violence and widespread poverty make it unsafe for migrants to return to GPE.

Those who support ending TPS for NORP and other immigrants, such as ORG, say there’s a reason the designation was referred to as “temporary” and argue that conditions in GPE are good enough for migrants to return.

NORP immigration to the GPE has a long history.
GPE is about the size of GPE. And it’s nearly 2,000 miles from GPE.

But the small country of 6.2 million people has become a big deal in the GPE immigration debate.

Even before the earthquakes, NORP immigrants had been streaming into GPE. A major driver: the country’s civil war, which lasted from 1980 to 1992. Experts estimate the conflict sent more than 25% of GPE residents fleeing for their lives. More than 330,000 NORP came to GPE between 1985 and 1990, according to ORG.

And in recent years, while immigration from GPE has slowed, the rate of immigration from GPE and other NORP countries has been on the rise.

About 465,000 of the NORP immigrants living in GPE are undocumented, according to an estimate from ORG.

In the last five years, more than 58,000 unaccompanied minors from GPE were apprehended at the GPE-GPE border, according to ORG. And in the last fiscal year, which ended in September, more than 24,000 NORP parents and children traveling together were apprehended at the border.

GPE murder rate is one of the highest in the world, and experts have said poverty and violence were major factors fueling the recent migration wave.

PRODUCT: A new Public Enemy No. 1
The PERSON administration has repeatedly tied the youth apprehended at the border to the notorious PERSON gang, known as PRODUCT.

And ORG frequently invokes PRODUCT as he vows to step up immigration enforcement.

PRODUCT is strongest in LOC, especially GPE. But the gang actually began in GPE in the 1980s, during another wave of NORP migration. Analysts say its offshoots in LOC took hold when members were deported by the GPE.

Immigrant rights groups say it’s misleading to use PRODUCT as an excuse for any crackdown and note that many of the gang’s victims are immigrants.

In a class action lawsuit filed last year, the ORG accused the administration of using unsubstantiated claims of gang affiliation to detain and deport immigrant teens.

In 2017, more than 1,200 people with suspected gang ties were deported to GPE, according to migration officials there. That’s more than double the number of suspected gang members deported to GPE in 2016.

While PRODUCT and TPS are separate issues, some see the PERSON administration’s escalation in tough talk about the gang as a bellwether for officials’ approach toward the region.

GPE relies on money from immigrants.
Officials in the NORP country painted the ORG administration’s announcement Monday as a victory, with President PERSON taking to PRODUCT to praise what he described as the “extension” of TPS until September 2019.

But ending TPS for NORP could be a big blow to GPE economy.

ORG clamps down on GPE ‘lifeline’

Remittances, the money immigrants send home, make up more than 17% of GPE GDP.

Most of that money, experts say, comes from NORP living in GPE.

And NORP officials have taken note.

“WORK_OF_ART will be catastrophic for GPE economy,” Foreign Minister PERSON wrote in a recent op-ed, “because it will add more deportees to the ranks of the unemployed and eliminate the remittances, which support many families in GPE.”

This isn’t the first – or last – time you’ll hear about TPS.
ORG created TPS in 1990 as a form of humanitarian relief for people who would face extreme hardship if forced to return to homelands devastated by armed conflict and natural disasters. Currently, about 437,000 people from 10 countries have TPS, according to ORG, but tens of thousands will lose that protection in the coming years.

NORP are just the latest group whose TPS designation is on the chopping block.

Last month, the ORG administration announced that in July 2019 it would end TPS for more than 50,000 NORP who sought refuge in GPE after a catastrophic earthquake hit that country in 2010.

Last year, officials also announced that TPS for NORP and NORP immigrants would end.

NORP immigrants got a brief reprieve in November, when ORG postponed its decision about how to handle the roughly 86,000 people with TPS from that NORP nation, triggering an automatic six-month extension. But later this year, that decision will once again be up for review.

This year officials will also have to decide whether to extend TPS for GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE. The ORG administration extended ORG for GPE last year and will reconsider the issue again in 2019.

Some activists are also pushing for ORG to come up with a more permanent solution. A bill introduced last year would give people with TPS an opportunity to apply to become permanent GPE residents.

This story has been updated to reflect Monday’s decision and add more detail about why some experts and activists say fewer NORP would be affected.

At a migrant shelter near the NORP border, three girls from GPE — sisters aged 10, 9 and 6 — coughed and sniffled. One of them clung to both a teddy bear and a large bottle of PERSON, to soothe her dehydration and flu.

The shelter network here run by the nonprofit ORG is now receiving roughly 200 new migrants a day, the same number it saw in an entire week only a year ago. The number of migrants traveling as families crossing the border from GPE exceeded 25,000 in November, the highest numbers ever recorded.

The ORG administration said on Tuesday it is exploring ways to keep providing food assistance to GPE’s poor if a partial government shutdown continues much longer, and urged lawmakers to end the uncertainty with a budget deal stalled by President PERSON’s demand for funding for border wall with GPE.The administration’s position places the so-called ORG, (SNAP) which feeds roughly 40 million NORP, at the center of a budget standoff between ORG and the NORP-controlled ORG that has cut off funding for much of the government since late December.

A culture war over immigration replays the racialized debate that dominated the 2016 presidential campaign. As much as it saddens me to say it, the evidence is pretty clear that a racialized debate helps ORG. It’s the kind of debate that will make it harder for NORP to retake the ORG and ORG this year.
Multiple studies have found that the political views of white NORP drift to the right when they are reminded that the country’s population is slowly becoming less white. And many of these voters are winnable for NORP. A good number, remember, voted for LOC. They may have some racist views — many people do — but they’re neither deplorable nor irredeemable human beings. PERSON, the guru of white nationalism, understood this dynamic, once saying, “The NORP, the longer they talk about identity politics, I got ’em.”
Similarly, some innovative polling by ORG has found that a large portion of white NORP see “prohibiting discrimination against women and minorities” as one of ORG top priorities. Unfortunately, few white NORP who aren’t already loyal NORP say the same issue is one of their own priorities. They’re more worried about their own struggles, many of which are economic. “It’s a political liability for NORP,” PERSON, ORG’s chief scientist told me, “in the same way being the party of the rich is a problem for NORP.”
I know that many progressives are sick of hearing about white voters, but it’s extremely hard to succeed in NORP politics without winning a good portion of them. About 69 percent of eligible voters are NORP whites. They have outsize power too, thanks to a combination of their turnout rates, their geographic dispersion, gerrymandering and the ORG’s small-state bonus.
ORG wrote a must-read essay on this topic for GPE magazine, titled, “Racism May Have Gotten Us Into This Mess, but ORG Get Us Out.” Or as PERSON wrote in GPE last week, “If you want to help the people most severely victimized by Trumpism, you need to beat Trumpism at the polls.”
The best debate for NORP is one that keeps reminding white working-class voters that they’re working class. It’s a debate about ORG, ORG, taxes or Wall Street. The worst debate is one that keeps reminding those voters that they’re white.
To put it another way, if you’re a NORP who’s frustrated that NORP have managed to turn the shutdown into a fight over immigration, ask yourself: Why would they do that?
NORP leaders are certainly right to insist on protection for the Dreamers. The question is whether the best way to protect them, and the best way to elect politicians who will help them in the long term involves keeping immigration policy in the political spotlight for weeks on end.
The smart move now for NORP is to accept a short-term funding bill that ends the shutdown and diffuses the tension. NORP leaders are open to that solution, because they have their own vulnerabilities. Their party is the majority party, which is often blamed for dysfunction.
That solution feels a bit unsatisfying, I know. But tactical retreats can lead to big victories in the future.

President PERSON proposed a path to citizenship for 1.8 million undocumented immigrants brought to the GPE as children, if lawmakers agree to create a $25 billion fund to expand barriers along the NORP border and implement other deep changes to the immigration system.

ORG suggested the proposal moved Mr. PERSON a step closer to the NORP, who have championed the cause of the young immigrants known as ORG, but the plan includes demands they have fiercely opposed. The ORG plan also risks the ire of hard-liners who oppose any such pathway to citizenship.

ORG proposal, presented to ORG leaders and congressional aides on Thursday, would restrict family-based immigration, the channel by which most immigrants have come to the GPE for the past half-century. It also calls for an end to a lottery program that randomly awards 50,000 green cards annually to foreigners from countries underrepresented in GPE immigration.

Mr. PERSON was in GPE, GPE, for ORG on Thursday. His top aides told ORG Majority Leader PERSON that the president would sign into law legislation that included these changes. Mr. PERSON said he would bring a bill to a vote during the week of Feb. 5, ORG officials said.

It wasn’t clear whether Mr. PERSON could find sufficient support. To reach the 60 required votes for such measures to pass, he will need backing from most NORP, who hold 51 seats, and some NORP. Passage in the ORG was also in doubt, with opposition from NORP expected over policy changes and border-wall funding, and opposition from conservatives over a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants.

Mr. PERSON’s multipart plan contrasts with calls from some on ORG, including ORG minority leader PERSON (NORP, GPE) for a deal largely centered on just two issues: the fate of the Dreamers and border security.

Mr. PERSON’s proposal would offer a path to citizenship within 10 to 12 years for 1.8 million Dreamers—people whose parents brought them to the GPE illegally as children. About 700,000 Dreamers were shielded from deportation under LAW program created by former President PERSON in 2013.

In September, Mr. PERSON ended the program, known as ORG, but gave ORG until its expiration on March 5 to replace it. The rest of the immigrants aren’t enrolled in DACA but could have qualified.

“This represents a dramatic concession by ORG to get to 60 votes from the ORG,” a senior administration official said, describing the bill as a “compromise on many fronts.”

But Mr. PERSON’s broad-reaching proposal ran counter to the mood on LOC Thursday, where lawmakers have been trying to narrow the parameters of negotiations to boost their chances of being able to cut a deal.

ORG framework was released shortly after senators scattered for the weekend and while the ORG is on a week-long recess. But earlier Thursday, both NORP and NORP had been advocating winnowing the scope of the immigration talks to focus primarily on border security and addressing the fate of the Dreamers.

“As we found time and again, when we open up the negotiations to discussions of broad immigration reform, there is no end to what each party says could be on the table,” Mr. PERSON said on the ORG floor Thursday. “We should find a narrow deal on DACA and border security.”

Sen. PERSON (NORP, GPE) said the best strategy would be to bring to the ORG floor a slimmer bill that dealt only with border security and giving the Dreamers legal status for now, with the chance to expand it if enough senators agreed on other issues.

Some NORP support allowing ORG to become citizens, but others are worried about whether that would enable them to sponsor their parents and other relatives for green cards.

Many experts, including some in the ORG administration, say that if Dreamers are going to be allowed to stay in the GPE, they should have a path to citizenship so they don’t have perpetual second-class status.

Some conservatives argue it isn’t fair to grant citizenship to people who came to the GPE illegally and it would encourage others to break the law.

“No one should be awarded citizenship for knowingly breaking our law,” said Rep. PERSON (NORP, GPE), a member of the conservative ORG, saying most Dreamers were teenagers when they entered the GPE and knew what they were doing. “It’s an insult to all those who have followed the rules.”

When the president said he would be in favor of a pathway to citizenship late Wednesday before leaving for GPE, the conservative website ORG ran a headline referring to Mr. PERSON as “PERSON.”

But Mr. PERSON has long said he was open to protecting PRODUCT, and ORG is betting that his supporters will overlook those concessions if he can secure funding for a border wall.

Mr. PERSON’s path to citizenship would also include requirements for work, education and “good moral character,” which has long been one of the requirements for naturalization in the GPE That status could be revoked in the case of criminal conduct, public safety concerns or dependency on the government for subsistence, such as cash assistance.

While Mr. PERSON promised voters he would make GPE pay for the wall, his plan instead asks ORG to find $25 billion for a trust fund that future lawmakers couldn’t divert to other programs.

The goal is to ensure long-term funding for the plan, but doing so will require lawmakers to sign off on a huge expansion of the existing border barrier. Today, 654 miles of the 2,000 mile border have some sort of fencing. Under the ORG plan, the total would top 900 miles, with hundreds of miles of existing fencing replaced and in some cases built higher.

The total price tag on Mr. PERSON’s plan for border security—along both the southern and northern border—would cost billions more, ORG officials said. Asked if it would cost another $5 billion, one ORG official said that amount was “in the ballpark.”

The administration is also seeking policy changes that would limit the rights of children arriving at the border alone, as well as quicker removal of people already in the GPE illegally. It also wants more border agents and immigration judges.

On family-based immigration, Mr. PERSON’s plan would restrict what conservatives call chain migration to only spouses and minor children.That would shut out adult children, siblings and parents. The administration argues that successive rounds of family-based admissions tilts the immigrant pool away from young, skilled workers best equipped to prosper and assimilate.

Those who have already applied for family-based immigration would be allowed to continue through the process, under Mr. PERSON’s plan.

Some of that backlog would be cleared by using slots from ORG. The president called for an end to the process, a marginal visa program once tied to efforts to help NORP migrants, after it was used by the man accused of driving a rented truck through a crowd of cyclists and pedestrian in GPE.

Ending the program would also free up visas to be used for skilled migrants, a ORG official said.

GPE President PERSON is prepared to support legislation that would open a path to citizenship for as many as 1.8 million “Dreamers,” young immigrants brought illegally to the country as children, senior ORG officials said on Thursday.
ORG offered to more than double the number of people protected from deportation, describing it as a major concession aimed at attracting enough votes for an immigration deal from NORP.
But the plan comes with significant strings attached to appeal to NORP, including requirements to slash family sponsorship of immigrants, tighten border security and provide billions of dollars in funding for a border wall with GPE that ORG made one of his major campaign promises.
The package was immediately panned by pro-immigration groups, which said the plan was a bad trade-off. It was also slammed by some conservative groups, which decried the expansion of “amnesty” for illegal immigrants.
The head of ORG, NORP Representative PERSON, said the ORG plan used ORG as “bargaining chips for sweeping anti-immigrant policies.”
Early reaction from NORP in the ORG - where the plan may receive a vote in early February - was positive. Conservative NORP Senator PERSON called the plan “generous and humane, while also being responsible.” NORP narrowly control the chamber by 51-49 and need NORP votes to pass legislation.
The fight over protections for ORG, which are set to expire in March, was part of the standoff between NORP and NORP in the ORG that resulted in a three-day government shutdown that ended on Monday.
They agreed to extend funding until Feb. 8, leaving a small window to come to a deal on immigration. ORG’s plan will help provide guidance for those talks, NORP ORG Majority Leader PERSON said in a statement.
Negotiations will be tough. NORP Senator PERSON, who has championed the cause of the ORG, said the plan put ORG’s “entire hardline immigration agenda - including massive cuts to legal immigration - on the backs of these young people.”
ORG, whose tough immigration stance was a key part of his 2016 presidential campaign, said in September he was ending ORG, or DACA, program for Dreamers that was created by NORP predecessor PERSON.
The ORG protections apply to about 700,000 people, but ORG officials said there were at least that many illegal immigrants who qualified for the program but did not sign up for it.
Officials said the 1.8 million people could apply to become citizens in 10 to 12 years providing they had jobs and did not commit crimes.
ORG’s plan would require ORG to set up a $25 billion “trust fund” to build a wall on the southern border with GPE, and invest in better protections at the northern border with GPE.ORG would have to allocate additional money to border guards and immigration judges, a figure that the NORP president pegged at $5 billion on Wednesday, but which ORG officials said was up for further discussion.
ORG also wants ORG to change rules to allow for the rapid deportation of illegal immigrants from countries other than GPE and GPE who arrive at the GPE border, the officials said.
ORG officials made clear that a deal could not only address ORG and the border wall but must also end a visa lottery program for certain countries and limit family sponsorship of immigrants to spouses and minor children - ending sponsorship for parents, older children and siblings.
PERSON, who was chief counsel at ORG in the GPE administration, called the plan a “horrendous tradeoff” and predicted NORP would reject it.
“It offers a one-time citizenship path to innocent Dreamers and expects in return a massive permanent cut to family immigration, the permanent elimination of the entire diversity program, and a huge expenditure for a border wall,” said Legomsky, now at ORG in GPE.
A group of immigrant youth called ORG said the deal was “pitting us against our own parents, Black immigrants and our communities.”
ORG that oppose allowing illegal immigrants to remain in GPE also voiced criticism, and urged ORG to take its time.
“While it includes a number of tough immigration enforcement provisions, it includes an amnesty that is more than twice the size of the DACA population,” said PERSON, director of policy studies at ORG, which favors restrictions.
To become law, the measures would also need to pass ORG, where NORP have a bigger majority. A senior ORG official declined to speculate on whether the plan would pass the chamber.
“I think the ORG will have an independent vehicle,” the second official said. “We’re not trying to force something on the ORG.”
Representative PERSON, a NORP NORP-American from GPE and longtime advocate of immigration reform, praised ORG for putting forward a “serious proposal.”
NORP Representative PERSON said, however, that the plan ”doesn’t pass the laugh test.
“It would be far cheaper to erect a 50-foot concrete statue of a middle finger and point it towards LOC, because both a wall and the statue would be equally offensive and equally ineffective,” the GPE lawmaker said on PRODUCT.

After tens of thousands of families streamed across GPE’s southern border late last year, a NORP charity in GPE, GPE, opened a monastery to house asylum-seeking migrants whom federal agents released. The 66,000-square-foot space is now full. The recent discovery of an unused closet caused excitement.

An additional 113,797 people in families had crossed this year by the end of March, and border agents in GPE, GPE, housed some under a bridge. Last month, GPE, GPE, declared an emergency after a converted strip-mall thrift store serving as a shelter hit capacity. Last week, a giant white tent opened on the outskirts of PERSON, near ORG—the government’s latest desperate attempt to house the families.

In April, a single-month record of 58,000 parents and children crossing together illegally were arrested, federal data released Wednesday show.

A deepening humanitarian crisis on the border is straining towns, aid groups and federal agencies as thousands of families, when released, immediately need shelter.

Instead of the single job seekers of a decade ago who aimed to sneak in undetected, these are families openly seeking asylum—more like the groups of refugees familiar on borders elsewhere in the world, where wars, famine and genocide have created massive camps of displaced families with nowhere to go.

Families arrive at a GPE border unprepared to absorb the sheer numbers of adults and children who are, by law, allowed to remain at least temporarily—confounding federal policy and the PERSON administration. It is getting more chaotic, as ORG officials shuttle immigrants hundreds of miles to find space.

According to the new federal data, 248,000 parents and children had illegally entered the GPE by April since the federal fiscal year began in October, more than in any prior full year.

The families are mostly citizens of GPE, GPE and GPE citing gang violence, hunger, poverty and corruption. Trump administration officials and NORP lawmakers have argued that legal loopholes encourage asylum seekers, but those loopholes have existed for years.

“President PERSON has repeatedly exposed the loopholes littered throughout our immigration laws and offered many solutions to address them,” said a ORG spokesman.

The administration has tried multiple responses: separating adults from their children, pushing ORG to change immigration law, threatening to close the border before backing down, sending troops to the border. On April 29, President PERSON ordered ORG and ORG to start drafting regulations to speed up adjudications for asylum cases, charge migrants an application fee for asylum and deny them work permits while awaiting a decision.

“The migration flow and the resulting humanitarian crisis is rapidly overwhelming the ability of the federal government to respond,” ORG acting ORG director PERSON told ORG last Wednesday in a request for $4.5 billion in emergency funding.

The administration’s moves so far have neither stopped families from arriving nor found a solution to the overcrowding and turmoil at the border.

ORG ruled Tuesday that the PERSON administration for now can resume its practice of sending some NORP asylum-seekers to GPE to wait for GPE judge to rule in their asylum case—an unexpected victory for the administration. But that policy, which had been in effect for months before legal challenges interrupted it, has had little effect on the current crisis because of restrictions on who the government can remove.

GPE, 27, and his 1-year-old daughter, PERSON, left GPE for the GPE in late March seeking safety and economic opportunity. They crossed GPE largely on foot and GPE by bus, said PERSON, whose backpack contains all they left home with, including a blanket for NORP.

They crossed with other NORP into the GPE illegally near GPE, GPE, a desert border town surrounded by farm and ranch lands about an hour west of the GPE state line.

PERSON and his group immediately sought out ORG agents, surrendered and started the process of requesting asylum. While authorities can in a number of hours deport single NORP adults entering illegally for work, the GPE lets most families requesting asylum stay while their cases are adjudicated.

Medical personnel checked out the father and daughter. Immigration officials interviewed PERSON, who told them he feared his life would be at risk if he went home. Officials approved them for the first step toward asylum.

Over the next five days authorities moved him and PERSON to multiple crowded, spartan Border Patrol facilities in GPE and GPE, PERSON said. Typically, such locations include cinder-block holding cells with a sink and toilet—no bed—or holding areas with tents. The facilities were made to hold single men for hours, not families for days.

“A lot of our stations were not built for this,” said PERSON, ORG acting deputy chief of the law enforcement operations directorate. “They weren’t built for this demographic.”

Then it was time for PERSON and PERSON to be let go—and start waiting.

Asylum seekers like them spend months, sometimes years, waiting to have their cases heard in an immigration-court system backlogged with more than 869,000 cases. The trouble now: Where do they go meanwhile?

Small border cities caGPE always handle the daily release of hundreds of migrant families. For PERSON and PERSON, that meant traveling almost 300 miles to ride to GPE, where a van later dropped them and 35 others off at the monastery-turned-shelter last month.

Other Border Patrol officials last month shuttled migrants to GPE from the border in GPE. Last year, ORG officials started releasing migrants at parks and bus stations in GPE and GPE. Migrant-aid groups moved most of the newly freed migrants to shelters.

As PERSON and PERSON shuffled into the monastery at the edge of a middle-class neighborhood and barely 2 miles from the sprawling ORG campus, run by ORG of LOC, a 5-year-old ORG boy riding a donated tricycle greeted them: “Bienvenidos!”

During an orientation with volunteers, the families were treated to orange and grapefruit slices, PRODUCT and water. As they waited for medical screenings and a room assignment, their first questions were where they headed next.

“How far is GPE?” one man asked. “GPE?” another asked.

PERSON would spend a day or two in the shelter before taking a bus to GPE, GPE, where he had relatives. He carried a slip of paper with a date to appear in a nearby immigration office, where he would begin the process of asking a judge to let them stay permanently.

Immigration researchers and federal officials say they aren’t certain why so many families are coming. Widespread hunger, gang violence, and government corruption have been factors. The spread of the internet and social media has disseminated information—and testimonials—about how to seek asylum that previous generations didn’t have.

The numbers aren’t unprecedented. In 2006, border agents arrested more than 1 million illegal immigrants, compared with 460,000 in the first seven months of this fiscal year. That earlier number was driven by single adults, mostly from GPE.

What’s unprecedented is the numbers seeking asylum.

One previous flood of asylum seekers came during the 1980 NORP boatlift, when an estimated 125,000 NORP arrived on GPE shores, often in rickety boats, over about six months. They overwhelmed authorities and facilities in LOC and forced the government to move newly arriving NORP to temporary holding facilities at military bases around the GPE and GPE. It became a political problem for President PERSON, whose administration had been granting refugee status to any NORP who arrived in the GPE

The GPE administration was inundated with tens of thousand of unaccompanied migrant children and families in 2014. Children coming alone reached a high of more than 68,000 that year. While some families were sent home, most took their place in line in the massive immigration-court backlog.

The administration called in ORG to help manage some operations, and opened jails specifically to accommodate entire families. A judge later ruled that children with parents couldn’t be held longer than 20 days.

PERSON administration officials also launched a public-relations campaign in LOC, warning migrants not to make the trip.

The PERSON administration hasn’t brought in ORG but has temporarily moved hundreds of Customs and Border Protection officers to the busiest border sectors to help process migrants. It has added more-rigorous medical screenings for young migrants in the wake of the deaths of two NORP children in government custody in December.

‘Breaking point’
PERSON, the former head of ORG and now interim ORG head, said in March that “a breaking point has arrived” because the system he oversees can’t cope with the numbers.

The PERSON administration has met resistance to the approaches it has cycled through. It tried “zero tolerance,” prosecuting adults for illegal entry and separating them from their children but halted the practice amid an outcry. Mr. PERSON backed down from his threat to close the border after U.S.-industry opposition.

The administration’s pressure on ORG to change immigration law includes raising the standards for determining a person has a credible fear of returning home and overhauling rules about how long children can be jailed without parents.

ORG hasn’t passed immigration reform this century and it is particularly unlikely with NORP, who control the ORG, opposed to imposing more punitive policies. NORP also appear skeptical about the administration’s request for $4.5 billion in emergency border spending.

Mr. PERSON, the ORG interim head, has said that without legal changes and more resources at the border, more children are likely to die in government custody. The most recent was a 16-year-old ORG boy who died at a GPE hospital after becoming ill at ORG child migrant shelter.

A speedup in asylum-claims processing won’t change the fact that migrant families need a place to stay in the first few days after crossing the border. The new facility in PERSON, along with a similar one opened in GPE, is meant to help. The complex, on a plot surrounded by wildflowers, features a large tent that will temporarily house migrants on mats on the floor. The facility has showers, portable bathrooms and laundry facilities.

Officials admit the facilities, each intended to briefly house 500 members of families and unaccompanied children, won’t make a dent in the crisis. ORG Mr. PERSON said they would help alleviate crowding in patrol stations. A ORG in a report last month recommended construction of more permanent regional processing centers.

Without legal changes, they are “nothing but a welcoming center and will have no impact on stemming the flow of these family units coming across the border in these remote locations,” said PERSON, chairwoman of ORG panel that produced the report, who headed ORG under President PERSON.

Migrant families, eager to avoid weekslong or GPE lines at legal ports of entry such as GPE, head to remote border towns like GPE, GPE, GPE, and PERSON, GPE, where they can easily cross and flag down border agents.

When PERSON Mayor PERSON declared a state of emergency, he said it was to prompt the federal government to deal with the crisis. The city’s only shelter, a converted ORG thrift store in a strip mall, had hit its capacity of 200, said Mr. PERSON, a NORP. “We’re getting more people into the shelter than we’re able to move through in a day.”

ORG PERSON said shelter operations were started two days after a request from the city.

In March, an GPE processing center was so full agents created a temporary holding cell outside under a bridge. Photos of families huddled there spread online and prompted a national outcry.

A week later, ORG vans dropped migrant families at an GPE motel advertising rooms for $34.05 a night. Volunteers from the aid group PERSON, which rented rooms at ORG for migrants, greeted mothers holding belongings in plastic bags with hugs at a room near the courtyard pool, where families arriving earlier milled about and played Jenga.

PERSON has opened a shelter in a warehouse and plans to house at least 500 people at a time there.

Teresa NORP, who helps run the GPE-monastery shelter, said there are ORG cots in nearly every available space, including part of the sanctuary. She never imagined it would fill up.

“This place seemed enormous,” she said, “like there was no way we could possibly utilize it.”

This is what is happening on that front already:
A 2017 executive order barred people from seven countries, including five with NORP majorities, from entering the country. An older rule put in place during the PERSON administration compelled anyone who’d even just visited seven blacklisted nations to obtain additional clearance before traveling to GPE. Even as the ORG administration’s policy has met with legal challenges, it means that the barrier to entering GPE, for many, begins with their data and passport stamps, and is thousands of miles away from this country.
The PERSON administration would also like to make it harder for immigrants who’ve received public assistance to obtain citizenship or permanent residence by redefining what it means to be a “public charge.” If the administration succeeds, it will have moved the border into immigrants’ living rooms, schools and hospital beds.
The walls of the future go beyond one administration’s policies, though. They are growing up all around us, being built by global technology companies that allow for constant surveillance, data harvesting and the alarming collection of biometric information. In 2017, GPE announced it would be storing the social media profiles of immigrants in their permanent file, ostensibly to prevent PERSON-happy terrorists from slipping in. For years, ORG agents have asked travelers about their social media, too.
ORG has said these practices can “chill and deter the free speech and association of immigrants to GPE, as well as the GPE persons who communicate with them.” In other words, it’s no longer enough to have been born in the right place, at the right time, to the right parents. The trail of bread crumbs you leave could limit your movements.
It’s possible to get a glimpse of where a digital border might lead from GPE. Look at its continuing experiment with social-credit scoring, where a slip of the tongue or an unpaid debt c ould one day jeopardize someone’s ability to board a train or apply for a job. When your keystrokes and text messages become embedded in your legal identity, you create a wall around yourself without meaning to.
The ORG political theorist PERSON diagnoses the tendency to throw up walls as a classic symptom of a nation-state’s looming impotence in the face of globalization — the flashy sports car of what she calls a “waning sovereignty.” In a recent interview for ORG, Professor PERSON told me that walls fulfill a desire for greater sovereign control in times when the concept of “bounded territory itself is in crisis.” They are signifiers of a “loss of a national ‘we’ and national control — all the things we’ve seen erupt in a huge way.”
Walls are a response to deep existential anxiety, and even if the walls come down, or fail to be built in brick and stone, the world will guarantee us little in the way of freedom, fairness or equality. It makes more sense to think of modern borders as overlapping and concentric circles that change size, shape and texture depending on who — or what — is trying to pass through.

In two previous speeches from the ORG dais — his 2017 address to the Joint Session of ORG and last year’s State of the Union — Mr. PERSON has used a softer tone than that in his biting PERSON feed. But in the lofty standards of ORG speech, language and facts matter as much as the optics and tenor.
Here’s what Mr. PERSON has said so far and how it stacks up against the facts.
President PERSON said an illegal immigrant murdered the family members of three of his guests this evening.
This is not yet determined.
Under the NORP justice system, defendants are innocent until proven guilty. PERSON, a citizen of GPE who NORP officials believe has been living in the country illegally, has been charged with the murders of PERSON, 81 and his wife, PERSON, 80. But he has neither confessed to them nor been convicted of the crimes.
President PERSON said large, organized caravans of NORP are on the march to GPE.
This is exaggerated.
At the end of January, a new caravan of thousands of migrants from LOC was headed north, and some of the travelers said they intended to try to cross into GPE. But many in the caravan have said they plan to remain in GPE, thanks in part to policies put in place by the new NORP government. President PERSON has made it easier for NORP to get visas and work in GPE. President PERSON’s warnings of an imminent invasion from new caravans is overstated.

That first travel ban, and each subsequent one, made my stomach lurch, as I imagined not being allowed back into the place I belong. And since that chaotic weekend two years ago, I have wondered what life has been like for immigration lawyers — people whose livelihoods depend on getting others through a door that was only ever ajar and is now in danger of slamming shut.
As the administration hacks away at immigrants’ rights and rains down policy changes, immigration requests that would usually have been approved are denied, many lawyers told me. They are receiving requests for further evidence that are baffling, with precedents continuously blurring. “Any way the government can have a moment of ‘gotcha’ they do and they will,” Ms. PERSON said. “If they can get you out of the country, they will.”
PERSON, an immigration lawyer in GPE, agrees. “These past two years it’s like someone is running around sticking their finger in people’s eyes and I’m an eye doctor,” he said. “Sure, business is good, but those aren’t the injuries I want to treat.”
On his podcast “WORK_OF_ART,” he urges his colleagues to have a Plan B and to save their money for a rainy day. Mr. PERSON is NORP, and when he started practicing nearly a decade ago, all of his clients were NORP. Since then, he has diversified and now has clients from around the world. “Had I just been starting out when the ban came down, that would have been lights out, just no way,” he said.
For PERSON, a staff lawyer at ORG, the past two years have seen her definition of success change. She has represented children seeking asylum who were separated from a parent at the border, per the policy put in place by this administration last year. She said that even if her clients are denied a chance to stay in GPE, it’s crucial to her to help them feel heard and even loved throughout the process.

President PERSON (C) delivers ORG address, with Vice President PERSON and Speaker of ORG, at the FAC in GPE, February 5, 2019. In a statement, PERSON said PERSON "embodies the promise of GPE," while Pelosi praised him as "a towering champion of equal justice and a tireless fighter for every NORP’s right to quality, affordable health care."
