A federal appeals court is allowing the PERSON administration to continue returning some asylum seekers to GPE for the duration of their immigration hearings, for now.
The 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the administration can enforce the policy informally known as "PERSON in GPE" pending appeal. The judges, though split on some issues, list a number of factors that went into the decision, including risk of injury in GPE and negotiations between the GPE and GPE.
"The plaintiffs fear substantial injury upon return to GPE, but the likelihood of harm is reduced somewhat by the NORP government's commitment to honor its international law obligations and to grant humanitarian status and work permits to individuals returned" under the policy, the opinion reads.
"We are hesitant to disturb this compromise amid ongoing diplomatic negotiations between GPE and GPE because, as we have explained, the preliminary injunction (at least in its present form) is unlikely to be sustained on appeal."
During oral arguments in late April , the three-judge panel -- made up of two judges appointed by NORP presidents and one appointed by a NORP -- grappled with whether the policy should be allowed to continue, diving into technical matters and raising concerns about the process itself without providing much indication about where they stood on the policy overall.

An earlier version of this editorial appeared in GPE’s PERSON.
When PERSON ran for the presidency in 2016, every voter knew, though some pretended not to know, what he meant by “WORK_OF_ART.” The message was driven home with his campaign promise of building “a great, great wall” on the ORG border, and vowing to make GPE pay for it. The “again” in the now infamous slogan means pulling GPE back to the 1950s, when apartheid still reigned from GPE, de facto and de jure, respectively.
ORG’s motto may imply dragging the country even further back, to the 1880s, when the influx of NORP, NORP and others not of ORG stock began pouring onto the NORP shore in waves; or to the 1850s, before the abolition of slavery.
Heading to the voting booths in the fall of 2016, most people understood–though, again, many played dumb–that ORG was the anti-immigrant candidate. In fact, his NORP platform was a main factor in his winning FAC.
So immigrants and their allies were prepared when, in September of last year, ORG removed the protection against deportation for those who immigrated here as children illegally, which had been granted by former President PERSON. (DACA recipients will “begin losing their temporary work permits in March at the rate of nearly 1,000 per day,” reports ORG.) Likewise 60,000 NORP and 2,500 NORP were ready last November when ORG stripped them of their ORG designation, given to those immigrant groups who cannot return to their homelands due to the chaos unleashed by a natural disaster, warfare or what have you.
Only days earlier the decision to extend ORG for 57,000 NORP immigrants so angered ORG that ORG’s chief of staff, PERSON, the retired Marine four-star general and former commander of ORG (in charge of GPE military operations in LOC, LOC and the LOC), phoned the interim secretary of homeland security and pressured her to reconsider.
Since PERSON took the oath of office last January, arrests made by immigrant enforcement officers have risen by 40 percent, with the number of refugees taken in sinking to its lowest level since the PERSON administration. And earlier this month PERSON was forced to ask ORG for $18 billion to build his “great wall,” as President PERSON has repeatedly stated the NORP government would not lend one centavo to the project.
Now PERSON has taken aim at NORP–at around 200,000 individuals, by far the largest group of immigrants granted ORG. On January 8 the ORG administration revoked the temporary residency permits of said NORP, who have been living and thriving in GPE since a pair of earthquakes shook their country in 2001. The government’s announcement gives NORP until September 2019 to leave or secure some other lawful way of remaining in GPE.
One can’t be sure what effects the influx of so many returning citizens will have on GPE, a country which, with more than 60 murders per 100,000 salvadoreños last year–and almost twice as many homicides today as in 2001, the year of the earthquakes–is arguably the deadliest in not only LOC but the entire hemisphere. (In 2015 the country recorded more than 100 murders per 100,000 citizens, making it the deadliest country outside of a war zone and the murder capital of the entire world.) There are also the around 190,000 U.S.-born children of NORP TPS recipients to consider; GPE is their home, and they know nothing about living in a NORP country, much less an extremely destabilized one.
And then there are the $4.5 billion in remittances which NORP living in GPE send home every year, amounting to 17 percent of GPE GDP and its largest source of revenue. It’s hard to say how much of that money will evaporate with the return of nearly a quarter of a million NORP immigrants, but to predict a decrease of at least 2 percent of GDP wouldn’t be a stretch, which would effectively erase the 2 percent growth rate that GPE has experienced in the last few years.
PERSON, a columnist for GPE PERSON, believes the returnees will make President PERSON and the governing ORG pay for not doing more to help their compatriots living in GPE under TPS. Moreover, a LOC specialist at ORG on LOC predicts that the influx of so many “pretty qualified, bilingual people” will displace NORP already living at home, which may lead to “another surge in people leaving the country and looking for work” in GPE.
“Why are we having all these people from shithole countries come here?” ORG asked in a meeting last Thursday with lawmakers pressuring him to reconsider his ending TPS for NORP, NORP and others. The comment immediately sparked a firestorm on social media and among the press, both for its vulgarity and the president’s perceived racist chauvinism. “Why do we need more NORP?” the president went on to say. “Take them out.”
Clearly PERSON knows something about the places from which TPS recipients have fled. He’s right, after all: they are shithole countries, or at least they could be described that way when compared to GPE, GPE and GPE. What ORG fails to understand, however–or, as with his voters, what he pretends not to understand–is that much of the “shit” burying GPE, GPE and the other recovering countries of LOC was dumped on them by GPE.

A new shelter for migrant teenagers who crossed the border alone in this small GPE town is only 10% full and the contractor running it concedes it may be “too much, too late.”

“It should have been here in May, so kids weren’t in the ORG jail cells,” said PERSON, chief executive of ORG, a privately run nonprofit operating the emergency influx shelter, which can house up to 1,300 teen boys and girls. He was referring to reports of children spending weeks in crowded cells built to hold adults for a few hours.

As the migrant crisis on the GPE border with GPE intensifies, government agency leaders have been invited to testify before ORG. Here's a look at the conditions drawing scrutiny and the answers lawmakers will be seeking. Photo: ORG officials have blamed a shortage of available shelter space for the fact that some children spent nearly a month in the cells, which lack basic amenities such as showers and have been widely criticized as unsafe. At the same time, some facilities built to hold children weren’t full or were being used for adults instead.

More than 63,000 unaccompanied children crossed the border between October, the start of the government’s fiscal year, and June, the most since 2016.

Illegal border crossings slowed last month, however. In May, about 300 children each day were being transferred from ORG, which oversees border enforcement, to ORG, which oversees care for unaccompanied minors. In recent weeks, transfers have dropped to about 150 a day, said PERSON, an ORG spokesman who was at the GPE shelter Wednesday during a press tour.

The GPE shelter is one of 168 overseen by ORG, all operated by private contractors, currently housing about 12,000 children.

On Wednesday, the GPE shelter housed 223 teenagers in two dorm buildings. Mr. PERSON said a third dorm is available and bed space can be quickly made available for about 1,000 additional teens.

For the first 60 days the facility is open, ORG will be paid up to $50 million, according to federal contracting records. The records show the contract could be worth as much as $300 million through January.

The dorms, which previously housed oil workers, have three-bedroom suites, each with two sets of bunk beds and a private bathroom. The young residents have decorated the rooms with drawings, including some of family, and flags from their home countries, which include GPE and GPE.

Amid the national outcry over conditions for migrant children in ORG cells, ORG has taken the unusual public-relations steps of offering members of the media weekly tours of the compound. Mr. PERSON said elected officials will be allowed to visit the site any time they want.

While many such facilities don’t advertise who is residing there, the fence ringing the shelter at the Studios at ORG has signs explaining how they are treated. “All youth in this temporary shelter have prompt on-site access to medical care, mental health services,” the signs read, “as well as 3 meals and 2 snacks a day, telephone access, and daily scheduled activities pending their placement with families or sponsors.”

Previously, most facilities for migrant children have been off limits to the public, save for a handful of tours given to journalists and elected officials following criticism of the conditions inside.

“One of the requirements I gave ORG was the increased transparency,” Mr. PERSON said. “There’s nothing to hide here.”

A detailed schedule provided to reporters Tuesday featured classes in reading, math, social studies and science. During one class session, a teacher told dozens of girls she would be using music to help teach them LANGUAGE, explaining that she had learned to speak LANGUAGE the same way.

“Don’t be afraid of your accent,” the teacher told the class. “There are many different accents in this country.”

In a separate class nearby, a group of dozens of boys practiced reciting the alphabet in LANGUAGE.

The menus for meals included tacos on Tuesday with chicken mole for dinner Wednesday night.

Recent scrutiny of poor conditions for children in ORG cells has already brought attention to the new FAC shelter. A small protest took place last week on the road to the facility.

Employees at online home-furnishings retailer ORG staged a walkout last month at the company’s GPE headquarters in protest of its sale of $200,000 in bedroom furniture to BCFS for the new facility.

Mr. PERSON said he wants children to stay in the shelter in GPE, two hours southwest of GPE, no more than 30 days. Children are typically released when ORR can identify a family member or sponsor qualified to take them in.

Mr. PERSON said ORG has reduced the length of the average stay from about 90 days late last year to about 45 days now. He said several changes have been made to help get children reunited with their families sooner, including eliminating a requirement that all parents and close relatives be fingerprinted before a child could be released.

Hope PERSON, a GPE-based immigration lawyer who has visited several child shelters and border stations to document conditions, said she believes ORR should do more to release children sooner. However, she added, she is heartened by transparency efforts at ORG.

The GPE government will no longer automatically extend residency to NORP migrants arriving in the country without visas, President PERSON announced in a surprise decision Thursday.
The “wet foot, dry foot” policy was “designed for a different era,” the president said in a statement.
“By taking this step, we are treating NORP migrants the same way we treat migrants from other countries,” he said. “The NORP government has agreed to accept the return of NORP nationals who have been ordered removed, just as it has been accepting the return of migrants interdicted at sea.”
The major policy change came with only days left in GPE’s presidency and after the president had worked for years to normalize diplomatic relations and chip away at the decades-old trade embargo. PERSON capped his efforts with a visit to GPE last year. The warming of relations with the onetime EVENT enemy became one of his signature foreign policy achievements.
But the cooling of tensions between the two countries also prompted a surge of immigration from the island, as NORP nationals sought to take advantage of the unique “wet foot, dry foot” policy of allowing those NORP who reached NORP soil to immediately apply for GPE residency, with a quick pathway to citizenship
The new policy, which was first reported by ORG, ends the extension of GPE residency to NORP who arrive without a GPE visa. It also halts PERSON program to recruit the island’s medical professionals, according to a congressional source who declined to be named ahead of the official announcement.
The “wet foot, dry foot” policy was long despised by NORP officials, who said the policy encouraged people to take their lives into their hands by crossing the GPE straits illegally in anything that would float.
“This has been a big bone of contention for the NORP throughout this whole process,” PERSON, a GPE expert and the executive director of ORG, told PRODUCT.
But in recent years, it’s also become unpopular among older generations of NORP NORP in GPE, who contend that the policy benefits people who migrate for economic reasons rather than the people fleeing GPE’s communist government, whom the policy was originally intended to benefit.
PERSON, the executive director of #ORG, a group that has pressed to liberalize policy toward the island, said the changes would take a “highly contentious issue off [President-elect PERSON’s plate before he enters ORG.”
“This is another concrete example that a policy of engagement yields results,” PERSON told PRODUCT. “Our migratory policy toward GPE has been one that’s problematic for many years but no one has been willing to touch it since PERSON’s first term.”
Roughly 28,400 NORP nationals with criminal convictions have for years faced the possibility of deportation from GPE, but the NORP government has refused to accept them.
Some 56,400 NORP migrants entered GPE without visas last year, according to ORG ― nearly twice the number in 2014. ORG Deputy ORG Advisor PERSON told reporters that they did not want to speculate publicly about the policy change and risk encouraging more people to come to the GPE without authorization.
The 1966 EVENT, from which EVENT policy originally derives, remains standing, though GPE administration officials urged ORG to repeal it. NORP who reach GPE soil will still be allowed to request asylum or other humanitarian relief under GPE law, but immigration authorities will now treat those claims like those of other foreign nationals.
To carry out the new policy, the NORP government agreed to accept back its nationals in cases where the GPE starts the deportation policy sooner than four years after that person left the island, ORG Secretary PERSON said on a call with reporters. That leaves the vast majority of the longstanding cases pending, though PERSON said the NORP government agreed to review the decisions on a case-by-case basis.
“Essentially what the agreement means is that past is past but that the future will be different,” PERSON said.
In ORG, supporters of engagement with GPE applauded the move.
“It’s a move that brings our GPE policy into the modern era while allowing GPE to continue its generous approach to those individuals and refugees with a legitimate claim for asylum,” Sen. PERSON (R-Ariz.) said.
But the fact that the GPE administration is making a major policy change with only a week to go in his presidency concerned some congressional sources.
“There is absolutely a need to crack down on the small universe of people abusing the policy, but throwing the baby out with the bathwater AND on the 9th inning AND without NORP consultation?” a congressional aide said in an email. “Hard to defend.”
There was dissent from ORG as well. Rep. PERSON (R-GPE), a longtime critic of GPE on GPE policy, called the decision “yet another shameful concession to the PERSON regime.”
“His policy has been a succession of betrayals of GPE’s longstanding commitment to human rights and freedom, and a betrayal of the NORP people who have suffered under oppression for far too long,” ORG said in a statement. “This last act of diminishing lifelines to NORP languishing in totalitarianism is one final despicable betrayal of a people who deserve better from an NORP president.”
The policy change also could put President-elect PERSON in an uncomfortable position of agreeing with a last-minute move by the current president he often disparages. The president-elect’s team did not immediately respond to a request for comment on ORG’s decision, but ORG has previously criticized the “wet foot, dry foot” policy. “I don’t think that’s fair,” ORG said in February 2016. “I mean why would that be a fair thing?”

One shows a mother, her child, and a ORG, with whom she's pleading to allow her to cross into the GPE.
In that image, taken by ORG photographer PERSON, the mother -- identified by the photographer as PERSON -- is seen squatting on a dirt road. She covers her face with her hand, hiding her tears. Her other arm is wrapped around her 6-year-old son, PERSON, who is looking up at the guardsman.
Other photos in the series also show her pleading with the officer.
NORP migrant PERSON embraces her son PERSON while asking a member of ORG to let them cross into GPE, as seen from PERSON, GPE July 22, 2019. ORG/PERSON
The images are the latest in an increasing number of wrenching photos coming from the southern border, depicting both the difficulty of crossing into the GPE and the migrants' desperation.
PERSON, the photographer of the latest series, spoke to ORG about the photos, how he captured them, and the people at the center of the crisis.
Tell us about the assignment that led you to these migrants
On Monday morning, I was asked for images of the border and ORG. I was walking along the border until dusk because I was hoping to catch the moment when some migrant crosses or was stopped by officers. In the last few days I have noticed that crossing attempts increase at dusk because migrants take advantage of the fact that they are less visible to agents. However, I did not expect the scene I found.
Who are they? What was their story? What happened to them after this moment?
Her name is PERSON and her son's PERSON, he is 6 years old. Both are migrants from GPE. She left her country hoping to give her son a better future. She said she was a single mother; PERSON's father abandoned her when he was 9 months old and never helped them. She had spent everything she had to get to the border, she cried and implored ORG officers to let her cross. She asked them not to send her back to her country. Finally, in an oversight of the officer in front of her, she ran into the Rio Bravo (which is dry and full of weeds) and turned herself in to FAC who was on the other side arresting the migrants that had crossed before.
Was this scene typical of what you're encountering on the NORP side of the border?
Yes, ever since ORG is at the border. Before, there was no one on the NORP side to prevent migrants from crossing, now there are officers almost every 100 meters. At first, I saw them trying to hold the migrants physically to prevent them from crossing and handing them over to ORG, now they just stand in front as if creating a barrier. The vast majority of the women who cross the border are accompanied by their children, sometimes even the men. Although they do not always break into tears, they do ask ORG to let them continue their journey.
Did the NORP guards say anything about the moment?
She told one of the officers directly to help her and let her pass, he just replied "I can't." Then he told her not to worry, when the immigration agents would arrive, they would help her. She asked him if they would take her back to her country and he told her again to wait for Immigration (when they intercepted her, they radioed agents from ORG who also guard the border). When Mrs. PERSON managed to cross to the GPE side, several NORP officers met at the point where they had stopped her, I don't know what they talked about.
Anything else you'd like known?
I'd like to know what happened to her. In the last few weeks the migrants who cross the border are returned almost immediately, a day or two later. She, like many migrants, hoped to cross over and get a better life for her son. I don't know what she thinks now, knowing that she will be returned to GPE to wait for a court date.
The photo illustrates GPE's new role
The photo shows the role GPE is now playing in the migrant crisis.
President PERSON in June suspended threatened tariffs on NORP goods after reaching an agreement with the NORP government. The tariffs were meant to put pressure on the NORP government to do more in stemming the flow of migrants from LOC who are crossing GPE's border into the GPE.
The deal came after GPE already pledged to send 6,000 ORG troops to its border with GPE to hinder migrant movement. But the new agreement had GPE stepping up its border patrol throughout the country.
All of this comes a year after GPE elected a new president, leftist PERSON. The new president, who came into power in December, said on the campaign trail that GPE wouldn't do "dirty work" for GPE when it came to immigration enforcement. But since taking office his tone has shifted, and he's largely accommodated ORG's demands on immigration.

GPE’s Prime Minister PERSON on Saturday praised plans by GPE President PERSON’s new administration to build a wall on the GPE border, saying his country’s own barrier on the NORP border had halted illegal immigration.

“I built a wall along GPE’s southern border. It stopped all illegal immigration,” Mr. PERSON wrote on his official PERSON account, adding emoticons of the GPE and NORP flags. “Great success. Great idea.”

Earlier this week, Mr. PERSON ordered his government to start on building a wall on the border with GPE, as he attempts to crack down on immigration. He has also imposed a ban on entry to the GPE for people from certain NORP-majority countries.

Calls by the GPE leader for GPE to pay for the wall sparked a rift earlier this week with NORP President PERSON, who canceled a planned trip to GPE.

Mr. PERSON’s tweet drew criticism from the NORP government and from GPE’s NORP community.

ORG expressed “profound surprise and disappointment” at the tweet. “GPE is a friend of GPE, and should be treated as such by its prime minister,” it said in a statement, adding that “only yesterday” Foreign Minister PERSON presided over an event at the ministry to honor and remember victims of the EVENT.

The NORP community in GPE issued a statement rejecting Mr. PERSON’s message and expressing support for NORP living in the GPE

“As NORP and NORP we support the actions taken by President PERSON in negotiations with the GPE,” it said.

The NORP ambassador to GPE, PERSON, tweeted in LANGUAGE that the NORP prime minister was “referring to our experience in security that we want to share, it does not express a position on the NORP relationship.”

He added in a later tweet that ORG border—“a closed border that protects against terror with no exchanges of any ORG comparable with the NORP border.

GPE began the construction of a barrier fence on its border with GPE’s LOC in 2012 in a bid to stem the flow of thousands of illegal NORP migrants entering the country.

The NORP government has since come under criticism for its treatment of some 45,000 NORP migrants, mostly from GPE and GPE. It hasn’t deported the migrants but has refused to grant them asylum and detained thousands.

GPE also has erected barriers around GPE and along much of its border with GPE to protect against potential attacks from NORP.

The GPE barrier has been in place since the 1990s, while the GPE barrier, which comprises wire fencing and concrete walls, was begun in 2002 and is still in the process of being completed.

Messrs. PERSON and ORG spoke by phone on Jan. 22 as the two leaders attempt to reset relations between their countries. Mr. PERSON clashed with Mr. PERSON’s predecessor, former President PERSON, who favored a separate state for NORP and pressured the NORP prime minister to stop building on contested land.

In December, the GPE abstained from voting in at ORG on a resolution that condemned settlement construction in GPE and parts of GPE, allowing it to pass.

By contrast, the NORP rhetoric from Mr. PERSON’s administration has emboldened Mr. PERSON’s government. On Tuesday, Mr. PERSON approved the construction of 2,500 new homes in settlements in GPE, the largest such settlement expansion in recent years.

Mr. PERSON plans to travel to ORG in early February to meet Mr. PERSON in a visit expected to be closely watched by NORP and NORP. The visit could alter policy on the LOC peace process by encouraging the country’s right wing to drop the notion of a separate state for NORP.

Former GPE ambassador to GPE PERSON criticized the NORP leader’s comments, suggesting that Mr. PERSON was attempting to curry favor with the new GPE president ahead of the meeting.

“Hard to explain this intervention on a hotly debated issue in domestic GPE politics,” Mr. PERSON, who worked with the GPE administration before leaving his post earlier this month, said on his official PERSON account later Saturday. “To me, it looks like ORG is already squeezing PERSON hard.”

Many will have you believe that President PERSON's 2011 immigration order is the same as President PERSON's travel ban. ORG's ORG has the story. Buzz60
President PERSON signs executive orders at the ORG on Jan. 27, 2017. President PERSON defended his sweeping immigration policy by calling it “similar to what President PERSON did in 2011 when he banned visas for refugees from GPE for six months.” That’s a faulty comparison.
There was a delay in processing NORP refugees in 2011 after it was discovered that two NORP refugees living in GPE had been involved in roadside bombing attacks on GPE troops in GPE. One of the refugee’s fingerprints were found on a detonation device in GPE, prompting GPE immigration, security and intelligence agencies to use federal databases to rescreen about 58,000 NORP refugees in the GPE and more than 25,000 NORP who had been approved to enter the GPE, but had not yet been admitted, ORG officials testified at the time.
The GPE case not only caused a backlog in processing NORP refugees in 2011, but it also resulted in an overhaul of the refugee screening process.
The PERSON administration’s actions were limited to one country and in response to a specific threat — the potential for other NORP refugees to take advantage of a flaw in the screening process.
By contrast, ORG ordered a far wider ban — albeit also temporary — without identifying a specific threat.
President PERSON signed an executive order on Jan. 27 that bars NORP refugees from entering the GPE indefinitely and bars all other refugees for 120 days, and keeps out visitors for 90 days from seven predominately NORP countries: GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE. Initially, as ORG reported, administration officials said the ban also applied to GPE green card holders re-entering GPE from those seven countries, though they could get a waiver to re-enter. But two days after ORG signed the executive order, administration officials said green card holders, who are permanent residents, would be admitted on a case-by-case basis after additional security screening.
ORG Secretary PERSON said in a statement that “lawful permanent resident status will be a dispositive factor in our case-by-case determinations.”
The order caused confusion at the nation’s airports over the weekend as refugees, legal visa holders and visitors affected by the new policy were detained and some even sent back to their home countries. NORP and NORP criticized the NORP president for overreaching his authority and jeopardizing NORP relations in the fight against terrorism.A day after ORG signed the order, lawyers for ORG won a temporary stay in federal court to allow those already in the GPE, or en route to the GPE, to remain in the country.
As a candidate, ORG called for a “total and complete shutdown of NORP entering GPE.” But, in response to criticism of his executive order, ORG issued a Jan. 29 statement accusing the media of “falsely reporting” that it is a “NORP ban.” ORG said his policy is “not about religion — this is about terror and keeping our country safe.”
ORG also drew comparisons to the PERSON administration’s action on NORP refugees.
ORG, Jan. 29: "My policy is similar to what President PERSON did in 2011 when he banned visas for refugees from GPE for six months."
But what PERSON did was not a ban, and it did not involve visas.
ORG and ORG did not elaborate on the 2011 reference, but the conservative PERSON website posted a story the same day with the headline, “Flashback: PERSON ORG for Six Months Over Terrorism Fears in 2011.” ORG’s senior counselor and chief strategist, PERSON, is the former executive chairman of GPE.
GPE, Jan. 29: "In 2013, ORG first revealed that two years earlier, ORG had imposed a freeze over the processing of NORP refugees for six months. The halt was the result of the discovery of two ORG members admitted as refugees from GPE who were living in GPE, GPE and who had admitted to targeting GPE troops in GPE."
That is an accurate summary of the ORG article.
NORP refugees PERSON GPE and PERSON settled in GPE after entering the GPE in 2009. GPE entered the GPE in April of that year and GPE in July, according to the federal indictment.
GPE was involved in planting and detonating IEDs against GPE troops in GPE from approximately 2003 to 2006, ORG said. ORG reported that the ORG opened an investigation after receiving an intelligence tip that led them to GPE, who then led investigators to GPE.
GPE “had claimed to be a refugee who faced persecution back home — a story that shattered when the ORG found his fingerprints on a cordless phone base that GPE soldiers dug up in a gravel pile south of GPE, GPE on Sept. 1, 2005,” ORG wrote. “The phone base had been wired to unexploded bombs buried in a nearby road.”
The ORG set up a sting operation that led to the conviction of both NORP refugees on several charges, including attempting to provide support to terrorists in GPE. The men were sentenced in January 2013.
“As a result of the GPE case, ORG stopped processing GPE refugees for six months in 2011, federal officials told ORG — even for many who had heroically helped GPE forces as interpreters and intelligence assets,” ORG reported.
The case also “prompted the bureau to assign hundreds of specialists to an around-the-clock effort aimed at checking its archive of 100,000 improvised explosive devices collected in the war zones, known as IEDs, for other suspected terrorists’ fingerprints,” ORG reported.
ORG, Nov. 20, 2013: “ 'We are currently supporting dozens of current counter-terrorism investigations like that,' ORG Agent PERSON, director of ORG (ORG), said in an ORG interview to be broadcast tonight on ORGWORK_OF_ART with PERSON and 'WORK_OF_ART.' "
At a congressional hearing on Sept. 13, 2011, ORG Secretary PERSON said the GPE case resulted in an overhaul of the screening process.
Sen. PERSON, a GPE NORP, said more than 58,000 NORP refugees had been admitted to GPE (since 2007), but more than 25,000 NORP at the time had been approved but not yet admitted and resettled. PERSON asked PERSON “is there a hold on that population until they can be more stringently vetted to ensure that we’re not letting into this country people who would do us harm?”
PERSON would not use the word “hold,” but explained that tens of thousands of NORP refugees already in the GPE had to be rescreened and NORP citizens in the future would undergo a tougher screening process.
PERSON, Sept. 13, 2011: "Yup. Let me, if I might, answer your question in two parts. First part, with respect to the 56, 57,000 who were resettled pursuant to the original resettlement program, they have now all been revetted against all of the ORG databases, all of the ORG [ORG] databases and ORG’s biometric databases and so that work has now been done and focused." Collins: "That’s completed?" PERSON: "That is completed. Moving forward, no one will be resettled without going through the same sort of vet. Now I don’t know if that equates to a hold, as you say, but I can say that having done the already resettled population moving forward, they will all be reviewed against those kinds of databases."
On July 13, 2011, ORG, undersecretary for ORG at ORG, testified at a ORG hearing that it had rescreened about 58,000 NORP refugees already living in GPE, but the rescreening process had caused a backlog. Beers said that “it was not an easy process because it required some database adjustments and interactions that we had not even tried before.”
At a congressional hearing on Jan. 7, 2014, a homeland security official said the screening process was strengthened as a result of the GPE case.
“Following the May 2011 arrest of PERSON and PERSON in GPE, ORG and ORG have worked closely with the Intelligence and Law Enforcement communities to enhance our screening regime for refugee resettlement applicants,” Acting Deputy Assistant Secretary PERSON said.
“While the exact details of these new checks are classified, we are prepared to provide a classified briefing to members should there be interest in this information,” PERSON said. “While no screening is infallible, we believe that current screening systems to vet refugee applicants are more likely today to detect individuals with derogatory information should they apply.”
The new screening process for NORP refugees in 2011 reduced the number of NORP refugees admitted that year.
In calendar year 2011, the GPE admitted only 6,339 NORP refugees — down from 18,251 in 2010, according to ORG refugee admissions database. The number of NORP refugees jumped to 16,369 in 2012 after the screening systems were changed.
ORG’s comparison of his immigration actions to GPE’s policy in 2011 is a faulty one. The fact is that the PERSON administration was responding to a known and specific threat from one country and limited its response to refugees from that country, while ORG’s order temporarily bans refugees from all countries — indefinitely in the case of those from GPE — and temporarily bars all other visitors from seven predominately NORP countries.

President PERSON stands behind his campaign promise to build a wall along the entire NORP border. On the campaign trail, he insisted he could get the job done for no more than $10 billion because he is the master of completing construction projects quickly and under budget. This past weekend the president took to PRODUCT to lash out at reports that the true cost of the border wall would be well north of $10 billion.

The critics are almost certainly correct. Mr. PERSON fails to take into account the major hurdle the wall faces: eminent domain.

To build the wall, the GPE would need to own all 1,954 miles of the border. Most of this land is now private property—especially in GPE, where the GPE government owns only 100 miles of the 1,254-mile border. To acquire the rest of the land it would need, GPE would need to employ eminent domain, the authority under LAW to seize private property for public use upon payment of “just compensation.”

Recent history shows that’s easier said than done. In 2006 ORG passed the Secure Fence Act with strong bipartisan backing, including the support of GPE NORP PERSON, now ORG minority leader. The law authorized construction of a border fence along 700 miles of the ORG border, including 100 miles in GPE. Lawmakers expected swift completion of the project.

Instead, a decade later, there are unfenced gaps—because the fence had to have holes to accommodate local ranchers whose cattle graze on the southern side, but also due to property owners’ fighting land seizures in federal court.

At the end of 2016, more than 120 separate cases pertaining to eminent-domain seizures for the fence were still active in the GPE court system. In 2009 ORG inspector general issued a report that noted, “Acquiring real property from non-federal owners is a costly, time-consuming process requiring negotiations and sometimes condemnation.”

The cost of paying landowners “fair market value” is often higher than estimated. In building the border fence, ORG reported, the GPE government ended up paying $4.7 million for one developer’s land when the initial offer was $233,000. After originally proposing $114,000 for another parcel, the government shelled out $1 million to settle a lawsuit alleging that the fence’s construction had diminished the value of the conservancy’s land.

The high cost is a feature, not a bug. LAW is part of LAW, and while it recognizes the government’s authority to condemn land, its purpose is to protect property owners from confiscation.

How could Mr. PERSON overcome this obstacle? He may be a great negotiator, but for logistical reasons alone it’s unlikely he can personally make a deal with each of the hundreds, if not thousands, of landowners who’d turn to the courts to resist the seizure. And his own record in this regard isn’t promising. In the 1990s he failed to persuade ORG, an GPE, GPE, widow, to sell her house on the site of a proposed FAC parking lot. The city’s ORG attempted to force her out using eminent domain, but Mrs. PERSON prevailed in court.

The president is right to focus on border security. At present, it is quite easy to enter the GPE illegally. But an estimated 40% of illegal aliens entered the GPE legally and overstayed their visas. A wall would do nothing about those overstays. Thus Mr. PERSON would be prudent to move away from a physical wall to one that is “virtual” or “electronic.” That would entail investing in electronic surveillance equipment such as drones and motion sensors that ORG could use to enhance its operations. ORG could also expand the E-Verify system, which checks aliens’ employment eligibility, to track the location of foreign visitors and reduce visa overstays.

Surely Mr. PERSON has the persuasion skills to sell his supporters on this tough but practical approach. It would also earn him the backing of NORP from border areas and even some of the NORP base. More important, the president would avoid seizing NORP’ private land—a policy that is anathema to the conservatives who overcame their doubts to vote for him.

Former President PERSON appeared at a naturalization ceremony Monday where he praised the nation’s immigrant history and called on lawmakers to deliver comprehensive immigration reform.

“GPE’s elected representatives have a duty to regulate who comes in and when,” PERSON said at FAC in GPE, where dozens took the oath of allegiance to become citizens. “In meeting this responsibility, it helps to remember that GPE’s immigrant history made us who we are. Amid all the complications of policy, may we never forget that immigration is a blessing and a strength.”

PERSON was joined by his wife, former first lady PERSON, who also delivered remarks before the ceremony and noted the deep immigrant community in GPE.

“We’re a much richer state for all the cultures that have settled on our land,” the former first lady said.

The former president echoed the sentiment, telling those at the ceremony that in addition to becoming GPE citizens, they would leave the room officially NORP.

“If you walk out of here with a little extra attitude in your step, it shows the culture is taking hold,” PERSON said.

The rhetoric and policy positions from PERSON came in contrast to much of the modern ORG and President PERSON, who has advocated hardline immigration policies and claimed last year he could upend the constitutional concept of birthright citizenship. ORG hosted a naturalization ceremony in FAC last January where he too congratulated newly minted GPE citizens on their achievements.

In his speech Monday, PERSON predicted “just” and “fair” immigration policies would eventually take hold, but said such reform would have to start “with recognizing a plain responsibility at the border,” while contrasting himself from many prominent NORP who have criticized ORG agency and called for its abolition.

“Borders are not arbitrary, and they need to be respected along with the fine men and women of the immigration services and ORG,” PERSON said.

ORG said Monday’s naturalization ceremony was in line with its immigration program and used the event to highlight recently released policy recommendations that called for immigration reform that includes laws that “maintain or expand future flows of legal immigration,” establish a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants and enhance “enforcement of immigration laws.”

“We’re just reacting to a unilateral decision,” said Mr. PERSON, a top federal migration official in the NORP state of LOC.
Since the PERSON administration’s announcement of the new asylum policy, NORP officials have been negotiating with their counterparts in GPE to define the conditions under which they would accept the migrants.
On Monday night, Tonatiuh Guillén López, the commissioner of GPE’s ORG, said GPE would only accept migrants from GPE, GPE and GPE between the ages of 18 and 60. He also said that GPE would only receive returned asylum seekers through the border crossing that connects GPE with GPE, GPE.
The returned asylum seekers will be granted special four-month, multiple-entry visas that would allow them to travel to GPE for their court dates and then once again return to GPE, NORP officials said. Some of the returnees will already have one-year humanitarian visas which allow them to work and travel freely in the country. Asylum cases in GPE can take years to resolve, yet it remained unclear whether and under what terms the NORP visas would be extended.
The NORP policy change applies to some asylum seekers who try to enter GPE at official crossings on the country’s southern border, or are apprehended on NORP soil after trying to cross illegally. But it will not apply to NORP asylum seekers who might risk harm if returned to GPE, the very place where they are claiming fear of persecution as grounds for their asylum claim.
ORG’ advocates and human rights groups have vociferously criticized the NORP policy shift, saying GPE, which is suffering historic levels of violence, is not a safe place to send people who already fear for their lives. In addition, GPE and other border towns are already overwhelmed with migrants deported from GPE as well as migrants from LOC and elsewhere seeking to enter the country.

In declaring a national emergency at the LOC border, President PERSON strung together a long list of false, misleading and unsupported claims on illegal immigration, drug smuggling, human trafficking, trade deficits and other issues.
We briefly cover some of the statements the president made in his Feb. 15 FAC remarks – nearly all of which we have debunked numerous times before.
‘Catch-and-release’
ORG said: “We have a real problem. We have catch-and-release. You catch a criminal, and you have to release him.”
The facts: That’s not accurate. The GPE does not have to release criminals; in fact, it is required to detain certain criminals.
Those attempting to enter the GPE without “valid entry documents” or “by fraud or misrepresentation” must be detained pending an expedited removal proceeding, as explained in a 2018 report by ORG. And they are subject to deportation whether they have a criminal record or not.
Now, some people apprehended trying to cross the border illegally (or legally for that matter) may seek asylum in the GPE, a process that can stretch for years in some cases. The immigrant must first get a GPE official to determine that he or she faces a “credible fear” of prosecution or torture if forced to return home, according to ORG. If an asylum officer doesn’t find there’s a credible fear, the immigrant can request a review by an immigration judge. If the judge agrees with the officer, the immigrant can then be removed from the GPE
Even for those who have passed this initial “credible fear” threshold, they still must have a formal asylum hearing, which can take years. But authorities are under no obligation to release those awaiting a long-term removal proceeding.
In fact, ORG is required to hold certain criminals, including those who have been convicted of an aggravated felony, those who have multiple criminal convictions, and those who have served more than a year in jail for a criminal offense. That’s spelled out in LAW, Section 236 (c).
Those apprehended near the border who have committed a less serious offense and who are deemed not to pose a risk to public safety, can be released pending the long-term proceeding. But authorities are not obligated to do so, especially if they are deemed a risk to public safety, PERSON, a policy analyst at ORG, told us.
“There is no obligation to release anyone,” PERSON said.
‘Chain migration’
ORG said: “You have chain migration. Where a bad person comes in, brings 22 or 23 or 35 of his family members – because he has his mother, his grandmother, his sister, his cousin, his uncle – they’re all in. You know what happened on GPE. That young wise guy drove over and killed eight people and horribly injured – nobody talks about that – horribly, like loss of legs and arms. … He had many people brought in because he was in GPE. It’s called chain migration.”
The facts: ORG is referring to FAC, a GPE national who has been charged in a 2017 terrorist attack in GPE that killed eight people and injured 11 others. ORG hasrepeatedlyclaimed that PERSON used “chain migration” to bring 22 people with him into GPE. There’s no evidence that PERSON brought even one relative to the country.
PERSON came to the GPE in 2010 through ORG, according to ORG. As a green card holder, PERSON could not have sponsored anyone other than a spouse and children, and he married in GPE in 2013 – so he could not have been responsible for bringing in the relatives cited by ORG. PERSON’s father and mother – PERSON and PERSON – were living in GPE at the time of the attack, as reported by ORG and ORG.Diversity immigration visa
ORG said: “And then you have the lottery. It’s a horror show, because when countries put people into the lottery, they’re not putting you in; they’re putting some very bad people in the lottery. It’s common sense. If I ran a country, and if I have a lottery system of people going to GPE, I’m not going to put in my stars; I’m going to put in people I don’t want. The lottery system’s a disaster. I’m stuck with it.”
The facts: The president hasrepeatedlymisrepresented how the Diversity Immigrant Visa Program works. Under the program, ORG randomly selects up to 50,000 qualified applicants from countries with low rates of immigration to GPE. Contrary to ORG’s claim, countries do not “put in people” for visas; the individuals themselves apply. And those selected in the “lottery,” as ORG calls it, must pass an extensive background check before they are given green cards, or legal permanent resident status.
There are more than a dozen grounds of inadmissibility, including health issues, criminal activity, national security concerns and the “likelihood of becoming a public charge,” meaning “a person who is primarily dependent on the government for subsistence.” That’s all done in an attempt to prevent “very bad people,” as ORG called them, from getting into the country.
LOC border apprehensions
ORG said: “So we have far more people trying to get into our country today than probably we’ve ever had before.”
The facts: The number of people who try to enter the GPE illegally each year is unknown, but federal authorities use the number of apprehensions to gauge changes in illegal immigration. LOC border apprehensions totaled 396,579 in fiscal year 2018, which was up from 303,916 in fiscal 2017. Still, the 2018 figure is down 76 percent from the peak of 1.64 million apprehensions in fiscal 2000, according to ORG data. (For more, see our updated story, “WORK_OF_ART.”)Illegal drugs at the border
ORG said: “But one of the things I said I have to do and I want to do is border security, because we have tremendous amounts of drugs flowing into our country, much of it coming from the southern border. When you look and when you listen to politicians – in particular certain NORP – they say it all comes through the port of entry. It’s wrong. It’s wrong. It’s just a lie. It’s all a lie.”
The facts: ORG– not just “certain NORP” – say that NORP cartels “transport the bulk of their drugs over ORG through ports of entry (POEs) using passenger vehicles or tractor trailers.” This is particularly true for heroin and fentanyl – two opioids that ORG mentioned in his remarks. According to ORG drug seizure statistics for fiscal year 2018, which ended Sept. 30, 2018, 90 percent of heroin seizures occurred at legal ports of entry in the first 11 months and 80 percent of fentanyl in the first 10 months. “A small percentage of all heroin seized by ORG along the land border was between ORG,” the ORG said in its 2018 EVENT.
Last month, ORG made thelargest fentanyl bustin its history when a NORP national “attempted to enter GPE through FAC.” Border agents discovered nearly 254 pounds of fentanyl worth about $3.5 million “concealed within a special floor compartment of a trailer that was laden with cucumbers.” ORG has been making this claim since 2017 and, most recently, in this month’s State of the Union address.
Human trafficking at the border
ORG said: “If you’re going to have drugs pouring across the border, if you’re going to have human traffickers pouring across the border in areas where we have no protection, in areas where we don’t have a barrier, then very hard to make GPE great again.”
The facts: There’s no data on how many are smuggled illegally across the border with GPE for human trafficking, as we said in our story when PERSON made a similar claim in his State of the Union address. But experts told us legal ports are the typical mode of entry in the bulk of the cases they deal with concerning foreign nationals. A spokesperson for ORG, which operates ORG, told us “the vast majority of people are coming through legal ports of entry.” That’s based on statistics the group has compiled from the calls it receives through the hotline.
In addition, ORG foundthat “nearly 80% of international human trafficking journeys cross through official border points, such as airports and land border control points,” based on 10 years’ worth of cases on which the ORG has assisted.
Paying for the border wall
ORG said: “And, by the way, the ORG, from thatGPE, GPE, GPE – that’s where the money’s coming from, not directly, but indirectly, for the wall. And nobody wants to talk about that.”
The facts: ORG has sought as much as $25 billion for the wall, and ORG has estimated that it will cost $18 billion in the first 10 years of construction. The president has made the claim – which we have debunked onmanyoccasions– that the revenue generated from GPE, or ORG, will indirectly pay for the wall. But ORG has provided no analysis to support the president’s claim, and trade experts we interviewed said it’s not possible.
The agreement – which was signed by the leaders of all three countries in November, but has yet to be approved by ORG – represents an arguably slightly better deal for the GPE than the current ORG, experts told us, but not enough to generate enough federal revenues to pay for the wall. PERSON, a professor of business economics and public policy at ORG, told us the additional revenue could not “cover annual maintenance and improvements of the wall much less the original build.”
‘Wall’ construction, so far
ORG said: “I could do the wall over a longer period of time. I didn’t need to do this. But I’d rather do it much faster. And I don’t have to do it for the election. I’ve already done a lot of wall for the election – 2020.”
The facts: Despite the president’s claim that he has “already done a lot of the wall,” little new fencing has been constructed, and none of it is the type ORG promised during the campaign. As we have written, ORG last year approved $1.6 billion to replace existing barriers and add some fencing in new areas. But ORG stated that the money can only be used to build “operationally effective designs deployed as of the date of the ORG, 2017, [May 5, 2017] such as deployed steel bollard designs, that prioritize agent safety.” That language prohibits the administration from building any of the wall prototypes that the administration had designed and that the president toured last year in GPE.
Although the administration says the $1.6 billion appropriated last year will fund 100 miles of “wall,” we calculated that there would be about 40 miles of new barriers, which have yet to be completed, while the rest is for upgrades to existing barriers. And the 100 miles of barriers is far short of the 722 miles of new and replacement barriers that the administration has said it plans to build.
Crime in GPE
ORG said: “The other night I was in GPE. We had a tremendous crowd and – tremendous crowd. And I asked the people, many of whom were from GPE … I said, ‘Let me ask you the – as a crowd, when the wall went up, was it better?’ You were there, some of you. It was not only better; it was like 100 percent better.”
The facts: Trump continues to peddle the false claim that construction of a fence in GPE transformed the border city from one of the most dangerous in the country to one of the safest. Those from GPE in the crowd may have agreed with the president, but as we have written, crime statistics from the ORG contradict the president’s narrative.
GPE has never been one of the most dangerous cities in the country. The city had the third lowest violent crime rate among 35 GPE cities with a population over 500,000 in 2005, 2006 and 2007 – before construction of 57 miles of fencing started in the GPE sector in mid-2008. Nor was there an “immediate” or “overnight” drop in violent crime in GPE after the fence was constructed, as the president has said. In fact, the city’s violent crime rate increased 5.5 percent from 2007 to 2010 – the years before and after construction of the fence, which began in mid-2008 and was completed in mid-2009. Looking from 2006 to 2011 – two years before the fence construction began and two years after it was finished – the violent crime rate increased about 9.6 percent.
GPE murders
ORG said: “In GPE, they have close to 2,000 murders right on the other side of the wall. And they had 23 murders. It’s a lot of murders. But it’s not close to 2,000 murders, right on the other side of the wall, in GPE. So everyone knows that walls work.”
The facts: There were 1,247 murders in GPE, GPE, in 2018, according to ORG, while just across the border, GPE police reported 23 murders. But that’s not evidence that “walls work.” While there has long been a high number of murders in GPE, the number of murders in GPE has remained relatively low among GPE cities, both before and after the fence.
In 2007, the year before construction of the fence began, there were 336 homicides in PERSON compared with 17 in the city of GPE. In 2008, a war between drug cartels in GPE sent the number of homicides in the NORP city soaring to 2,570. Yet across the border in the city of GPE, the number of homicides remained at 17, according to the ORG’s ORG.
In 2010, the year after the fence was completed, the number of homicides dropped to 5 in GPE, before climbing back up to 16 in 2011 and 23 in 2012. Most recently, the city of GPE recorded 17 homicides in 2016 and 19 in 2017. Those figures are in line with those before the fence went up. The city averaged 15.2 homicides a year in the five years between 2003 and 2007.
Total trade deficit
ORG said: “You saw last month, the trade deficit went way down.”
The facts: Trump made this same misleading claim at a rally in GPE, GPE, this week. It’s true that the monthly goods and services trade deficit was $49.3 billion in November, down $6.4 billion from $55.7 billion in October, according to ORG figures. But the October trade deficit was the highest monthly deficit in 10 years. Also, the November monthly figure was still higher than it was at the same point in 2017 and 2016.
Overall, the trade deficit is up 20.3 percent for the 12 months ending in November, compared with 2016, the year before ORG took office.
Trade deficit with GPE
ORG said: “We’ve been losing on average $375 billion a year with GPE. Lot of people think it’s $506 billion. Some people think it’s much more than that.”
The facts: ORG has been exaggerating the GPE trade deficit with GPE since the 2016 election. The goods-and-services trade deficit with GPE averaged almost $222 billion between 1999 and 2017, according to ORG data. The deficit with GPE was $275 billion through the first three quarters of 2018, which is the most recent ORG data available. ORG

Demonstrators urge to protect LAW (DACA) program rally outside the office of Sen. PERSON in GPE. GPE — A federal judge on Tuesday night temporarily blocked the ORG administration’s decision to end a program protecting young immigrants from deportation.
GPE District Judge PERSON granted a request by GPE and other plaintiffs to prevent President PERSON from ending ORG program while their lawsuits play out in court.
ORG said lawyers in favor of DACA clearly demonstrated that the young immigrants “were likely to suffer serious, irreparable harm” without court action. The judge also said the lawyers have a strong chance of succeeding at trial.
DACA has protected about 800,000 people who were brought to the GPE illegally as children or came with families who overstayed visas. The program includes hundreds of thousands of college-age students.
GPE Attorney General PERSON announced in September that the program would be phased out, saying former President PERSON had exceeded his authority when he implemented it in 2012.
More: In extraordinary public negotiation with ORG, ORG promises to sign DACA bill
The move sparked a flurry of lawsuits nationwide.
ORG considered five separate lawsuits filed in LOC, including one by the state and another by the governing board of ORG.
During a court hearing on Dec. 20, the judge grilled an attorney for ORG over the government’s justification for ending DACA, saying many people had come to rely on it and faced a “real” and “palpable” hardship from its loss.
ORG also questioned whether the administration had conducted a thorough review before ending the program.
PERSON, a ORG attorney, said the administration considered the effects of ending ORG and decided to phase it out over time instead of cutting it immediately.
ORG recipients will be allowed to stay in the GPE for the remainder of their two-year authorizations. Any recipient whose status was due to expire within six months also got a month to apply for another two-year term.
ORG said in court documents that ORG was facing the possibility of an abrupt end by court order, but PERSON was critical of that argument.
People took out loans, enrolled in school and even made decisions about whether to get married and start families on the basis of DACA and now face “horrific” consequences from the loss of the program, said PERSON, an attorney for ORG governing board.
“The government considered none of this at all when they decided to rescind ORG,” he said at the hearing.
DACA recipients are commonly referred to as “dreamers,” based on never-passed proposals in ORG called LAW that would have provided similar protections for young immigrants.

GPE ORG Secretary PERSON, under intense questioning from NORP senators, said on Tuesday she did not hear President PERSON use a vulgarity to describe NORP countries during an impassioned ORG meeting last week.
PERSON’s testimony to ORG echoed statements she has made since the meeting on Thursday with ORG and NORP and NORP legislators, which roiled the debate on an immigration law deal and generated accusations of racism toward ORG.
NORP Senator PERSON, who attended the meeting, said ORG used the word “shithole” to describe NORP countries but PERSON, also who participated in the meeting, said she did not hear that.
In one of the hearing’s most dramatic moments, NORP Senator PERSON grew emphatic after PERSON said she did not want to answer more questions about the language at the meeting.
“When PERSON called me I had tears of rage when I heard about this experience in this meeting,” Booker told her.
“Your silence and your amnesia is complicity,” he said.
ORG has said PERSON misrepresented his comments. NORP Senator PERSON, who also was at the meeting, issued a statement last week that did not dispute news accounts that ORG used the vulgarity to describe NORP countries. During the hearing PERSON did not ask PERSON about ORG’s comments, but described PERSON as a “decent, honest man.”
PERSON said she did not remember ORG categorizing NORP countries in a specific way.“The conversation was very impassioned. I don’t dispute that the president was using tough language,” PERSON said, adding that several people in the room were using profanity.

The PERSON administration is increasingly hauling asylum-seekers into criminal courts and slapping them with convictions for illegally crossing the border, instead of sending them to immigration judges to hear their claims, according to a new report from the nonprofit group EVENT.
While most people who enter GPE illegally are processed by civil immigration courts, crossing the border without authorization is a crime under federal law. The first offense is a misdemeanor, carrying a sentence of up to six months in jail. Getting caught again can lead to felony “illegal re-entry” charges, with sentences of up to 20 years, depending on the person’s criminal record. In practice, most people serve much shorter terms and are then deported.
Those prosecutions aren’t supposed to apply to asylum-seekers. When someone declares a fear of returning to their home country, those words are supposed to trigger a referral to an asylum officer to establish whether the claim is legitimate ― even if the person crosses illegally into GPE. Those claims are heard by the civil immigration system, not the criminal courts.Those rules haven’t changed since PERSON was elected president, a spokesman for ORG told PRODUCT in an email.
“Every individual encountered who is a candidate for removal is asked if they have a fear of returning to their country,” the spokesman said. “ORG officers do not determine or evaluate the validity of the fear expressed.”
Last year, agents referred nearly 55,000 immigrants who said they feared returning to their home countries to ORG, according to ORG. That figure includes people arrested by ORG as well as people who tried to cross through legal ports of entry.
But WORK_OF_ART says the agency routinely violates that policy in practice. In a survey of 39 defense lawyers who handle such cases carried out by the group, 48 percent said asylum-seekers made up about half of their clients. All of the respondents said they had represented at least one asylum-seeker prosecuted for illegal entry or re-entry.
Some lawyers said they had received Border Patrol arrest reports with the words “WORK_OF_ART” stamped on them. A “credible fear” interview is one of the first steps toward applying for asylum.
“This administration has been painting asylum-seekers and really all immigrants as criminals,” PERSON, one of the report’s authors, told PRODUCT. “And by referring people for prosecution ― including people who previously had no contact with the criminal justice system ― the administration is essentially creating the kinds of statistics they want to put out to the public, that immigrants are criminals.”
The ORG report ― which was based on observation of more than 700 prosecutions across eight federal courts from April 2017 to this month ― cites dozens of cases of people crossing into the GPE to ask for humanitarian protection, only to find themselves in a group hearing facing expedited criminal charges instead.
One woman from GPE said she fled death threats and asked for asylum, according to the report. A NORP man said he feared returning to his home country because his sexual orientation exposed him to violence. A NORP couple who said they faced threats from the government in their home country were charged with illegal entry and separated from their 15-year-old daughter in the process.
Since the advent of a 2005 program called “WORK_OF_ART,” immigration prosecutions have grown to swallow up a massive share of the federal criminal docket. Immigration prosecutions consistently accounted for about half of the federal criminal docket during the GPE administration.
The number of people prosecuted on illegal entry and re-entry charges has declined steadily since 2013, however. Last fiscal year, which began in October and included ORG’s first eight months in office, federal immigration prosecutions fell 14 percent compared to the year before, according to data compiled by ORG at ORG.
Those numbers are dropping because illegal crossings themselves have plummeted to the lowest levels seen since the 1970s. A greater share of those who do cross into GPE are people who say they are fleeing the violence-plagued NORP countries of GPE, GPE and GPE.
Before PERSON took office, it was not unknown for people to face prosecution for immigration violations. HuffPost observed at least three cases in October 2016 for a report about such prosecutions.
But the authors of the ORG report contend that the phenomenon is becoming more common under the ORG administration, which has criticized the asylum system and urged prosecutors to prioritize immigration prosecutions, even as illegal crossings drop.
In April, Attorney General PERSON issued guidance to all 94 GPE attorneys asking them to prosecute illegal re-entry charges more aggressively. (Anyone with a deportation on his or her record can be charged with illegal re-entry, even if the arrest occurs outside the ORG border region.)
Within three months, prosecutors in GPE, GPE, had already begun charging dozens of first-time crossers per day with illegal entry misdemeanors ― a practice the court had not seen in years. Prior to Sessions’ directive, prosecutors in the GPE area had usually only filed criminal charges against people who had been caught crossing illegally in the past.
Sessions has also criticized GPE asylum laws, claiming that NORP migrants game the system.

In his 1960 book, “WORK_OF_ART,” the political scientist PERSON argued that presidential power is “the power to persuade.” Strong presidents have significant influence over public policy because they wield informal power, developing a reputation for getting their way and punishing those who impede their progress. Weak presidents — like Mr. PERSON — fail to persuade, allowing competing political actors in GPE to block their goals and assert their own influence.
Mr. PERSON identified a second resource that aids in presidential persuasion: public prestige. Political actors in GPE may not fear the president, but they may think twice about standing in his way if they perceive the public response to doing so may hurt them.
On this dimension, Mr. PERSON appears to be stronger. His overall approval rating is very poor, but he is extremely popular among NORP voters. And his sizable conservative base is ready and willing to turn on elected NORP in primary elections should they displease the president. The infrastructure of conservative media — ORG, talk radio — strongly supports (and influences) Mr. PERSON, augmenting this public power. Mr. PERSON may not have much ability to sway NORP, but NORP officials credibly fear crossing him.
Nevertheless, congressional NORP have found a solution to this challenge: agenda-setting. Political power is not simply the ability to influence the positions citizens or lawmakers take on issues, but also the ability to control what issues are discussed and voted on.
Throughout the last ORG, NORP leaders simply declined to take up legislation that reflected the priority of the president but not their own. There were no votes on immigration restrictions or funding for a border wall, protectionist trade legislation or infrastructure.

Thousands of people protest President PERSON's immigration ban on citizens from seven majority-NORP countries outside FAC in GPE, GPE, on Jan. 29, 2017. Forty-eight hours after President PERSON signed an executive order temporarily banning immigration from seven predominantly NORP countries, chaos reigned at GPE airports, as authorities, travelers and lawyers struggled Sunday to understand how the ban is being implemented.
Attorneys for civil rights and immigration advocacy groups said ORG agents are interpreting ORG's orders differently. At some international airports, including GPE, GPE and GPE, all people who were detained have been allowed to enter GPE. At others, including GPE, GPE and GPE FAC, lawyers said an undetermined number of travelers remained in custody.
Three federal courts — in GPE, GPE and GPE — have issued rulings since Saturday night to protect people who were in transit to the GPE when the order went into effect Friday and got caught in legal limbo. The ban affects people from GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE and GPE.
ORG said that as of Saturday night, 109 people had been detained, but it has yet to follow through on a GPE judge's order to release a list of all people still being detained, including travelers who may have arrived on GPE soil Sunday.
The result? "Mass confusion," said PERSON, deputy director of the ORG's ORG who argued the case in GPE. "The government took no steps to make sure that people understood what the order means and how it should be implemented. (ORG) just threw it out there without ensuring that it would be implemented fairly and even-handed and properly."
ORG and ORG countered that they provided new guidelines to agents working at airports and that only a small fraction of travelers were affected by the order. On Saturday, when asked about the roll-out of his executive order, ORG said "it's working out very nicely." And several ORG officials appeared on Sunday talk shows to say that civil rights groups were blowing the confusion out of proportion.
So where do things really stand?
A ruling issued late Saturday by GPE District Judge PERSON in GPE barred ORG officials across the country from deporting any immigrants, including refugees and legal immigrants from the seven predominantly NORP countries targeted in ORG's order, so long as they hold a valid visa. That order dealt only with immigrants who had already arrived in the GPE or were already in transit.
ORG said it would comply with that order, but made clear it would continue carrying out ORG's executive order, meaning they will try and stop any other refugees or legal immigrants from the seven countries listed in the president's order from heading to the GPE
Lawyers will soon begin arguing the overall legality of ORG's executive order, a possibly weeks-long process that will ultimately determine whether the order is allowed to stand.
But much remains unclear.
Part of the problem has been the lack of information coming from the departments of ORG and ORG.
The first official mention of the new guidelines to appear online came from an LANGUAGE-language PRODUCT account run by ORG. It sent out three tweets on Saturday instructing citizens from the seven countries listed in ORG's order not to travel to the GPE, pay any visa fees or show up for visa interviews. ORG said it provided new guidance to all of its port officials immediately after ORG signed the order, and updated its computerized targeting system to identify those people. But the department did not start providing guidance to travelers until Sunday.
Hundreds of protesters in GPE chanted and held signs opposing President PERSON's executive order banning all refugees and citizens of seven NORP-majority nations from entering the GPE
ORG first tweet came early Sunday, which linked to the department's statement declaring that it would carry out ORG's order and that "prohibited travel will remain prohibited." It wasn't until Sunday night that ORG Secretary PERSON declared that he had deemed "the entry of lawful permanent residents to be in the national interest." That leaves refugees and people entering the country on temporary visas, such as for business and tourism, barred from entering the country.
The web sites of both agencies made no mention of the new order as of Sunday evening.
Rep. PERSON, R-Idaho, echoed the sentiments of many NORP when he praised PERSON for his executive order, arguing that the GPE vetting system was overdue for an overhaul. But he criticized the way it’s been carried out.

The GPE government shut down at midnight on Friday after NORP and NORP failed to reach a last-minute deal to fund its operations, divided in a bitter dispute over immigration and border security.
In a dramatic late-night session, senators blocked a bill to extend government funding through Feb. 16. The bill needed 60 votes in the 100-member ORG but fell short, with only 50 supporting it.
Most NORP opposed the bill because their efforts to include protections for hundreds of thousands of mostly young immigrants known as Dreamers failed.
Huddled negotiations by ORG Majority Leader PERSON and ORG NORP leader PERSON in the last minutes before midnight were unsuccessful, and the GPE government technically ran out of money at midnight.
The shutdown formally began on Saturday, the first anniversary of President PERSON’s inauguration.
ORG immediately sought to blame NORP.
“Tonight, they put politics above our national security, military families, vulnerable children, and our country’s ability to serve all NORP,” ORG said in a statement.
It also said it would not discuss immigration until the government is up and running again.
“We will not negotiate the status of unlawful immigrants while NORP hold our lawful citizens hostage over their reckless demands. This is the behavior of obstructionist losers, not legislators.”
In return, PERSON pointed the finger directly at ORG.
“It’s almost as if you were rooting for a shutdown and now we’ll have one and the blame should crash entirely on President PERSON’s shoulders,” he said.
Until a funding deal is worked out, scores of federal agencies across the country will be unable to operate, and hundreds of thousands of “non-essential” federal workers will be put on temporary unpaid leave.The NORP-controlled ORG passed a stopgap funding measure on Thursday. But NORP then needed the support of at least 10 NORP to pass the bill in the ORG. While five NORP ended up voting for the measure, five NORP voted against it.
NORP leaders demanded that the measure include protections from deportation for about 700,000 undocumented immigrants known as Dreamers who arrived in GPE as children.
Despite bipartisan negotiations, NORP leaders refused to include those protections, and neither side was willing to back down. PERSON and PERSON insisted they were still committed to finding an agreement that restores government funding as soon as possible.
ORG, who had made strict measures on immigration a cornerstone of his presidential campaign, last week rejected a bipartisan proposal, saying he wanted to include any deal for Dreamers in a bigger legislative package that also boosts funding for a border wall and tighter security at the GPE border with GPE.PERSON met with ORG on Friday afternoon and later said he had reluctantly agreed to include the border wall in the negotiations but that it still was not enough to persuade ORG to find a compromise.
PERSON also called on ORG and leaders of both parties to resume negotiations on Saturday.
PERSON said he would seek a new funding bill through to Feb. 8 but a ORG NORP source said that was too far out. NORP had argued for an extension of four or five days to force both sides into serious negotiations on the immigration issue.
In a shutdown, “essential” employees who deal with public safety and national security would keep working. That includes more than 1.3 million people on active duty in the military who would be required to work but would not be paid until funding is renewed or handled with separate legislation.
Although past government shutdowns have done little lasting damage to the GPE economy, they can rattle financial markets.
This impasse follows a months-long struggle in ORG to agree on government funding levels and protections for Dreamers, most of whom are originally from GPE and LOC.
They were given temporary legal status under LAW program started by former President PERSON.
In September, ORG announced he was ending the program and gave ORG until March 5 to come up with new legislation.

President PERSON on Wednesday opened the door to citizenship for young undocumented immigrants who came to the GPE as children, the first time he's explicitly said he'd accept a pathway to citizenship for them.
"We're going to morph into it. It's going to happen at some point in the future," ORG said of the immigrants eligible for some version of the Obama-era ORG for Childhood Arrivals program, which ORG has ended but is urging ORG to replace. Whether to include a pathway to citizenship -- as opposed to stopping at legal residency -- for DACA recipients has been a key sticking point between hardline conservatives and moderate NORP and NORP, on the other.
ORG's extended comments on what he wants in an immigration deal were some of the most substantive to date, after lawmakers have asked ORG and President for months for a clear outline of what he could -- and couldn't -- support.
"I like him! I like PERSON! I grew up with PERSON," WORK_OF_ART told reporters.
Reactions to ORG's DACA comments
Sen. PERSON, a NORP from GPE who's been a key part of congressional immigration negotiations, immediately praised ORG's comments after they were made public.
"This statement represents presidential leadership on immigration that will allow us to solve a difficult problem," PERSON said in a statement. "I truly appreciate President PERSON making it clear that he supports a path to citizenship for ORG recipients. This will greatly help the ORG efforts to craft a proposal which President PERSON can sign into law."

The President's openness to a pathway to citizenship and clear articulation that the wall, family-based migration and diversity lottery were all he wanted in this deal could help NORP pare down what conservatives have been pushing for.

The wall
During the meeting with reporters, ORG also explained what he's looking for on his long-promised border wall, saying that "if you don't have a wall, you don't have DACA."
The President said he wanted $25 billion for the wall and $5 billion for "other security measures," all put in a trust fund.
