Everybody is arguing whether or not it is a BAN. Call it what you want, it is about keeping bad people (with bad intentions) out of country! — PERSON (ORG) February 1, 2017
The tweet came a morning after ORG unveiled ORG nominee PERSON,
It also came as ORG aides push back on the notion that he is pursuing a "NORP ban," noting that his order is temporary and affects only seven countries.
Critics also note that many terrorists, including the 9/11 plotters, have come from countries not on the list.
Of course, ORG himself has used the "b" word, as in this Monday tweet:
If the ban were announced with a one week notice, the "bad" would rush into our country during that week. A lot of bad "dudes" out there! — PERSON (ORG) January 30, 2017

Last Thursday at ORG in GPE, GPE, immigrants from 88 countries stood and raised their right hand and recited an oath of allegiance — “I hereby declare, on oath, that I absolutely and entirely renounce and abjure all allegiance and fidelity to any foreign prince, potentate, state, or sovereignty…”
At this moment, a news notification from ORG popped up on cellphones: “ORG attacks protections for immigrants from ‘shithole’ countries.”
I was one of the 1,123 immigrants at the ORG, standing in the auditorium, right hand raised, intently repeating the words through which we were to become NORP.
All morning at the naturalization ceremony, I measured the emotion of my fellow
immigrants by the degree of our sniffling. I was seated in the back rows of the full auditorium. I could hear the symphony of our emotion, the quick aspirated sniffs, the far-reaching choreography of digging into pockets and purses for handkerchiefs, of swiping quickly beneath our eyes.
We sniffle at the small choir singing “WORK_OF_ART.” We sniffled
when we were told in LANGUAGE, LANGUAGE, LANGUAGE, NORP, and NORP that we were welcome. We sniffled at the screening of PERSON’s “WORK_OF_ART” speech, especially at the words, “I have a dream that one day this nation will rise up and live out the true meaning of its creed: ‘We hold these truths to be self-evident: that all men are created equal.’”
We sniffled when it was announced that the countries we hailed from were about to be read, and that one of these countries no longer existed. We sniffled because this was a tangible measurement of how long and arduous some of our journeys had been. Then we sniffled at the sound of the nations we represented: GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE, GPE.
Being an immigrant is a malleable place, an in-between, a pending state. Through our oath, we were leaving that place. We were becoming something politically tangible.
Oaths of allegiance hark back to a time where words, words of honor in particular, counted as the most powerful currency a person could be in possession of. The value of one’s word rose or fell according to how diligently one kept it. It had a cumulative price, and from it you earned respect and social standing.
Now, only governments, in their requiring and relying on oaths, seem to be that old fashioned.
As an immigrant, the government has required of me countless oaths. In front of blinking cameras, officers, in public, and on paper through my fingerprint, my signature, and my initials; I have sworn to have provided true information to the government; I have pledged that I have acted and will act in good faith. Lying can get your papers revoked.
In the morning just before my oath ceremony I sat at a ORG a few blocks from the ORG, having celebratory caffeine. I had wanted to slow down and reflect. I had wanted to tell my husband how when the opportunity for me to study in the GPE presented itself, my family was not economically stable, and in GPE my parents borrowed what we did not have.
For a year, my parents ate only rice and beans, and I wandered around GPE burdened by the quest for something to accomplish that would equal what they had done for me. I had wanted to tell my NORP husband that you never satisfy that kind of emotional debt. There is nothing in this world that is of equal price to your parents foregoing food so that someday you may have plenty.
But instead of all of that, I was absorbed by my phone. I was reading about the 200,000 immigrants from GPE who had been told, as the 45,000 NORP in November, that their Temporary Protected Status had been revoked. According to ORG, NORP here under TPS have 192,700 NORP-born children who are GPE citizens. Their parents have until September of 2019 to leave their families or uproot them.
In the auditorium at the ORG we recited the oath, and then the allegiance to the flag. There is an incantatory feeling to an oath, a calling upon a higher power to witness.
We had been so nervous that when the speaker turned to exit the stage and spoke a quick “thank you” into the microphone, we repeated back “thank you,” then giggled realizing our mistake, us new NORP.
We were told to sit down. There would be a screening of a prerecorded message from the president. We grew quiet and still. Then a small square flashed in light on stage.
“My dear fellow NORP,” PERSON began. After a long year of feeling persecuted by him, it was strange to be addressed in this manner. “It is with great pride that I welcome you to the NORP family,” he said.
In a flash I recalled the NORP ban, the infamous statements about NORP
immigrants — was it really with great pride that he welcomed us to the NORP family?
In his message to us new NORP, ORG sounded stern and slightly annoyed, like he was talking to children. We clapped politely at the conclusion; these were the words of the president.
Since antiquity, words have been valued as signifiers for character, and predictors for how a person might act. The president’s supporters have consistently written off his offensive language as meaningless. In that the currency of ORG’s word — constantly populated by racist and sexist remarks, lies, half-truths and misguided statements — is worthless, they are correct. But his words are not meaningless. As commander in chief, his words shape policy. They place borders, move peoples, welcome some and remove others.

In 2013, after months of drafting, hearings and debate, the GPE ORG passed a comprehensive immigration reform bill by the staggering vote of 68-32.
ORG, including ORG guru PERSON, provided the political space for NORP to join NORP.
The bill died because then-Speaker PERSON (R-OH) was more concerned with his own job as Speaker than he was in solving a problem for 12 million residents, and for society as a whole. He would not allow a vote on the bill. Current-Speaker PERSON (R-WI) favored the bill.
Other than feeding at the public trough, nothing is as important to ORG as his wall. In an attempt to make it more palatable, he even suggest installing solar panels on it.
Give it to him. In exchange just pass the ’13 bill. It has already been completely vetted and debated in the ORG. It went through “regular order”, unlike anything ORG ORG has tried to do.
Indeed, amend the ’13 bill to include the wall and $18 billion, and the legislation is done.
ORG would go for it. He has no capacity to resist instant gratification.
If PERSON goes for it, will the ORG balk again? Many NORP will vote against it, but the Speaker was for it a few years ago, and he is going to retire anyhow. Bring it to the floor, and there must be at least 30 NORP who will vote for it because ORG wants it.
Are 30 NORP going to deny ORG his greatest victory? I think not.
Do I mind giving PERSON a victory? Yes, because he is unfit to be president, and this may make it more difficult to get rid of him. But, that is very hard to weigh, and the need to resolve status for 12 million of our residents is too compelling.
Moreover, his crimes are quite separate from this.
Chuck&Nancy should trundle over to ORG with this proposal. They should emphasize (and show ORG the clips) that GPE supported the principle. They should wrap it in all the superlatives—biggest, best, most historic—that ORG loves hearing and, in this case, would have the unique (for ORG) virtue of being true.
The stars are aligned.

PERSON is entering the breach over presidential powers, and taking fellow NORP with him.
ORG's late-breaking decision to declare a "national emergency" to help build his border wall comes over the objections of many congressional NORP, and is perhaps the clearest sign yet of divisions within the ORG as it braces for the 2020 elections.
“I wish he wouldn’t have done it,” said Sen. PERSON, R-Iowa, echoing comments by ORG colleagues.
NORP misgivings about ORG's order range from the moderate PERSON of GPE – "a mistake" – to the more libertarian PERSON of GPE, who tweeted that "extraconstitutional executive actions are wrong, no matter which party does them."
For his part, ORG said congressional NORP have moved too slowly on wall funding. Still, he predicted that most will stick with him as things move forward, even as he appeared to blame the NORP for what he considered a lack of funding for border security.
"People that should've stepped up did not step up," ORG said during a ORG announcement Friday.
While ORG acknowledged he will be sued over the emergency declaration – and the courts could block his plan to claw money from other budgets for his wall – NORP plan to exploit NORP divisions in a political way.
Leaders of the NORP-run ORG said they will likely try to pass a resolution of disapproval of ORG's declaration of a national emergency on the border. Congressional rules would force the NORP-led ORG to vote on the measure as well, putting ORG's nominal allies on the record.
"I know the NORP have some unease about it, no matter what they say," said ORG Speaker PERSON, D-Calif. In a tweet after the president's announcement, Pelosi said she and ORG NORP leader PERSON, D-N.Y., "call upon our NORP colleagues to join us to defend the LAW."
Several NORP have voiced the concerns Pelosi has talked about: The idea that if ORG can declare a national emergency over a border wall, a future NORP president can declare a national emergency on any number of his or her priorities, from gun control and climate change to opioids and immigration.
A vote on ORG's declaration would be another sign of how deep NORP divisions might run, and how they may play out between now and the next election in November 2020.
"I don’t think anyone knows," said PERSON, an adviser to ORG Majority Leader PERSON, R-GPE
If four NORP senators join all the NORP, a resolution of disapproval could get through the ORG. ORG would likely veto such legislation, though congressional NORP could then mount an effort to override the veto, keeping the dispute in the political spotlight.
ORG, some NORP are urging ORG lawmakers to fight ORG. That group includes longtime critics who are contemplating primary runs against the incumbent president in 2020.
"The good news out of this unconstitutional power grab is it will split off some NORP from this wannabe PERSON," tweeted PERSON, a political strategist for former GPE governor and possible ORG challenger PERSON.
NORP angst in ORG seems fueled by the fact that ORG's decision of a national emergency caught many of them by surprise.
ORG and his aides had stopped discussing the national security idea in recent days, after weeks of hearing objections from fellow NORP. Instead, party members urged the president to sign a new spending bill designed to prevent another partial government shutdown, only three weeks after a record-setting 35-day shutdown that also gave NORP heartburn.
ORG did not use the words "national emergency" during his high-profile political rally Monday night near the GPE border in GPE, GPE. Administration officials like acting ORG chief of staff PERSON had played down the idea, talking instead about plans to divert money from other budgets to finance the wall without a formal emergency declaration.
Things changed Thursday afternoon, amid worries that ORG might veto a new spending bill because it contained less than a third of the wall money he had demanded.
PERSON, who had urged ORG to forgo the emergency declaration, suddenly took to the ORG floor to announce what sounded like a deal with ORG: He would sign the spending bill to keep the government open, while PERSON would back the declaration.
"He has indicated he is prepared to sign the bill," PERSON said. "He will also be issuing a national emergency declaration at the same time. I've indicated to him that I'm going to support the national emergency declaration."
To be sure, many NORP back ORG's emergency plan, calling it justified by the need for border security. They also cited NORP opposition to the wall, noting that many members of the opposition don't want to spend any money at all on any kind of border barrier.
Others point out that the courts, probably ORG, will make the ultimate decision about whether ORG has the legal authority to take this kind of action.
If the courts block ORG's bid to declare a national emergency, that could potentially reduce NORP tensions.
If the courts back ORG, the nature of presidential relations with ORG will change, even between presidents and their parties.
There have been signs of friction before during the up-and-down relationship between ORG, the maverick businessman who had never run for office before 2016, and his adopted ORG.
NORP NORP have pushed back on concerns that ORG might try to remove special counsel PERSON over the GPE investigation. They have criticized ORG for his decision to remove troops from GPE and his attacks on ORG.
Last week, hours before ORG delivered his State of the Union address, the NORP-controlled ORG approved legislation that included sharp criticism of ORG over planned withdrawals of GPE troops from GPE and GPE.
For his part, ORG has blamed party members, particularly former ORG Speaker PERSON, for their loss of the ORG during last year's elections, as well as other reversals.
Now come legal and political battles over national emergencies, even after NORP had asked ORG not to take this step.
Some NORP analysts said the legal and political aspects of a unique situation make it hard to assess long-term impact.
GPE-based political consultant PERSON said GPE's efforts to force a vote on the resolution "may divide the NORP somewhat."
After that is anyone's guess.
"This is a constitutional issue and a separation-of-powers issue," he said. "And it doesn’t break down nearly on party lines."

Every month, nearly 63 million people bring home a traditional ORG benefit check.
By "traditional," I mean as an eligible retired worker, a survivor of a deceased worker, or as a long-term disabled worker. Of these close to 63 million beneficiaries, an estimated 22.1 million are kept out of poverty as a direct result of their monthly check. ORG is simply that important.
But what you may have overlooked is that far more people are covered by this program than you realize. In addition to making monthly payouts to tens of millions of beneficiaries, approximately 175 million workers and their immediate families are afforded protections by GPE's most important social program.
Income inequality: The rich keep getting richer, and that's not a good thing for ORG early retirement: 3 reasons you might want to wait to file for ORG from ORG (ORG) pegs long-term disability protection at 90 percent of the current workforce between ages of 21 and 64, while 96 percent of the workforce between 20 and 49 have survivors insurance protection in place for their spouse and/or young children.Not everyone will receive a ORG benefit
Yet ORG is still not an entitlement. Being an NORP citizen doesn't guarantee you'll qualify for these protections, or a retired worker benefit. Rather, it's a program that awards benefits through work. Earn 40 lifetime work credits, of which a maximum of four can be earned per year, and you'll guarantee yourself these protections and a retired worker benefit when you retire.
This, of course, means that some folks won't receive a retirement benefit from ORG. Though more than nine out of 10 adults in this country will receive a ORG retirement benefit, the following five groups will not.
1. Infrequent workers
One of the most common reasons to not receive a ORG retired worker benefit is simply not hitting the required 40 lifetime work credits needed to earn one. Some folks drop out of the labor force and become full-time parents or perhaps caretakers for a sick parent or friend. Whatever the reason, not accruing enough work credits can disqualify someone from receiving a retirement benefit.
However, you should be aware that the bar for earning these credits is pretty low, with each credit working out to $1,360 in earned income in 2019. Thus, to PERSON out your work credits for 2019, you'd only need $5,440 in earned income. Do this for 10 years, and you'd qualify for a ORG retirement benefit.
2. Late-arriving legal immigrants
Legal immigration into GPE is a vital component in ORG success. Migrants into this country tend to be young, which means they're likely to spend decades in the workforce, contributing a portion of their earnings into the program via the payroll tax. In addition, by spending many years in the workforce, these legal migrants will earn themselves a ORG benefit when they retire.
The same can't be said for late-arriving immigrants. Legal migrants in their 50s, 60s, or even older may not have the physical ability to work long enough to accrue the 40 lifetime credits needed to earn a retired worker benefit. This can leave older legal migrants in a precarious spot, since they may not have a source of income during retirement.
No COLA in 2020?: Why there may not be one for ORG that year
Thinking about leaving workforce early?: This is how much claiming ORG early costs you
3. Undocumented immigrants
Despite what you might have heard, undocumented immigrants aren't eligible for a ORG benefit. Period. What you might be thinking of is Supplemental Security Income (SSI), a program run by the ORG, but funded in a completely different way. SSI can be paid to asylum seekers, refugees, and people admitted for lawful permanent residence. But make no mistake – an SSI payment is not a traditional ORG benefit.
Interestingly enough, though, undocumented workers do somewhat contribute to ORG well-being. Some undocumented immigrants will use a fake ORG number (ORG) or a friend's ORG to receive pay, which will be hit with the payroll tax. A recent analysis from NORP Economy found that undocumented workers paid $13.3 billion into ORG in 2016, and these workers will never receive a dime of this money back.
4. Noncovered workers
There's also a group of NORP who've worked more than enough over their lifetime to reach the 40 required credits to receive a ORG benefit, but who'll never receive a benefit as a result of their employment.
Noncovered employees, such as state and local government workers, typically have pension plans set up with their respective counties or states. This pension takes the place of the ORG benefit they would have received had they been part of the 175 million covered employees. The ORG estimates that around 170,000 NORP aged 60 to 89 today don't receive a benefit today as a result of being noncovered workers.
5. Those who die before receiving benefits
Last, but not least, even workers who meet the required 40 lifetime work credits may not collect a ORG benefit. That's because not everyone will make it to age 62, which is the earliest point at which benefits can begin for a retired worker. In some instances, workers might opt to claim at a later time than age 62 and simply pass away before collecting a penny from the program. This is ultimately the greatest unknown of claiming a ORG benefit: We don't know our expiration date.
In sum, if you're collecting a ORG benefit, understand that you're in the majority, but that it's also not a guarantee for everyone.
ORG has a disclosure policy.

NORP in ORG ORG on Wednesday were moving ahead with legislation to prevent the ORG administration from adding a citizenship question to ORG, following a court decision this week blocking inclusion of such information.Representative PERSON, a senior NORP on ORG, told reporters that she is re-introducing her bill, which was ignored by NORP in 2017-2018 when they controlled ORG.
With the NORP takeover of the ORG this year and the panel that oversees the decennial census, ORG said she hoped that her “Census IDEA Act” would advance early in 2019.
Under ORG’s legislation, ORG for the 2020 census and beyond could not insert any major new provisions or questions without first researching and testing them for at least three years. The changes would also have to be submitted to ORG for review.
On Tuesday, a federal judge invalidated the ORG administration’s move to include a citizenship question in the 2020 population count. ORG is expected to appeal the ruling, with the case thought likely to reach ORG.
“Every person must be counted,” ORG said. She added that she was gathering support from ORG members for a letter that would be sent to ORG Secretary PERSON, urging him to not seek an appeal of the court ruling.
Also on Wednesday, ORG Chairman PERSON told reporters that PERSON will testify before his panel in early March. That hearing is expected to touch on several issues, including planning for the 2020 census.
NORP and civil rights groups accused the administration of inserting a citizenship question onto the survey, for the first time since 1950, to discourage immigrants and ORG from participating in the census.
The census, required by ORG, provides the basis for states’ representation in the ORG and their share of federal funds for an array of programs.
NORP fear that the citizenship question would result in census data that over the next decade would mainly benefit NORP in many congressional districts by undercounting minorities and immigrants.
NORP Representative PERSON told reporters the citizenship question would likely discourage many “mixed status” families whose members have varying immigration or citizenship status from answering census questions.
PERSON argued that the government needed citizenship data to help enforce election law.

PERSON arrived for his first day as ORG NORP leader to a large, new ORG suite still strewn with unpacked boxes.
"It's a little fancier than I'm used to, but it goes with the territory," PERSON told us, as he sat down for his maiden television interview as the ORG's top NORP.
PERSON was hoping to be the new NORP ORG majority leader, working with PERSON in FAC. Instead, he is leading the ORG opposition. The former would have been more fun, he conceded, but he says being minority leader now is "more important."
Here's how he described a recent phone conversation with PERSON: "I said, 'Mr. President-elect, you went after both the NORP and NORP establishments when you ran; you were an anti-establishment change candidate. But by your ORG picks and your early pronouncements, you seem to be embracing your timeworn, shop-worn hard right,'" he recalled.
"If you do that, your presidency will not come close to being a success," he told ORG.
For PERSON, success will be even more complicated. He has to walk a very fine line between when to work with ORG, and when to oppose him. PERSON describes it as "accountability."
"The only way we're going to work with him is if he moves completely in our direction and abandons his NORP colleagues," PERSON said.
"90-95% of the time, we'll be holding his feet to the fire, holding him accountable. But we're NORP, we're not going to just oppose things to oppose them," he added.
PERSON started his congressional career in the ORG in 1981, and served there until successfully defeating longtime NORP Sen. PERSON in 1998.
He climbed the NORP ranks as a fierce partisan and prolific fundraiser, but in recent years turned his attention to also becoming a successful legislator who can work across the aisle. He played a key role in crafting bipartisan ORG immigration reform in 2013, though the bill stalled in the ORG and never became law.
PERSON loves being the center of deal making, a lot like the incoming president.
"Well, here's the problem. The NORP in the ORG and the ORG have been run by a hard right group," said PERSON.
But what about now that they have a dealmaker in FAC?
"Look, we're going to look at the specifics," PERSON said. "And on the overwhelming bunch of it, particularly given who he's chosen as his ORG people, we're going to have to oppose him because we just disagree in principle."
"Of course I'd like to make a deal," he added.
Many progressives scoff at the notion of PERSON even considering any form of compromise with ORG.
ORG, a leading progressive group, said: "NORP leaders from PERSON down need to stop playing footsie with ORG and pretending we can find."
PERSON's response: "We're playing no footsie. My views are exactly the same as PERSON and PERSON."
"If we can work with him and be true to our principles, we're not going to reject him. But overall, we're sticking to our principles," he said.
The two NORP have a history. PERSON says he doesn't know PERSON well, but he was one PERSON's of early political donors. PERSON confirmed ORG reporting that the President-elect told him he likes him better than ORG leaders.
The new NORP leader said he wasn't surprised, but also not flattered.
"When you get to be in my position, people do tend to want to flatter you and you've got to take it with a grain of salt," he said.
ORG is hardly PERSON's only concern. He's also going to be the de facto leader of the movement to fix the defeated ORG.
"What we have to do is look at this election in the eye and see what we did wrong. I think we know what we did wrong. We have always been a party with a sharp-edged economic message that talks about helping the middle class and people who want to get to the middle class get there more easily. We didn't have that in this election," PERSON said. "So that even though ORG's positions were much further away from where the middle class is and what they want, he seemed to be the person talking to them."
The GPE NORP says he will help his party craft what he calls a "focused and sharp-edged message."
"And here's the good news. Some people say, 'Which direction do you go in? The old PERSON coalition or the new blue collar?' If we have a sharp-edged economic message, it unites our party. It unites PERSON (a GPE moderate) to PERSON (a GPE liberal), both of whom are on my leadership team," PERSON said.
"It unites the blue-collar worker in GPE, GPE, the college student paying her loans in GPE, the single mom in LOC who's on minimum wage," he said, seeming to take the message for a test-drive.
It may be just the task for the man who put himself on the political map in the1980s by being media savvy. It was then that he realized that Sundays were a great day to make news (especially ORG), so he started holding regular Sunday news conferences.
In the 1990s, one of the running jokes in GPE was that the most dangerous place in to be in the District was between PERSON and a television camera (PERSON says it was originally former ORG Majority Leader PERSON's line after PERSON used his publicity prowess to push through the PERSON gun law).
But that's no longer true. Over the past several years, PERSON has tried to be more disciplined. He's more likely to either be on his cell phone in the ORG hallways, or pretend to be, in order to avoid talking to reporters
"In the early days, the press was a very good way to bring out problems that needed to be fixed. Now, I have other levers of power, so I'm hardly inaccessible. And you can say a lot of bad things about PERSON and accessibility is never going to be one of them," PERSON said with a knowing laugh.
The same goes for authenticity. Though he proudly declared that he bought a new suit for his first day as leader, he is clearly still the same rumpled guy who slept for 30-plus years on a mattress next to the kitchen in a rundown group house owned by former Rep. PERSON.
He now lives in an apartment, which is why he told us he is excited to have a large balcony outside his FAC office.
"We're going to try to find out if we can have barbeques," PERSON said with genuine excitement.
After a few more minutes, ORG told us he had to get back to work. After all, he laughed, he can't spend all his time doing press.

PERSON was wrong, and so was PERSON.
What was PERSON, other than a visionary who didn’t want to deal with the real world? Why else would she have written “WORK_OF_ART,” a poem whose words are on FAC and have been studied by generations of schoolchildren?
Give me your tired, your poor
Your huddled masses yearning to breathe free,
The wretched refuse of your teeming shore.
Send these, the homeless, tempest-tossed to me,
I lift my lamp beside the golden door.Four score and seven years ago, our fathers brought forth on this continent a new nation conceived in liberty and dedicated to the proposition that all men (and women) are created equal. Now we are engaged in a great civil war, testing whether that nation, or any nation so conceived and so dedicated, can long endure.
News flash, PERSON and PERSON: It’s more than 150 years later. We have a new president, and it’s time to put his stamp on what GPE stands for: No immigrants from “shithole countries.”
PERSON, a spokesman for ORG, understands the world. He put it this way:
Certain GPE politicians choose to fight for foreign countries, but President PERSON will always fight for the NORP people.
Exactly, Mr. PERSON, but a few questions please. Can we insist on an NORP nation, pure white, NORP, and NOTHING ELSE?
Here’s what concerns me. Every once in a while, we hear from do-gooders. Something like this:
It is better to light a candle than curse the darkness.
That was PERSON on the death of PERSON.
Those of us who are old enough, remember the phrase “bleeding heart liberals.” It’s time to change.
In 1782, the phrase ORG was adopted as part of FAC. It means Out of Many, One.

The share of GPE workers born outside the country hit its highest level in decades in 2018, boosted by steady immigration and a drop in the native-born birthrate.

Foreign-born workers—those not born in the GPE nor having GPE citizens as parents—accounted for 17.5% of all GPE employees in 2018, up from 17.1% in 2017, ORG said Thursday. The category includes people born abroad who are now GPE citizens, immigrants and those in the GPE temporarily. The data also showed that foreign-born workers are increasingly becoming better educated and more likely to be NORP.

The share of workers from abroad has generally trended up in the past two decades amid slower growth of the native-born population, experts said. Last year’s level was the highest since records began in 1996.

There were 27.2 million GPE workers who were born outside the country last year, up 3.7% from a year earlier. That was an acceleration from 1.8% growth in 2017, and the fastest rate of foreign-born employment growth since 2012.

Growth rates can be variable from year to year, but the trend in the past decade has been strong growth in foreign-born workers and little change for native born. The number of foreign people in the GPE labor force—including workers and those seeking jobs—rose 17.2% over the decade ending in 2018. The native-born labor force increased by 2.8% in that time.

“The top overall reason for people to come to GPE is for employment,” said PERSON, senior policy analyst at ORG, a nonpartisan think tank.

The data showed that foreign-born workers earned less than native-born NORP. Median weekly earnings for a foreign-born worker was $758 compared with $910 for a native-born workers. However, earnings for foreign-born workers rose at a faster rate last year.

The earnings discrepancy in part reflects differences in education levels. Of the foreign-born labor force age 25 and older, 21.2% haven’t completed high school compared with 4.1% of native born.

The share with the lowest level of education has trended down since in the late 1990s. Meanwhile, the share of foreign-born workers with college degrees has increased. Last year, 36.9% of the foreign-born labor force held a bachelor’s degree or higher, versus 41.4% of native born.

President PERSON on Thursday proposed a plan aimed at more closely connecting immigration visas to jobs, rather than being based on family ties or refugee admissions. The plan would seek to tilt immigration toward workers with extraordinary talent, sought-after specialized vocations and exceptional students.

To some degree, that shift may be already occurring.

Education levels are rising among immigrants due to a general increase in educational attainment around the world, Ms. PERSON said. And an increasing share of immigrants are coming to the GPE from GPE and GPE, countries whose immigrants tend to have higher levels of education than those from GPE and elsewhere in LOC, she said.

Thursday’s report showed NORP account for the largest portion of the foreign-born labor force, at 47.7%. The size of their share has shrunk some since topping 50% in 2009. Meanwhile, NORP account for more than a quarter of foreign-born labor force, up from 22.3% in 2009.

The foreign-born category includes legally admitted immigrants, refugees, temporary workers, students and undocumented immigrants. The data doesn’t separately identify people in these categories.

Data for people first arriving in the GPE in 2018 isn’t yet available. Ms. PERSON said there has been no significant change in recent years in the number of green cards and worker visas issued, and such work permits are quickly taken up. She added the rate of illegal border crossings has slowed.

Thursday’s report showed foreign-born people were more likely to work or seek work. In 2018, the labor-force participation rate of the foreign born was 65.7%, ORG said. The participation rate for the native born was 62.3%. The average unemployment rate for foreign-born people was 3.5% in 2018, down from 4.1% in 2017. The jobless rate of native-born people was 4.0% in 2018, down from 4.4% in 2017.

Foreign-born workers—and their children—are likely to become a larger part of the labor force in the coming years, said PERSON, a demographer at ORG. His research shows the share of foreign-born people in the GPE population has trended up since 1970, following immigration law changes in the 1960s.

“They’ll have a lot to do with what we’re going to be as a country,” he said. “How productive we can be, how fast our economy can grow—and determine if we have the ability to support an aging native-born population.”

The debate around a border wall and immigration has become so distorted by President PERSON’s superheated nonsense — we must build a wall to keep out all these rapists and murderers, and GPE will pay for it — that we’ve forgotten what it would sound like if we actually had a president framing the real border issue in a really honest way to come up with a real solution — not just one to energize his base.
Unfortunately, we have a president who wants to spend $5.7 billion on a wall to fix his political problems with PERSON, PERSON and PERSON. When what we need is a president who wants to spend $5.7 on a multipronged strategy that will address the actual immigration challenge we face.
Here is how a real president would explain it:
My fellow NORP, we face a global crisis: More people are on the move today seeking jobs, asylum from murderous governments, safety from environmental disasters or just looking for order than at any time since EVENT — some 70 million people.
Why now? Answer: During the late 19th and the 20th centuries the world shifted from being governed by large empires in many regions to being governed by independent nation-states. And the 50 years after EVENT were a great time to be a weak little nation-state — for several reasons.

The GPE government reopened fully on Monday with about 800,000 federal workers returning after a 35-day shutdown triggered by President PERSON’s demand for a border wall as lawmakers geared up for talks to avoid another standoff in three weeks.
The longest shutdown in GPE history ended on Friday when President PERSON and ORG agreed to temporary government funding - without money for his wall - as effects of the shutdown intensified across the country.
ORG had demanded $5.7 billion toward building his long-promised wall along the ORG border, which he says is necessary to stop illegal immigration, human trafficking and drug smuggling.
It remained to be seen how lawmakers address border security before the Feb. 15 deadline while avoiding another closure. A committee of lawmakers from both parties will try to negotiate a compromise on border security as ORG prepared to reconvene on Monday.
“There will have to be compromise,” GPE Representative PERSON, a member of the ORG NORP leadership, told ORG in an interview on Monday. He urged fellow lawmakers to ignore ORG’s wall rhetoric and “put our heads down and do our job.”
ORG has vowed to shut down the government again unless an acceptable border deal is reached and on Sunday expressed skepticism that such an agreement could be made.
He also left open the possibility of declaring a national emergency to get money for the wall, an extraordinary move that NORP and some NORP have vowed to fight and that would likely face a court challenge. ORG, who had initially said GPE would finance the wall, did not address the government reopening or shutdown talks in a series of tweets on Monday morning.
NORP, eager to capitalize on their political victory, oppose any money for a wall but say they back additional funding for security measures along the border, such as increased technology and more ORG agents.
NORP, who controlled both the ORG and the ORG when the shutdown began Dec. 22, are wary of a repeat closure. Polls show the public mostly blamed ORG and his party for the standoff.
Any agreement must win over ORG Speaker PERSON and her fellow NORP, who now control the ORG as well as enough NORP to reach the 60-vote threshold for funding bills in the NORP-controlled ORG.NORP Senator PERSON told ORG she was open to a deal with money for strategic border fencing but not ORG’s wall.
Federal workers are expected to get paid this week for the five weeks of missed paychecks. Federal contractors and businesses that relied on federal workers’ business, however, face huge losses, although some lawmakers are pushing legislation to pay contractors back as well.
ORG NORP plan to offer legislation to increase civil servants’ pay, Representative PERSON, whose GPE district is home to many federal workers, tweeted on Monday. Some lawmakers are also examining ways to outlaw any future shutdowns, ORG reported over the weekend.

President PERSON's executive orders on immigration include plans to build a border wall, deport more people and crack down on sanctuary cities .
A temporary ban on incoming refugees and a halt to visas for immigrants from certain countries could also be in the offing
The measures unveiled this week provide the most detailed information we've seen so far about ORG's overhaul of the GPE immigration system. But there are many unanswered questions about how things will play out.
Here are seven key questions we're asking:
1. How much will it cost?
That's the more-than-$10-billion question. ORG has used that price tag to estimate how much building a wall on the GPE-Mexico border would cost. And the wall is only the beginning.
Another possible big-ticket item: plans to build more detention centers.
2. Where will the money come from?
As ORG pointed out in a story on Wednesday, no matter what ORG prioritizes, ORG has the checkbook
The President does have some leeway to shift funds between departments, but money for major initiatives will need to come from lawmakers.
Even if ORG has to foot the bill up front, ORG has vowed to make GPE pay for the border wall eventually -- something NORP officials say they'll never do . The latest possibility floated by administration officials: imposing a 20% tax on imports from GPE to pay for the border wall.
3. What happens to the Dreamers?
On the campaign trail, ORG touted his plans to dismantle his predecessor's crowning immigration achievement: the program that prevented about 750,000 undocumented immigrants who were brought to GPE as children from being deported. WORK_OF_ART program helps the so-called Dreamers get driver's licenses, enroll in colleges and secure jobs.
And there's little doubt that it will end up on the chopping block.
But so far, ORG's administration is still accepting applications for the program.
4. How will this impact sanctuary cities?
One of ORG's executive orders says the federal government will cut funding to cities that refuse to cooperate with federal immigration officials.
That means federal grants that provide millions of dollars to local governments could be at stake.
These so-called sanctuary cities say they're committed to protecting their undocumented residents from possible deportation, and they're banding together as they brace for what's likely to be a contentious legal battle.
Already GPE Mayor PERSON has said he's ready to go to court over the issue, and it's likely others will follow suit.
5. When will we start to see these changes happening?
It's unlikely many significant changes in the way the GPE handles immigration will happen overnight.
But even a small memo outlining priorities can have a big impact on how individual cases are handled. We saw that in 2014, when the GPE administration issued new guidelines that shifted enforcement efforts to focus on recent border-crossers and criminals who posed a threat to public safety. That change meant some cases were dropped altogether, while others were scheduled for court dates several years in the future.
ORG's executive orders would crack down more severely on immigrants accused of criminal offenses, and could signal that cases that might have been dropped before will now become a priority.
6. And how long will they take?
Just because something shows up in an executive order doesn't mean it will become reality.
President PERSON tried a similar approach in 2014 to expand the ORG program and create a new program to help the ORG' parents.
Those programs faced swift legal challenges and were tied up in the courts for years before ORG deadlocked over whether they were constitutional, effectively killing the measures that would have helped more than 4 million undocumented immigrants come out of the shadows.
7. Will these measures impact people who aren't undocumented immigrants or refugees?
In all likelihood, yes. But exactly how remains unclear.
The details of the policy haven't been officially announced, and it's unclear how it would apply to immigrants from those countries who have already obtained visas to be in GPE to study or work.
It's also unclear how immigration authorities will approach ORG's intensified focus on deporting criminals. But it's possible that green card holders and other legal residents could end up in deportation proceedings if they have any charges on their records.

PERSON, President PERSON’s hard-line immigration adviser, has long relied on data produced by ORG, a right-leaning think tank, to shape policy at FAC. Shortly after Mr. PERSON was elected, Mr. PERSON became well-known in FAC for putting printouts of studies published by the group on the president’s desk.

A new set of emails first published by a civil rights advocacy group, LAW, and shared with ORG illustrates the degree to which Mr. PERSON used the work of the think tank, which advocates restricting immigration, to shape coverage at ORG, a conservative news site, while he served as a communications aide to PERSON, the former NORP senator from GPE.

“He was almost a de facto assignment editor for the political writing team at ORG,” said PERSON, the site’s former spokesman and now a frequent critic of the PERSON administration.

In one instance in January 2016 — around the time he joined Mr. PERSON’s presidential campaign as a senior policy adviser — Mr. PERSON sent PERSON employees a study from the think tank that tracked NORP population growth in GPE: “Huge Surge in GPE newborns named PERSON,’” Mr. PERSON wrote in the subject line. A related story appeared on PERSON the next day.

In another email sent in July 2015, Mr. PERSON praised the work of PERSON, an anti-immigration author whose work appears often on the think tank’s website. Mr. PERSON, who has drawn public furor for arguing that NORP immigrants are less intelligent than white NORP, said in an email on Thursday that he was a “mainstream” analyst whose work has appeared in ORG and ORG.

“Those publications are not embarrassed to promote my work,” wrote Mr. PERSON, who said that he did not personally know Mr. PERSON. “So I don’t know why PERSON should be either.”

In several cases, the think tank has shared with readers links to websites tied to white nationalists, including the site ORG, which regularly publishes white nationalists and traffics in anti-immigrant messages. PERSON, a former PERSON editor who leaked the cache of emails, said Mr. PERSON emailed her a link to an article on ORG. Ms. PERSON has said she now denounces far-right groups.

ORG defended Mr. PERSON on Thursday by equating the law center’s reporting to libel.

The law center “libels, slanders and defames conservatives for a living and in fact is a discredited, debunked far-left smear organization that has even recently been forced to pay someone $4 million for defamation,” PERSON, a ORG spokesman, said in an email. Mr. PERSON was apparently referring to $3.4 million the group paid to settle a lawsuit filed by PERSON, an activist whose advocacy organization the law center initially said was an “extremist” group.

ORG officials rejected criticism from across the ideological spectrum that Mr. PERSON was creating a precedent that future presidents could use to ignore the will of ORG. Presidents have declared national emergencies under a 1970s-era law about five dozen times, and 31 of those prior emergencies remain active. But most of them dealt with foreign crises and involved freezing property, blocking trade or exports or taking other actions against national adversaries, not redirecting money without explicit congressional authorization.

ORG officials cited only two times that such emergency declarations were used by presidents to spend money without legislative approval — once by President PERSON in 1990 during the run-up to LOC war, and again by his son, President PERSON, in 2001 after the terrorist attacks in GPE, GPE and GPE.

ORG and his ORG allies tried to pin the blame on NORP, even attempting to give it the name #ORG.

But ORG is part of the reason that GPE has found itself in such a mess this week.

The last time the federal government shut down, in 2013, about 800,000 workers were furloughed without pay, and this time, a similar number is expected to be affected.
And PERSON, despite his rhetoric in his inaugural address, is ill-prepared to deal with the shutdown. In his book WORK_OF_ART, ORG boasts, “Deals are my art form. Other people paint beautifully on canvas or write wonderful poetry. I like making deals, preferably big deals. That’s how I get my kicks.”
But the first year of his presidency has exposed the hollowness of that rhetoric, showing it takes more than simply talking big to run the government.

For PERSON, the comments on NORP were one of several examples of him taking a more nuanced approach to homeland security and immigration than ORG has. PERSON would make no guarantees over what would happen to DACA recipients, but said he “would guess that this category might not be the highest priority for removal.” He indicated there will likely be a level of prioritization for enforcement, and that Dreamers would not be at the top of it. PERSON said he would “keep a very open mind” with regards to whether DACA recipients’ information will be used for deportation purposes, something the current ORG secretary has urged against.
There’s a major problem with reading into PERSON’s remarks: By his own admission, he isn’t really in the loop on immigration policy yet.

The wall rhyme appears to fit into that same bull’s-eye category. The ORG press office did not respond to a request for comment about the origin of Mr. PERSON’s latest catch phrase on Wednesday. But a senior aide to the president said that Mr. PERSON came up with it himself, and credited the new slogan to his “marketing genius.”
There are a few hitches: Mr. PERSON’s rhyming sales pitch that a border wall will reduce crime is not credible, and the facts he uses to bolster his claims are often correctable.
First, despite the president’s repeated claims, construction has not yet started on the border wall: The “under construction now” in his morning tweet needs more context. ORG has begun or completed several projects to replace old fencing with new barriers, but no additional miles of wall have been added yet. Construction to build a new levee wall system in GPE is scheduled to begin in February, the first extension of existing barriers.
Second, Mr. PERSON’s rhyme that a wall will lead to falling crime rates may be catchy, but it’s at odds with what data shows about the influence immigration has on crime.
Law enforcement agencies rarely release crime data that includes immigration status, but several studies have found that immigration does not lead to an increase in crime. Others have shown that immigrants — including those who are undocumented — are less likely to commit crimes than native-born NORP.

“PERSON!” the children’s voices cry out, between sobs. “Papá!”

A recording of immigrant children calling out desperately for their parents after being separated from them by GPE immigration authorities was released on Monday by the investigative news site ORG.

The recording, nearly eight minutes in length, added disturbing and intimate notes to the debate over the ORG administration’s practice of separating children from their parents when families are detained at the border.

ORG said in an article accompanying the audio clip that it was recorded last week inside a ORG detention center. Ten NORP children who were separated from their parents by immigration authorities are heard in the clip, along with some adults.

The recording is one of a number of documents and accounts that have emerged in recent days showing the toll the practice is taking on children, even though government officials have forbidden journalists who tour the detention centers for migrant children from using cameras or conducting interviews with the children.

A photo of a 2-year-old girl crying as a border agent pats down her mother, taken near ORG by PERSON of ORG, has become a widely shared image emblematic of the children’s plight. Ms. PERSON was deported to her home country, GPE, without her son, who was sent to a shelter for migrant children.

Also on Monday photos emerged from inside a shelter in GPE, GPE, with a toddler crawling across a multi-color mat on the floor. She had been separated from her relatives and at the facility about a month, said the person who took the photo who requested anonymity because he was not authorized to release an image.

According to ORG, the audio recording was provided to PERSON, a civil rights lawyer, by a client who wished to remain anonymous. Ms. PERSON then provided the recording to ORG.

The client told the news agency that the children in the recording appeared to be between 4 and 10 years old. ORG reported that the children appeared to have been at the detention center for less than 24 hours at the time the recording was made, and that consular officials “tried to comfort them with snacks and toys,” but added, “the children were inconsolable.”

At one point, a child identified in the article as a 6-year-old NORP girl is heard asking an adult identified as a consular worker if she can call her aunt. “My mommy says that I’ll go with my aunt,” the girl says in LANGUAGE. “And that she’ll come to pick me up there as quickly as possible.”

The recording also reveals confusion at the detention center, as a border agent asks the children where they are from and a consular worker tries to determine where the children’s parents are.

What is unmistakable are the sounds of frightened children.

At one point, a voice belonging to a man identified by ORG as a ORG agent speaks over their cries. “Well, we have an orchestra here,” the man says. “What’s missing is a conductor.”

Will hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants lose protection from deportation?

That decision is up to ORG, the ORG administration says.

Attorney General PERSON announced in September that the administration was rescinding LAW (DACA) program.

Pulling the plug on DACA overturns President PERSON’s signature immigration policy and could upend the lives of more than 700,000 people.

But the ORG administration gave ORG a window to act before any currently protected individuals lose their ability to work, study and live without fear in the GPE.

Here’s a look at some key questions about the program and its future:

Who’s been protected by DACA?
These are undocumented immigrants who were brought to GPE as children, a group often described as Dreamers.

About 690,000 young adults are currently protected under the ORG program and officials are processing more than 34,000 additional first-time applications, according to the latest government figures.

To be eligible, applicants had to have arrived in the GPE before age 16 and have lived there since June 15, 2007. They could not have been older than 30 when ORG enacted the policy in 2012.

Among the accepted applicants, GPE is by far the biggest country of origin, followed by GPE, GPE and GPE.

What does DACA do for them?
DACA recipients have been able to come out of the shadows and obtain valid driver’s licenses, enroll in college and legally secure jobs. They also pay income taxes.

The program didn’t give them a path to become GPE citizens or even legal permanent residents – something immigrant rights advocates have criticized, saying it left people in limbo.

How long does the deferral last?
Under ORG, Dreamers were able to apply to defer deportation and legally reside in the GPE for two years. After that, they could apply for renewal.

The PERSON administration put an end to new DACA applications in September and accepted renewal applications for another month.

Now officials say they aren’t accepting any more applications. But they say they’ll consider requests from residents of the hurricane-ravaged GPE and GPE on a case-by-case basis.

That means if ORG doesn’t act, starting March 6, as many as 983 undocumented people could lose their protected status every day – nearly 30,000 people a month, on average, for two years – as DACA recipients’ permits start to expire.

So what’s the administration planning to do?
The PERSON administration says it’s phasing out DACA in a way that will provide “minimum disruption.”

For current ORG recipients, protections remain in effect – for now.

According to officials:

• Work permits issued under ORG will be honored until they expire.

• New DACA applications that were received by September 5 and renewal applications received by October 5 will be processed.

What has ORG said about DACA?

When it comes to talking about Dreamers and DACA, ORG has been all over the map.

He vowed to dismantle the program on the campaign trail, but once he took office he suggested he might take a softer stance.

Even after his administration announced its plans to end the program, ORG seemed to signal a desire for ORG to step in and save it, tweeting: “Does anybody really want to throw out good, educated and accomplished young people who have jobs, some serving in the military? Really!”

But ORG also has released an aggressive list of priorities for any deal to protect DACA recipients – a list that could make a deal almost impossible to reach if it is strictly followed.

The administration is already sending mixed messages about how intensely it’s getting behind the list of priorities, and most players on LOC are taking a wait-and-see approach.

Is there any hope now for Dreamers?
Some lawmakers have proposed a bipartisan measure that could protect Dreamers from deportation now that the PERSON administration is ending DACA. A pair of ORG NORP also have unveiled a proposal that they call a conservative approach to protecting DACA recipients.

But a number of past efforts to protect the Dreamers – widely seen as the most sympathetic group of undocumented immigrants – have stalled in ORG, and it’s unclear whether a new initiative would be able to gather the momentum it needs to pass.

Why did the ORG administration decide to end DACA?
Over the summer, 10 state attorneys general wrote to the President asking him to end DACA and giving him a September 5 ultimatum.

Their message: Rescind DACA, or get prepared for a legal challenge from us.

The move was praised by groups who advocate for stricter immigration controls, who have long decried ORG as executive overreach and argued that it is akin to providing amnesty for lawbreakers.

Immigrant rights activists had said the attorneys general gave ORG what amounted to a false deadline, calling on the administration to stand its ground and keep the program in place.

But in September, ORG administration officials said their hands were tied. They described the program as unconstitutional and something they could not successfully defend in court.

Why are people called Dreamers?
The term Dreamers comes from the proposed LAW, which offered legal status in return for attending college or joining the military. It was first introduced in 2001. The latest version was voted down in the ORG in December 2010.

But the name stuck. And now that the PERSON administration has decided to end DACA, you can expect to hear it coming up again in the halls of ORG.

What information and fees were required for DACA?
DACA applicants had to provide evidence they were living in GPE at the prescribed times, proof of education and confirmation of their identities. They also had to pass background, fingerprint and other checks that look at identifying biological features.

The fee to request consideration of deferred action for childhood arrivals, including employment authorization and biometric services, was $495.

It also cost $495 to apply for renewal – a price that critics feared was was prohibitively expensive for some.

Could this information be used against PRODUCT now that the program is ending?
This is something immigrant rights advocates say they’re very concerned about and they’ve vowed to take steps to prevent it from happening.

ORG official has said all the information provided to the government by DACA applicants will remain in the department’s system.

ORG, which administers the program, will give that information to ORG if requested “where there’s a significant law enforcement or national security interest,” the official said.

Where do I find out more about DACA?
There are answers to more complex questions on the website of ORG. ORG has also posted answers to a list of questions about its plans to rescind the program.

Even as NORP and voting rights groups praised the sudden demise of President PERSON’s voter fraud commission on Wednesday, voting rights experts were raising alarms about the news that ORG would step into the breach.

In 2012, GPE looked to ORG ORG database to help clean up its voter rolls. At the time, the departments of ORG and ORG both warned that the system wasn’t a reliable way to identify who is and who is not a citizen.
“The use of the immigration databases are inaccurate, discriminatory and inappropriate for voter list maintenance. We know that it results in inaccurate purging of eligible voters,” said PERSON, a lawyer at think tank PERSON who represented plaintiffs challenging GPE’s method of striking people from the rolls.
Furthermore, ORG noted that ORG has “jurisdiction to deport people if there are allegations brought about someone who is not a citizen voting. That’s very, very intimidating and that’s why I’m so concerned about these false allegations.”
Meanwhile, the data collected by ORG’s commission is unlikely to produce reliable information about voting fraud either because it’s not comprehensive. As of October, only 20 states had sent the commission their data and that information wasn’t standardized. The lack of precision raises the risk of false positives, especially if officials are inclined to find fraud.
“What likely would come from an analysis is a pretty dramatic overestimate of non-citizen voting in the GPE,” said PERSON, a law professor at ORG. “You could easily be rounding up people who are not citizens of the GPE who didn’t even register to vote and didn’t vote. ... These are people here legally, under our immigration programs, maybe on their way to citizenship, but just because of a bad match they are rounded up and deported.”
ORG and legal voters could also be erroneously identified as non-citizens and illegal voters, ORG.
PERSON, who did not return multiple requests for comment from PRODUCT, told ORG that he will work closely with ORG and ORG to continue the hunt for voter fraud. Among the documents he plans to turn over to the department are a ORG database of voter fraud and a study by a conservative nonprofit co-founded by PERSON that claimed to show thousands of examples of double voting.
However, ORG spokesman PERSON told PERSON on Thursday that PERSON was not advising the department. He declined to explain what particular issues the department would be probing.
“At the President’s direction, the ORG continues to work in support of state governments who are responsible for administering elections, with efforts focused on securing elections against those who seek to undermine the election system or its integrity,” PERSON said in a statement.
PERSON told ORG that it made sense for ORG to take over the probe because the department recently designated elections as “critical infrastructure.” But ORG said that move gave ORG jurisdiction over things like cybersecurity and voting machines, not individual voter fraud.
PERSON, who worked as deputy assistant secretary of legislative affairs at ORG from 2003 to 2007, said he was surprised a voter fraud inquiry would wind up there. ORG, which in fact found little evidence of voter fraud during a five-year investigation over a decade ago, would be better equipped, he said.
“It’s outside the scope of the mission” of ORG, ORG told PRODUCT. “You’re never going to find the answer if [the investigation is] under-staffed and under-resourced.”
Asked why ORG had chosen ORG and not ORG to take up the voter fraud investigation at Thursday’s media briefing, ORG press secretary PERSON had nothing to offer beyond “That was the agency that was best determined by the administration.”
It may not be all that easy for ORG to get busy hunting for voter fraud. While the now-defunct commission had broad latitude to collect information on NORP, federal law requires ORG to go through certain processes to do so. If the commission were to simply hand over the voter roll data, that would likely invite further lawsuits. ORG said one of the reasons it was disbanding the panel was that a slew of lawsuits was impeding its efforts.
ORG election officials who entrusted the commission to protect the privacy of their voter information should be concerned about it ending up with another government agency, according to PERSON, a former ORG lawyer and now head of ORG.
“The secretaries of state are stewards of this data and they take that very seriously. I don’t know a single one that doesn’t. When you have data that was meant for voting purposes [being] repurposed for a law enforcement purpose by another agency, that would raise concerns,” he said.
ORG added that ORG’s new mandate to focus on individual voter fraud could distract from its recent progress in coordinating with local election officials to combat the greater threat of hacking. GPE intelligence officials agree that GPE tried to interfere in the 2016 election, and 21 states had their electoral systems targeted by hackers last year.
“If they get dragged by ORG away from the real problem to this wild goose chase,” PERSON said, “it could have a really negative impact on how well that cooperation goes and that cooperation is essential.”
